(AP) -- The U.S. Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self defense after he encountered a 23-year old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release on Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital where he died, officials said.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nIn a statement, the Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office said the deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.\n\nFrisaro reported from Fort Lauderdale.", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WBOC TV-16"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@wboc.com", {"uri": "2024-05-350591645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:45:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:45:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:37:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.local10.com/news/national/2024/05/08/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says/", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "MIAMI - The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "local10.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-349156747", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:40:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:40:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:15:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/us/man-shot-dead-by-florida-police-identified-as-us-air-force-member", "title": "Man Shot Dead by Florida Police Identified as US Air Force Member", "body": "Senior USAF Airman Roger Fortson was shot dead by a Florida police deputy last week. | Image:AP\n\nFort Walton Beach: The US Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy. Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the US Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self-defence after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to a hospital where he died, officials said. The deputy involved was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nIn a statement late Tuesday, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the incident and the State Attorney's Office will conduct an independent review. He said the sheriff's office was \"saddened\" by the shooting.\n\nThe Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted.\"", "source": {"uri": "republicworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Republic World"}, "authors": {"uri": "8119432652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:56:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:56:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:56:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/branches/air_force/2024-05-09/airman-shot-florida-police-13804553.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation", "body": "MIAMI -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun.\n\nThe sheriff's office declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nHe was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived, Crump said.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nOn Wednesday, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", "source": {"uri": "stripes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8119469111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:25:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:25:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:21:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.fox10tv.com/2024/05/09/attorney-says-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment/", "title": "Attorney says deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun.\n\nThe sheriff's office declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nHe was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived, Crump said.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nOn Wednesday, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, Freida Frisaro in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "fox10tv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX10 {"uri": "2024-05-347830573", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:05:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:05:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T13:25:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/nation/us-service-member-shot-and-killed-by-florida-police-identified-by-the-air-force/", "title": "US service member shot and killed by Florida police identified by the Air Force", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- The U.S. Air Force said a 23-year-old airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self defense after he encountered a 23-year old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release on Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital where he died, officials said.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron. In a statement, the Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office said the deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-350257903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:03:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:03:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:47:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.maryvilleforum.com/news/state_news/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-want-a-transparent-investigation/article_2e334c93-432a-50e4-8afa-f542ed22eded.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation", "body": "The family of a Black U.S. Air Force airman fatally shot by Florida sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference calling for transparency in the investigation\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "maryvilleforum.com", "label": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Call Centers", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 99}], "image": null, "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-18", "textStart": 2847, "textEnd": 2855}], "sentiment": -0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 229, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8119284509", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:11:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:11:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:10:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-want-a-transparent-investigation/article_7c828034-bf4d-580b-a02d-c3f2b97a25c8.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation", "body": "FILE - Civil rights attorney Ben Crump speaks in the Audubon Ballroom, now part of The Malcolm X & Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center, in New York, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2024.\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, Freida Frisaro in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-18", "textStart": 2918, "textEnd": {"uri": "2024-05-350245151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:51:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:51:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:37:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-05-09/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says", "title": "Florida Deputies Who Fatally Shot US Airman Burst Into Wrong Apartment, Attorney Says", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-05-350507161", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:06:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:06:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:43:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/news/national/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-say-he-was-a-patriot/article_1564cfe7-e646-50d2-8cf8-934f5047c96a.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies say he was a patriot", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- The mother of a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle began crying while listening to her family's attorney recount the death of her son.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" said Chantimekki Fortson at a news conference on Thursday in Fort Walton Beach, where her son, Senior Airmen Roger Fortson, was living when he was killed.\n\nThe family's attorney, Ben Crump, said that Senior Airmen Roger Fortson said Okaloosa County sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump, a noted civil rights attorney, called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing\" and said the sheriff's office needed to own up to it instead of creating a counter-narrative that deputies were acting in self-defense.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. Fortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived, Crump said.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.", "source": {"uri": "santamariatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Santa Maria Times"}, "authors": {"uri": "8119655327", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:57:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:57:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:55:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.11alive.com/article/news/local/atlanta-airman-killed-by-florida-deputies-reaction/85-732fea99-416c-4820-8735-5f130959e2e7", "title": "'He was a patriot' | Family in tears following news of Atlanta airman killed by Florida deputies", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. -- The family of an Atlanta Air Force airman killed by sheriff's deputies in Florida gathered for an emotional conference on Thursday in an attempt to reframe his life and legacy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, a 23-year-old U.S. service member, was fatally shot on May 3 after the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office claimed a deputy responding to a call about a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\n11Alive confirmed Wednesday night from attorneys that Fortson was from Atlanta and graduated from McNair High School in DeKalb County. Following graduation, Fortson enlisted in the Air Force, where he was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field -- right near Fort Walton Beach.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump joined the family along with fellow Florida attorney Brian Barr.\n\nYou can watch the full conference in the video below:\n\nDuring the press conference on Thursday, Fortson's mother, Mica, fought back tears as she described her son as \"a gift.\"\n\n\"Where we come from, you don't end up where Roger ended up,\" she said about her son's journey to the Air Force.\n\nFortson would go on to be described as someone who was kind, intelligent, humble, and passionate, as well as a figure of inspiration in his family's life.\n\n\"My child taught us how to love, how to forgive,\" Mica added.\n\nThe young airman was also described by Crump as someone who was \"going to make it better for his mother, his siblings, and his family, so they could have a chance at the American dream.\"\n\n\"Roger Fortson was the best America had to offer. He was a patriot...He was fighting for our way of life,\" Crump said.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\nIn the conference on Thursday, Crump noted, \"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy...they killed a good guy.\"\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. {"uri": "2024-05-350241251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:48:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:48:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:38:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/us/florida-police-deputies-who-shot-airman-entered-wrong-apartment-lawyer", "title": "Florida Police Deputies Who Shot Airman Entered Wrong Apartment: Attorney", "body": "Senior USAF Airman Roger Fortson was shot dead by a Florida police deputy last week. | Image:AP\n\nMiami: Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black US Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nFamily lawyer calls for release of body cam footage\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response.\n\nA few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defence after encountering an armed man.\n\nThe office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nA tragic pattern\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the {"uri": "8119473690", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:25:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:25:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:25:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-want-a-transparent-investigation/JVUW3NSHHVCAVDPIF6KCXSIGVY/", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation", "body": "Crump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun.\n\nThe sheriff's office declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nHe was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived, Crump said.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nOn Wednesday, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, Freida Frisaro in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "daytondailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8118447042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:24:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:24:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:24:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.11alive.com/article/news/national/us-airman-shot-killed-by-florida-deputies-atlanta-native-dekalb-high-school/85-7f379820-e12f-4cdf-94c4-e451f2debed9", "title": "US airman shot, killed by Florida deputies inside apartment was from Atlanta, attorney says", "body": "ATLANTA -- A Black United States Air Force airman shot and killed in Florida by deputies at his off-base apartment complex was from metro Atlanta, according to attorneys.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, a 23-year-old U.S. service member, was fatally shot on May 3 after the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office claimed a deputy responding to a call about a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\n11Alive confirmed Wednesday night from attorneys that Fortson was from Atlanta and graduated from McNair High School in DeKalb County. Following graduation, Fortson enlisted in the Air Force, where he was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field -- right near Fort Walton Beach.\n\nFortson can be seen below on graduation day at McNair High School:\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a FaceTime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their FaceTime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd. Crump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nLast week when the sheriff's office said the deputy reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man, the office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.", "source": {"uri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Atlanta, Georgia"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": {"uri": "8119266482", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:59:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:59:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:58:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/national/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-want-a-transparent-investigation/article_1a0783a0-54af-5c19-83d2-5b7049d1a19e.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, Freida Frisaro in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Miami"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United
