{"uri": "2024-05-350493766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:50:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:50:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:44:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.startribune.com/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-want-a-transparent-investigation/600364742/", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies say he was a patriot", "body": "The mother of a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle began crying while listening to her family's attorney recount the death of her son.\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. -- The mother of a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle began crying while listening to her family's attorney recount the death of her son.\n\n''My baby was shot up,'' said Chantimekki Fortson at a news conference on Thursday in Fort Walton Beach, where her son, Senior Airmen Roger Fortson, was living when he was killed.\n\nThe family's attorney, Ben Crump, said that Senior Airmen Roger Fortson said Okaloosa County sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun.\n\n''For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,'' Crump said. ''They took a patriot from us.''\n\nCrump, a noted civil rights attorney, called the shooting ''an unjustifiable killing'' and said the sheriff's office needed to own up to it instead of creating a counter-narrative that deputies were acting in self-defense.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. Fortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\n''He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,'' Crump said.\n\nFortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived, Crump said.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n''At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,'' Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.", "source": {"uri": "startribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Star Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mike_schneider@startribune.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-05-350275776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:19:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:19:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:11:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2024/05/09/roger-fortson-death-okaloosa-county-sheriff-shooting/73624898007/", "title": "US airman Roger Fortson killed by deputies who may have hit wrong home, Ben Crump says", "body": "Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when he was shot by Florida deputies.\n\nAn active-duty airman was shot and killed during a deputy-involved shooting in Fort Walton Beach, Florida, last Friday, and his attorney is saying the police may have entered the wrong apartment.\n\nAccording to a 1st Special Operations Wing release, the airman was identified as 23-year-old U.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson. He was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron and entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nAccording to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, a deputy responded to a call of a disturbance in progress on the afternoon of Friday, May 3.\n\nThe deputy \"encountered an armed man,\" according to a news release, and the deputy shot the man.\n\nFortson was taken to a local hospital where he later succumbed to his injuries, according to police.\n\nThe deputy in question has been placed on administrative leave pending the results of an investigation from the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. Police said the state attorney's office will also conduct an independent review of the incident.\n\nRoger Fortson was alone in apartment, attorney says\n\nFortson's family has retained national civil rights and personal injury attorney Ben Crump to represent them. Crump has represented the families of Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, among others.\n\nAccording to a news release from Crump's law office, the encounter played out differently than what the OCSO has been reporting.\n\nCrump says a witness who was on a FaceTime call with Fortson at the time of the shooting said that Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at his door.\n\nFortson asked, \"Who is it?\" and failed to get a response, Crump said in a news release Wednesday.\n\nA few minutes later, Fortson heard an \"aggressive\" knock, but failed to see anyone once he looked out his peephole.\n\nFortson, concerned for his safety, retrieved his legally owned gun, the release says. As Fortson returned to the living room, the witness said, deputies \"burst through his door.\" When deputies saw the gun, they fired at Fortson six times.\n\nBen Crump: Civil rights attorney Ben Crump now represents family of slain Hurlburt Field airman\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in his statement on Wednesday.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family. (AP) -- The U.S. Air Force said a 23-year-old airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self defense after he encountered a 23-year old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release on Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital where he died, officials said.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron. {"uri": "8119267493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:59:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:59:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:59:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/us/air-force-airman-fatally-shot-florida-deputies-breached-wrong-apartment-attorney-says", "title": "Air Force airman fatally shot when Florida deputies breached wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nUS AIR FORCE SECRETARY KENDALL FLIES IN COCKPIT OF PLANE CONTROLLED BY AI\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama {"uri": "8119270063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:01:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:01:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:01:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.wbrz.com/news/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says/", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", "source": {"uri": "wbrz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WBRZ"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawyer", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lawyer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legislator", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Legislator"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_can't_breathe", "type": {"uri": "2024-05-348304694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "23:11:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T23:11:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T23:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.wpbf.com/article/us-service-member-shot-and-killed-by-florida-police-identified-by-the-air-force/60721832", "title": "US service member shot and killed by Florida police identified by the Air Force", "body": "The U.S. Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.A deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release Friday.Fortson was taken to a hospital where he died, officials said. The deputy involved was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.In a statement late Tuesday, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the incident and the State Attorney's Office will conduct an independent review. He said the sheriff's office was \"saddened\" by the shooting.The Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted.\"___Frisaro reported from Fort Lauderdale.Top headlines:Stay up-to-date: The latest headlines and weather from WPBF 25 Get the latest news updates with the WPBF 25 News app. You can download it here.\n\nThe U.S. Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to a hospital where he died, officials said. The deputy involved was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nIn a statement late Tuesday, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the incident and the State Attorney's Office will conduct an independent review. He said the sheriff's office was \"saddened\" by the shooting.\n\nThe Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the {"uri": "8119334843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:46:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:46:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:45:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/05/09/nation/black-airman-fatally-shot-civil-rights-investigation/", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation - The Boston Globe", "body": "Fortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd, and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-350204711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:14:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:14:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:03:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://eu.pnj.com/story/news/2024/05/09/ben-crump-roger-fortson-fort-walton-beach-florida-air-force-shot/73624751007/", "title": "'Police entered wrong apartment': Ben Crump takes case of airmen killed by deputy. What \\nwe know", "body": "\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in his statement on Wednesday, May 8.\n\nContinuing: \"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family. His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nWhere is Fort Walton Beach?\n\nFort Walton Beach is a small city in the Florida Panhandle, tucked between Panama City Beach and Pensacola.\n\nWho is Roger Fortson?\n\nU.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field when he was fatally shot at his home at Chez Elan Apartments.\n\nAccording to The Associated Press, he was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\n\"Roger enlisted in the military after graduating from high school with honors and had no criminal record,\" Crump said in the release. \"By all accounts, he was a stellar member of the Air Force and loved by his community.\"\n\nWhat happened to Roger Fortson at his Fort Walton Beach apartment?\n\nAccording to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, authorities were called to Fortson's apartment about 4:30 p.m. on Friday, May 3 in reference to an apparent disturbance.\n\nOnce a deputy arrived on the scene, the officials said he \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\" The office has not shared details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFortson died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nHowever, a news release from Crump's law office details the encounter played out differently.\n\nAccording to Crump's press release, a witness who was on a Facetime call with Fortson at the time of the shooting said that Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at his door.\n\nFortson asked, \"Who is it?\" and failed to get a response, the release says. A few minutes later, Fortson heard an \"aggressive\" knock, but failed to see anyone once he looked out his peephole.\n\nFortson, concerned for his safety, retrieved his legally owned gun, the release says. As Fortson returned to the living room, the witness said, deputies \"burst through his door.\" When deputies saw the gun, they fired at Fortson six times.\n\nThe witness said he saw Fortson on the ground, stating, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot. The witness also said police were at the wrong apartment, and there was no disturbance, according to the release.\n\nWho is Ben Crump? Represented Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor and George Floyd\n\nBen Crump is an attorney who specializes in civil rights and catastrophic personal injury cases such as wrongful death lawsuits\n\nWhat happened to the deputy following Roger Fortson's shooting?\n\nAccording to the sheriff's office, the deputy in question was placed on paid administrative leave, as is standard in such cases, pending the results of an investigation. The deputy has not been identified to the public.\n\nWhat has the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said about Roger Fortson's shooting?\n\nOn Tuesday, Sheriff Eric Aden released a statement about the shooting. He said all members of his agency \"are saddened about the fatal officer-involved shooting over the weekend.\"\n\nAden then reiterated points made in the previous release from his agency, noting that the deputy in question was placed on administrative leave and that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the shooting.\n\nAden also noted that the State Attorney's Office also will conduct an independent investigation into the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" said Aden.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.", "source": {"uri": "2024-05-349633140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:06:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:06:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T20:04:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.fox61.com/article/news/nation-world/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-wrong-apartment/507-3fec4e9f-230c-4929-93cc-836c47787795", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "MIAMI -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n'Game of Thrones' actor Ian Gelder dies five months after cancer diagnosis\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nChiefs' Rashee Rice suspected of assault weeks after arrest over high-speed crash: report\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office {"uri": "8116005740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:22:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:22:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:21:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.militarytimes.com/news/your-air-force/2024/05/07/air-force-ids-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-sheriffs-officer/", "title": "Air Force IDs airman fatally shot by Florida sheriff's officer", "body": "Senior Airman Roger Fortson was shot and killed by a Florida sheriff's deputy May 3, 2024, at his off-base residence near Hurlburt Field, Florida. (Air Force)\n\nThe Air Force has identified a man shot and killed by a Florida sheriff's deputy Friday as Senior Airman Roger Fortson.\n\nFortson, 23, was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron at Hurlburt Field, Florida, where he served as a gunner on the AC-130J Ghostrider.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said a deputy was responding to a call of a disturbance around 4:30 p.m. local time Friday when they encountered an armed individual at an apartment located at 319 Racetrack Road NW in Fort Walton Beach, just several miles from Hurlburt.\n\nThe deputy heard sounds of a disturbance and reacted in self defense after identifying himself as law enforcement, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release.\n\nFortson was taken to a local hospital where he died. The deputy was placed on paid administrative leave, pending the outcome of an investigation and administrative review.\n\nAn Okaloosa County Sheriff's spokesperson did not immediately respond to a phone message from Air Force Times Tuesday.\n\nThe Air Force said Monday that Fortson was at his off-base residence at the time of the incident. The 1st Special Operations Wing is providing casualty affairs service to his family and a spokesperson for the wing told Air Force Times that it sent a base-wide message out reminding them of the availability of mental health, chaplain, and other resources.\n\nFortson entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nOkaloosa Sheriff's Deputy Jesse Hernandez resigned in November after an officer-involved shooting, during which he mistook a falling acorn striking his patrol vehicle for a gun shot. According to an investigation, Hernandez opened fire on the vehicle, believing the shot came from inside, where a suspect in an alleged auto theft sat after being restrained and searched. The man, who is Black, was uninjured in the shooting. {"uri": "8119152613", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:43:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:43:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:42:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://wtop.com/national/2024/05/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says-2/", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says - WTOP News", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. What we know", "body": "National civil rights and personal injury attorney Ben Crump has confirmed that he is representing the family of Roger Fortson, the airman who was killed in a deputy-involved shooting on Friday, May 3 in Fort Walton Beach.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in his statement on Wednesday, May 8.\n\nContinuing: \"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family. His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nFort Walton Beach is a small city in the Florida Panhandle, tucked between Panama City Beach and Pensacola.\n\nU.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field when he was fatally shot at his home at Chez Elan Apartments.\n\nAccording to The Associated Press, he was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\n\"Roger enlisted in the military after graduating from high school with honors and had no criminal record,\" Crump said in the release. \"By all accounts, he was a stellar member of the Air Force and loved by his community.\"\n\nAccording to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, authorities were called to Fortson's apartment about 4:30 p.m. on Friday, May 3 in reference to an apparent disturbance.\n\nOnce a deputy arrived on the scene, the officials said he \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\" The office has not shared details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFortson died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nHowever, a news release from Crump's law office details the encounter played out differently.\n\nAccording to Crump's press release, a witness who was on a Facetime call with Fortson at the time of the shooting said that Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at his door.\n\nFortson asked, \"Who is it?\" and failed to get a response, the release says. A few minutes later, Fortson heard an \"aggressive\" knock, but failed to see anyone once he looked out his peephole.\n\nFortson, concerned for his safety, retrieved his legally owned gun, the release says. As Fortson returned to the living room, the witness said, deputies \"burst through his door.\" When deputies saw the gun, they fired at Fortson six times.\n\nThe witness said he saw Fortson on the ground, stating, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot. The witness also said police were at the wrong apartment, and there was no disturbance, according to the release.\n\nBen Crump is an attorney who specializes in civil rights and catastrophic personal injury cases such as wrongful death lawsuits\n\nHis practice has focused on cases such as:\n\nAccording to the sheriff's office, the deputy in question was placed on paid administrative leave, as is standard in such cases, pending the results of an investigation. The deputy has not been identified to the public.\n\nOn Tuesday, Sheriff Eric Aden released a statement about the shooting. He said all members of his agency \"are saddened about the fatal officer-involved shooting over the weekend.\"\n\nAden then reiterated points made in the previous release from his agency, noting that the deputy in question was placed on administrative leave and that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the shooting.\n\nAden also noted that the State Attorney's Office also will conduct an independent investigation into the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" said Aden.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.", "source": {"uri": "8116035048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:46:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:46:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:45:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/roger-fortson-us-airman-shot-killed-florida-sheriffs-deputy/", "title": "U.S. airman shot and killed by Florida sheriff's deputy", "body": "The U.S. Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday. He was at his home at Chez Elan Apartments, around five miles from the air base, reported WKRG.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release on Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital where he died, officials said.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron and started his active duty service on Nov. 19, 2019. Fortson's squadron is one of nine flying squadrons in the 1st Special Operations Wing based at Hurlburt Field, and one of only two that fly the AC-130 gunship, reported Task and Purpose.\n\nIn a statement, the Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring {"uri": "8119147099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:39:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:39:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/nation-world/story/2024-05-09/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "sandiegouniontribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "San Diego Union-Tribune"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawyer", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "8118266701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:02:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:02:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:00:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/may/08/florida-police-kill-us-airman", "title": "Police shoot and kill Black US airman in Florida home", "body": "Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was at home in apartment when officers burst into wrong unit and shot him dead, family says\n\nDeputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black US air force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the special operations wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on Friday.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump did not identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but did not get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but did not see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was not causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa county sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida department of law enforcement and the local state attorney's office will investigate the shooting.\n\nPolice spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told the Associated Press on Wednesday it is highly unlikely the agency would have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office did not immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by the Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", The deputy was placed on paid administrative leave, pending the outcome of an investigation and administrative review.\n\nAn Okaloosa County Sheriff's spokesperson did not immediately respond to a phone message from Air Force Times Tuesday.\n\nThe Air Force said Monday that Fortson was at his off-base residence at the time of the incident. The 1st Special Operations Wing is providing casualty affairs service to his family and a spokesperson for the wing told Air Force Times that it sent a base-wide message out reminding them of the availability of mental health, chaplain, and other resources.\n\nFortson entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nOkaloosa Sheriff's Deputy Jesse Hernandez resigned in November after an officer-involved shooting, during which he mistook a falling acorn striking his patrol vehicle for a gun shot. According to an investigation, Hernandez opened fire on the vehicle, believing the shot came from inside, where a suspect in an alleged auto theft sat after being restrained and searched. The man, who is Black, was uninjured in the shooting. {"uri": "8119441885", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:03:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:03:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:02:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/2024/05/09/black-air-force-airman-killed-florida-deputies-wrong-apartment/", "title": "Black Air Force airman killed by Florida deputies responding to wrong home: attorney", "body": "By Jessica Schladebeck | jschladebeck@nydailynews.com | New York Daily News\n\nA Black U.S. Air Force airman was fatally shot in his home by Florida deputies, who mistakenly burst into the wrong apartment while responding to a disturbance call, according to his family's attorney.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when he was gunned down by law enforcement officers on Friday. He was on a Facetime call at the time with an unnamed woman, civil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement on Wednesday.\n\nCiting her account of the confrontation, Crump said 23-year-old Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at his door, prompting him to call out and ask who was there. He received no answer, though there was another louder, more forceful knock a short time later. This time, Fortson checked the peep hole, but he did not see anyone on the other side, the unidentified woman recalled. Still, he was worried, so he went to retrieve his gun, which he legally owned, according to Crump.\n\nAs Fortson returned, deputies busted into his apartment, saw he was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was struck in the gunfire, the civil rights attorney noted.\n\nFortson later died at the hospital. The deputy who shot him has since been placed on administrative leave.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office on Friday said the deputy was responding to call of a disturbance in progress and \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\" The officer's name has not been released.\n\nFortson's Facetime partner emphasized that the airman was not causing any problems or being combative during their call. She believes the deputies were meant to respond elsewhere in the apartment building, but entered Fortson's unit instead.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" he continued. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.", "source": {"uri": "nydailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jessica_schladebeck@nydailynews.com", "name": {"uri": "8116149921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "19:25:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T19:25:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T19:25:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/local/florida/us-service-member-shot-and-killed-by-florida-police-identified-by-the-air-force/", "title": "US service member shot and killed by Florida police identified by the Air Force - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- The U.S. Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self defense after he encountered a 23-year old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release on Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital where he died, officials said.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nIn a statement, the Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office said the deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press.
