{"uri": "8119214668", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:33:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:33:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:24:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13400161/Attorney-family-Black-airman-fatally-shot-Florida-deputies-want-transparent-investigation.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies...", "body": "MIAMI (AP) - The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn\u00b4t identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn\u00b4t get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn\u00b4t see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman\u00b4s account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump\u00b4s statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can\u00b4t breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFILE - Civil rights attorney Ben Crump speaks in the Audubon Ballroom, now part of The Malcolm X & Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center, in New York, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2024. (AP Photo/Ted Shaffrey, File)\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn\u00b4t causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump\u00b4s statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger\u00b4s death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger\u00b4s death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff\u00b4s Office didn\u00b4t immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump\u00b4s statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community\u00b4s patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff\u00b4s office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney\u00b4s Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson\u00b4s death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson\u00b4s front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I\u00b4m trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", {"uri": "8118260992", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:52:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:52:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:52:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.fox35orlando.com/news/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "MIAMI (AP) - Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed, and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump's statement said the woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believed that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols, and George Floyd.\n\nRELATED: Ben Crump says teen's death on Orlando FreeFall 'worst tragedy captured on video' since George Floyd\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not explain what kind of disturbance deputies responded to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined immediately to identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator. As a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew, one of his roles was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", "source": {"uri": "fox35orlando.com", an active-duty senior airman, according to family attorney Ben Crump.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said, citing the account of an unidentified person who was on FaceTime with Fortson at the time of the shooting.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said in a statement deputies responded to an apartment after receiving a call for \"a disturbance in progress.\"\n\n\"Hearing sounds of a disturbance, (a deputy) reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun and after the deputy had identified himself as law enforcement,\" the sheriff said.\n\n\"The deputy shot the man, who later succumbed to his injuries,\" said the sheriff.\n\n\"I immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents,\" the sheriff's statement said.\n\nCNN has reached out to the sheriff's office and Florida Department of Law Enforcement for additional information.\n\nThe deputy involved in the shooting has not been identified by officials.\n\nCrump called Fortson \"a stellar member of the Air Force and loved by his community.\"\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the IMMEDIATE release of bodycam video to the family,\" Crump said Wednesday in a post on X.\n\nAirman entered active duty in 2019\n\nFortson was on a FaceTime call with a witness when the deadly encounter occurred, Crump said.\n\nFortson heard two separate knocks at the door and - the witness said - when no one could be seen through the peephole, Fortson retrieved his gun, which was legally owned, according to Crump.\n\nThe deputy then allegedly burst into the apartment and shot Fortson.\n\nThe witness said law enforcement responded to the wrong apartment, and there was no disturbance there at the time, Crump said in a news release. According to Crump, the witness said Fortson was alone at the time.\n\nHer relationship to Fortson was not disclosed.\n\nDeputies communicated with dispatch that Fortson had been shot six times with multiple gunshot wounds to the chest with one exit wound, according to police dispatch calls, obtained by CNN affiliate WEAR.\n\nOfficers can be heard saying that there was a \"disturbance ... physical in progress,\" in the dispatch calls, WEAR reported.\n\nThe Fortson family and their attorney will hold a news conference in Fort Walton Beach, Florida, on Thursday morning, according to Crump.\n\n\"Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron. He entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019,\" said a statement from the Air Force.\n\n\"The 1st Special Operations Wing's priorities are providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the {"uri": "8119632148", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:55:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:55:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:34:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/us-airman-shot-killed-police-152808980.html", "title": "US airman shot and killed by police in Florida", "body": "A US Air Force member was fatally shot by police who entered the wrong address, a lawyer for his family says.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, who was 23 years old and black, died after a deputy sheriff shot him while responding to a disturbance call.\n\nPolice earlier said the deputy reacted in self-defence after he saw Fortson armed with a gun.\n\nCiting a witness, the lawyer alleges that police burst into the wrong home. He is demanding a full investigation.\n\nThe airman was shot on 3 May at his home, located 5 miles (8km) from the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, where he is based.\n\nFortson was taken to a hospital where he died, officials said.\n\nThe deputy who shot him - whom police have not named - has since been placed on administrative leave, according to a statement on Tuesday by Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden.\n\nThe incident is now being investigated by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the State Attorney's Office, Sheriff Aden added.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" he said.\n\nThe lawyer for the Fortson family, Ben Crump, has called for transparency from the police on what transpired.\n\n\"Roger Fortson was the best America had to offer. He was a patriot. He was a US airman, special ops. He was fighting for our way of life. He was fighting for everybody,\" Mr Crump said at a news conference on Thursday. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nHis mother, Chantimekki Fortson, broke down crying as Mr Crump recounted the moments before the airman was shot.\n\n\"My baby was my everything,\" she said.\n\nMr Crump said at the time of the shooting Fortson was on a video call with a friend, who described what she heard to his family's legal team.\n\nThe friend said the airman heard a knock on his apartment door and asked who was there, but received no response. He then heard a second, \"very aggressive knock\" but did not see anyone when he looked through the peephole.\n\nIt is at this point that Fortson is said to have grown concerned and retrieved his gun, which the lawyer said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson returned to his living room, the witness said police burst through the door, saw that the resident was armed and shot him six times.\n\nMr Crump said the witness believed the officers were in the wrong apartment, as Fortson was alone at the time with no disturbance at his residence.\n\nIn a statement released on 4 May, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said the deputy \"reacted in self defence after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun and after the deputy had identified himself as law enforcement.\"\n\nSpeaking to reporters, Mr Crump accused police of trying to \"justify unjustifiable excessive use of force.\"\n\nMr Crump noted that private gun ownership is allowed in the State of Florida.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has not responded to Mr Crump's comments.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron, according to the US Air Force, and entered active duty in November 2019.\n\nAccording to Mr Crump, he enlisted in the military after graduating from high school in Atlanta, Georgia with honours.\n\nMr Crump, a civil rights lawyer based in Florida, has worked on multiple high-profile cases of police-involved deaths of black Americans, including George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols and Breonna Taylor.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "8119206256", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:18:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:18:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:18:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/us-airman-roger-fortson-killed-131058912.html", "title": "US airman Roger Fortson killed by deputies who may have hit wrong home, Ben Crump says", "body": "An active-duty airman was shot and killed during a deputy-involved shooting in Fort Walton Beach, Florida, last Friday, and his attorney is saying the police may have entered the wrong apartment.\n\nAccording to a 1st Special Operations Wing release, the airman was identified as 23-year-old U.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson. He was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron and entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nAccording to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, a deputy responded to a call of a disturbance in progress on the afternoon of Friday, May 3.\n\nThe deputy \"encountered an armed man,\" according to a news release, and the deputy shot the man.\n\nFortson was taken to a local hospital where he later succumbed to his injuries, according to police.\n\nThe deputy in question has been placed on administrative leave pending the results of an investigation from the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. Police said the state attorney's office will also conduct an independent review of the incident.\n\nFortson's family has retained national civil rights and personal injury attorney Ben Crump to represent them. Crump has represented the families of Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, among others.\n\nAccording to a news release from Crump's law office, the encounter played out differently than what the OCSO has been reporting.\n\nCrump says a witness who was on a FaceTime call with Fortson at the time of the shooting said that Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at his door.\n\nFortson asked, \"Who is it?\" and failed to get a response, Crump said in a news release Wednesday.\n\nA few minutes later, Fortson heard an \"aggressive\" knock, but failed to see anyone once he looked out his peephole.\n\nFortson, concerned for his safety, retrieved his legally owned gun, the release says. As Fortson returned to the living room, the witness said, deputies \"burst through his door.\" When deputies saw the gun, they fired at Fortson six times.\n\nBen Crump: Civil rights attorney Ben Crump now represents family of slain Hurlburt Field airman\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in his statement on Wednesday.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family. His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\nGabe Hauari is a national trending news reporter at USA TODAY. {"uri": "8114604049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "00:11:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T00:11:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T00:11:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.wkrg.com/northwest-florida/okaloosa-county/u-s-air-force-senior-airman-shot-killed-by-okaloosa-county-deputy-ocso/", "title": "U.S. Air Force Senior Airman shot, killed by Okaloosa County deputy: OCSO | WKRG.com", "body": "OKALOOSA COUNTY, Fla. (WKRG) -- An armed man shot and killed by an Okaloosa County sheriff's deputy on Friday was a U.S. Air Force Senior Airman, News 5 has learned.\n\nThe sheriff's deputy, whose identity has not been released, shot U.S. Air Force Airman Roger Fortson, 23, on Friday at Chez Elan Apartments.\n\nAccording to Hurlburt Field, he was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron and entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nAn Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office spokesperson confirmed that the airman's death was connected to the previously reported officer-involved shooting death.\n\nOCSO is leading the investigation into this shooting.", "source": {"uri": "wkrg.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WKRG News 5"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kendra_day@wkrg.com", "name": "Kendra Day", "type": {"uri": "8119777974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:53:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:53:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:52:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/florida-sheriffs-office-releases-bodycam-video-of-fatal-shooting-of-air-force-airman-by-deputy/3306537/", "title": "Florida sheriff's office releases bodycam video of fatal shooting of Air Force airman by deputy", "body": "A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense.\n\nThe video from the deputy's body camera showed that Fortson answered his apartment door with what appears to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The video shows the deputy banging on the door, stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office!\"\n\nThe door opened, and the deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" The deputy then fired off shots, and shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun! Do not move!\" The deputy then called for paramedics on his radio.\n\nNoted civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, earlier had asked the sheriff's office for transparency and disputed the narrative authorities released following the May 3 shooting. Email and text messages were sent to Crump on Thursday afternoon seeking comment about what the bodycam footage showed and the sheriff's describing as inaccurate Crump's statements that the deputy went to the wrong apartment and didn't announce himself.\n\nThe deputy is seen on the video arriving at an apartment building and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nCrump told reporters earlier that Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked. He said Fortson was alone at the time.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating the shooting.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his Fort Walton Beach apartment.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nIn a statement last week, the sheriff's office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. {"uri": "2024-05-349586489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:25:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:25:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:05:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/national/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says/article_aefad9e0-bf25-5086-9a32-1ce7ba00d362.html", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "A civil rights attorney says deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporter Curt Anderson contributed to this story from St. Petersburg, Florida.", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WBOC TV-16"}, "authors": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-03", "textStart": 679, "textEnd": 684}], "sentiment": -0.2313725490196078, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8119588133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:57:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:57:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:57:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://mynorthwest.com/3959755/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-say-he-was-a-patriot/", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies say he was a patriot", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- The family of a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle said Thursday that they want to correct a false narrative put forth by authorities about the encounter that led to his death.\n\nThe family of Senior Airmen Roger Fortson planned to view body camera video later in the day. Civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing the family, said Fortson did not know it was sheriff's deputies who were breaking into his apartment -- \"his castle\" -- and that he grabbed his \"legally owned firearm\" to protect himself.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into a news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his apartment in Fort Walton Beach.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office planned to hold a news conference later Thursday afternoon. It has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nCrump said deputies responding to a disturbance call burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when they saw he had a gun. He said Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump, a noted civil rights attorney, called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing\" and said the sheriff's office needed to own up to it instead of creating a counter-narrative that deputies were acting in self-defense.\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said of sheriff's deputies. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has not responded to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's account. In a statement last week, it said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nFortson had constitutional rights to have the firearm and against unreasonable searches by the police, Crump said. He led family members and other attorneys in a chant of \"Clear Roger's Name.\"\n\n\"Any law-abiding citizens who feel they have a right to the Fourth Amendment and the Second Amendment, they should be troubled by this,\" Crump said.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nThe spelling of the name of Fortson's mother has been corrected to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki.", "source": {"uri": "mynorthwest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "My Northwest"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@mynorthwest.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Press_conference", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Press conference"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legislator", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Legislator"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Walton_Beach,_Florida", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Fort Walton Beach, Florida"}, "location": {"type": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawyer", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Lawyer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_and_political_rights", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": "place", "label": {"eng": "Okaloosa County, Florida"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_camera", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Body camera"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida_Department_of_Law_Enforcement", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Florida Department of Law {"uri": "8119645384", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:47:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:47:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:46:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/may/09/florida-airman-killed-by-police-roger-fortson", "title": "Family of US airman killed by Florida deputies say sheriff's narrative false", "body": "Relatives of Roger Fortson said deputies burst into wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when he reached for 'legally owned firearm'\n\nThe family of a Black US air force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle said Thursday that they want to correct a false narrative put forth by authorities about the encounter that led to his death.\n\nThe family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson planned to view body-camera video later in the day. Civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing the family, said Fortson had not known it was sheriff's deputies who were breaking into his apartment - \"his castle\" - and that he grabbed his \"legally owned firearm\" to protect himself.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into a news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his apartment in Fort Walton Beach.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nThe Okaloosa county sheriff's office planned to hold a news conference later Thursday afternoon. It has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida department of law enforcement and the local state attorney's office will investigate the shooting.\n\nCrump said deputies responding to a disturbance call burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when they saw he had a gun. He said Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said.\n\nCrump, a noted civil rights attorney, called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing\" and said the sheriff's office needed to own up to it instead of creating a counter-narrative that deputies were acting in self-defense.\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his business,\" Crump said of sheriff's deputies. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nThe Okaloosa county sheriff's office has not responded to an email or voicemail from the Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's account.\n\nIn a statement last week, the office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nFortson had constitutional rights to have the firearm and against unreasonable searches by the police, Crump said. He led family members and other attorneys in a chant of: \"Clear Roger's name.\"\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the US air force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the special operations wing at Hurlburt Field. He was a special missions aviator, and one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson had been talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on 3 May, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what had happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them: \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby, please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to those of other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a non-emergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, {"uri": "8119171115", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:56:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:56:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:55:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mn/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-want-a-transparent-investigation/article_4126ea3f-f900-59b9-9b1b-2972cabad7a5.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation", "body": "By DAVID FISCHER - Associated Press\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school Coaches association warns Waunakee basketball lawsuit 'sets dangerous precedent' Joe Gow's teaching position at issue as UW-La Crosse Faculty Senate to hear unethical conduct allegations Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire Onalaska man faces 60 years for alleged sexual assault of girls River Point District developers hit stride as buildings rise along La Crosse riverfront Viroqua High School's Kami Delap wins silver at national powerlifting championship Extra Effort: Luther High student overcomes school difficulties on her way to education career American Airlines reintroduces higher capacity E175 jets at La Crosse Regional Airport Extra effort: Holmen teen with brain tumor achieves academic success High school football: West Salem to search for new football coach La Crosse orders City Brewery to stop the smells; daily fines begin Monday\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8119575788", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:47:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:47:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:46:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2024/05/09/deputy-who-fatally-shot-black-airman-had-burst-into-wrong-apartment-family-says/", "title": "Deputy who fatally shot Black airman had burst into wrong apartment, family says", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- A deputy responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone, an attorney for the man's family said.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was shot in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach on the afternoon of Friday, May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said at a Thursday news conference that Fortson was alone in his apartment and on a Facetime call with his girlfriend when Okaloosa County sheriff's deputies arrived.\n\nCrump gave the account provided by the girlfriend: Hearing a knock on the door, Fortson called out and asked who it was, but didn't get a response. When there was a second, louder knock, he looked through the peephole and said he couldn't see anyone. He went to retrieve his gun -- which Crump said was legally owned -- and as he returned to the living room, deputies burst through the door. One of them shot Fortson six times.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement Wednesday on Facebook expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not say who made the call.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws similarities to other Black people killed in their homes by police.\n\nIn 2018, Dallas police officer Amber Guyger fatally shot Botham Jean after mistaking his apartment for her own. Guyger was found guilty of murder and sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, Fort Worth police officer Aaron Dean fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Dean was found guilty of manslaughter and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nIn 2020, sheriff's Deputy Jason Meade fatally shot Casey Goodson, who reportedly was holding a bag of sandwiches as he walked into his grandmother's home in Columbus, Ohio. A mistrial was declared in February in Meade's prosecution on a murder charge.\n\nThe Okaloosa County sheriff's office made news last year when one of its deputies mistook the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot and opened fire on his own SUV, where a handcuffed Black suspect was sitting.\n\n____Associated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York {"uri": "2024-05-349595826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:45:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:45:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.wesh.com/article/florida-black-airman-shot-killed-deputies/60737576", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.Civil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.According to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.The woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.As Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.Fortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.The woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"Crump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.Crump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.The Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.The sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.The sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.Fort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nDeputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", (AP) -- The U.S. Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self defense after he encountered a 23-year old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release on Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital where he died, officials said.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nIn a statement, the Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office said the deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an {"uri": "8118249704", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:43:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:43:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:36:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/lawyer-deputy-fatally-shot-florida-003035325.html", "title": "Lawyer: Deputy who fatally shot Florida airman had wrong apartment", "body": "Senior Airman Roger Fortson was home alone in his off-base apartment causing no trouble and FaceTiming with someone when a Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy, responding to the wrong address for a disturbance, broke through his door and fatally shot him Friday, an attorney for the airman's family said Wednesday.\n\nBen Crump, a civil rights attorney hired by Fortson's family, detailed the account in a news release, which was also posted Twitter Wednesday, asking for transparency and the immediate release of body camera footage of the incident.\n\nAir Force IDs airman fatally shot by Florida sheriff's officer\n\nFortson, 23, was shot six times, said Crump, who attributed his account of the shooting to a witness who the airman had been FaceTiming with during the incident.\n\nAccording to that woman, Crump said, Fortson heard a knock on his door, and when he asked who it was didn't get a response. A few minutes later, there was a \"very aggressive knock,\" but Fortson didn't see anyone when he looked out the peephole.\n\n\"Concerned, he did what any other law-abiding citizen would do and retrieved his legally-owned gun,\" Crump said.\n\nAs Fortson walked back to his living room, \"police burst through the door\" and shot him six times, Crump said, adding that the witness said they saw Fortson on the ground saying, \"I can't breathe.\"\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said a deputy encountered Fortson with a gun while responding to a disturbance around 4:30 p.m. local time Friday at an apartment located at 319 Racetrack Road NW in Fort Walton Beach, just several miles from Hurlburt Field, where Fortson served as a gunner on the AC-130J Ghostrider in the 4th Special Operations Squadron.\n\nFortson died at a local hospital, officials said.\n\nFew other details have been released about the shooting, including the type of disturbance they were responding to. The sheriff's office late Tuesday declined to release body camera footage, an incident report and other recordings related to the shooting to Air Force Times, citing an ongoing investigation.\n\nAccording to an unverified audio recording of a dispatch call posted on Facebook, police received a disturbance call related to a male and female and that it was called in by an apartment complex's leasing office. The recording refers to a Black male who had been shot \"multiple\" times in the chest.\n\nFortson's apartment complex declined to comment to Air Force Times.\n\nThe deputy who shot Fortson, who has not been identified, has been placed on paid administrative leave and Okaloosa Sheriff Eric Aden said Wednesday afternoon that he has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to handle the investigation into the matter.\n\nWhile he asked for the \"community's patience,\" Crump demanded \"immediate answers.\"\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment. The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement,\" Crump said in a statement.\n\nCrump could not be immediately reached for comment. He is a well-known civil rights attorney who has represented families in high-profile cases involving Black people killed by law enforcement, including George Floyd, Michael Brown and Breonna Taylor.\n\nHurlburt Field has said in social media posts that the base is supporting Fortson's family and offering assistance to grieving airmen.\n\nThe Okaloosa Sheriff's Office faced scrutiny last year after a deputy mistook a falling acorn striking his patrol vehicle for a gun shot and fired at his SUV while a suspect sat inside restrained. According to an internal investigation, Deputy Jesse Hernandez believed the shot came from inside his vehicle. The suspect, who is Black, was uninjured in the shooting. The sheriff's office determined Hernandez' use of force was not reasonable and he resigned in November.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "Yemen"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Job-Related", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt":
