"originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2862745098039216, "wgt": 209, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8119537094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:15:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:15:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:15:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mn/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-say-he-was-a-patriot/article_4126ea3f-f900-59b9-9b1b-2972cabad7a5.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies say he was a patriot", "body": "FILE - Civil rights attorney Ben Crump speaks in the Audubon Ballroom, now part of The Malcolm X & Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center, in New York, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2024.\n\nBy STEPHEN SMITH and MIKE SCHNEIDER - Associated Press\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- The mother of a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle began crying while listening to her family's attorney recount the death of her son.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" said Chantimekki Fortson at a news conference on Thursday in Fort Walton Beach, where her son, Senior Airmen Roger Fortson, was living when he was killed.\n\nThe family's attorney, Ben Crump, said that Senior Airmen Roger Fortson said Okaloosa County sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school Coaches association warns Waunakee basketball lawsuit 'sets dangerous precedent' Joe Gow's teaching position at issue as UW-La Crosse Faculty Senate to hear unethical conduct allegations Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire Onalaska man faces 60 years for alleged sexual assault of girls River Point District developers hit stride as buildings rise along La Crosse riverfront Viroqua High School's Kami Delap wins silver at national powerlifting championship Extra Effort: Luther High student overcomes school difficulties on her way to education career American Airlines reintroduces higher capacity E175 jets at La Crosse Regional Airport Extra effort: Holmen teen with brain tumor achieves academic success High school football: West Salem to search for new football coach La Crosse orders City Brewery to stop the smells; daily fines begin Monday\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump, a noted civil rights attorney, called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing\" and said the sheriff's office needed to own up to it instead of creating a counter-narrative that deputies were acting in self-defense.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. Fortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived, Crump said.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Ap State Florida Deputies Black Airman Killed Politics Shootings Race And Ethnicity U.s. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.6627450980392157, "wgt": 209, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8119801775", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:15:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:15:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:14:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/05/09/video-shows-florida-deputy-announced-himself-prior-to-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman/", "title": "Video Shows Florida Deputy Announced Himself Prior to Fatal Shooting of Black Airman", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense.\n\nThe video from the deputy's body camera showed that Fortson answered his apartment door with what appears to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The video shows the deputy banging on the door, stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office!\"\n\nThe door opened, and the deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" The deputy then fired off shots, and shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun! Do not move!\" The deputy then called for paramedics on his radio.\n\nNoted civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, earlier had asked the sheriff's office for transparency and disputed the narrative authorities released following the May 3 shooting. Email and text messages were sent to Crump on Thursday afternoon seeking comment about what the bodycam footage showed and the sheriff's describing as inaccurate Crump's statements that the deputy went to the wrong apartment and didn't announce himself.\n\nRelated Story: US Service Member Shot and Killed by Florida Police Identified by the Air Force\n\nThe deputy is seen on the video arriving at an apartment building and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nCrump told reporters earlier that Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked. He said Fortson was alone at the time.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating the shooting.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his Fort Walton Beach apartment.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nRelated Story: Police Clear Pro-Palestinian Protest Camp and Arrest 33 at DC Campus as ...\n\nIn a statement last week, the sheriff's office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nRelated Story: LA Police Make Arrest in Murder of Fresno Human Trafficking Fighter's ...\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. {"uri": "8119683774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:22:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:22:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:22:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.abcactionnews.com/news/state/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-say-he-was-a-patriot", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies say he was a patriot", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- The family of a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle said Thursday that they wanted to clear his name and that authorities had put forth a false narrative that deputies acted in self-defense.\n\nSenior Airmen Roger Fortson did not know it was sheriff's deputies who were breaking into his apartment -- \"his castle\" -- and that he grabbed his \"legally registered firearm\" to protect himself, civil rights attorney Ben Crump told reporters. Fortson's family planned to view body camera video later in the day.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his Fort Walton Beach apartment.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office planned to hold a news conference later Thursday afternoon. It has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nCrump said deputies responding to a disturbance call burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when they saw he had a gun. He said Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump, a noted civil rights attorney, called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing\" and said the sheriff's office needed to own up to it instead of maintaining that deputies were acting in self-defense.\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has not responded to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's account. In a statement last week, the office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nFortson had constitutional rights to have the firearm and against unreasonable searches by the police, Crump said. He led family members and other attorneys in a chant of, \"Clear Roger's name.\"\n\n\"Any law-abiding citizens who feel they have a right to the Fourth Amendment and the Second Amendment, they should be troubled by this,\" Crump said.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nOutside Jimmy Klass's mobile home in Clearwater, symbols of American pride hang all around his residence. But after 64 years of working, living, paying taxes, and voting in America - Jimmy Klass discovered that he's not a U.S. citizen when he was denied Social Security benefits he had paid into his entire working life.\n\nFlorida man finds he's not a legal citizen 60 years after moving to the U.S.\n\nAttorney: Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment\n\nAssociated Press\n\n10:48 PM, May 08, 2024\n\nDeSantis vows to 'keep order' as protests continue at FL Universities\n\nForrest Saunders\n\n6:13 PM, May 08, 2024\n\nFlorida CFO Jimmy Patronis answers your questions on rising insurance rates\n\nNadeen Yanes\n\n4:45 PM, May 08, 2024\n\nFloridians set for more than a billion dollars in tax relief\n\nForrest Saunders\n\n5:39 PM, May 07, 2024", "source": {"uri": "8118363887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:58:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:58:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:57:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.abcactionnews.com/news/state/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "MIAMI -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction of a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nOutside Jimmy Klass's mobile home in Clearwater, symbols of American pride hang all around his residence. But after 64 years of working, living, paying taxes, and voting in America - Jimmy Klass discovered that he's not a U.S. citizen when he was denied Social Security benefits he had paid into his entire working life.\n\nFlorida man finds he's not a legal citizen 60 years after moving to the U.S.\n\nDeSantis vows to 'keep order' as protests continue at FL Universities\n\nForrest Saunders\n\n6:13 PM, May 08, 2024\n\nFlorida CFO Jimmy Patronis answers your questions on rising insurance rates\n\nNadeen Yanes\n\n4:45 PM, May 08, 2024\n\nFloridians set for more than a billion dollars in tax relief\n\nForrest Saunders\n\n5:39 PM, May 07, 2024\n\nUS service member shot and killed by Florida police identified by the Air Force\n\nAssociated Press\n\n3:31 PM, May 07, 2024", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-350648555", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:05:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:05:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:37:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.denverpost.com/2024/05/09/video-shows-florida-deputy-announced-himself-prior-to-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman/", "title": "Video shows Florida deputy announced himself prior to fatal shooting of Black airman", "body": "By STEPHEN SMITH and MIKE SCHNEIDER (Associated Press)\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, body camera video shown to reporters Thursday shows.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense.\n\nThe video from the deputy's body camera showed that Fortson answered his apartment door with what appears to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The video shows the deputy banging on the door, stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office!\"\n\nThe door opened, and the deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" The deputy then fired off shots, and shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun! Do not move!\" The deputy then called for paramedics on his radio.\n\nNoted civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, earlier had asked the sheriff's office for transparency and disputed the narrative authorities released following the May 3 shooting. An email was sent to Crump's office Thursday afternoon seeking comment about what the bodycam footage showed and the sheriff's describing as inaccurate Crump's statements that the deputy went to the wrong apartment and didn't announce himself.\n\nAlden is seen on the video arriving at an apartment building and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nCrump told reporters earlier that Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating the shooting.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his Fort Walton Beach apartment.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nIn a statement last week, the sheriff's office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nThe spelling of the name of Fortson's mother has been corrected to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki.", "source": {"uri": "denverpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Denver Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@denverpost.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8119625764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:29:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:29:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:28:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/05/09/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-say-he-was-a-patriot/", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies say he was a patriot", "body": "By STEPHEN SMITH and MIKE SCHNEIDER (Associated Press)\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- The family of a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by deputies who burst into his apartment in the Florida Panhandle said Thursday that they wanted to clear his name and that authorities had put forth a false narrative that deputies acted in self-defense.\n\nSenior Airmen Roger Fortson did not know it was sheriff's deputies who were breaking into his apartment -- \"his castle\" -- and that he grabbed his \"legally registered firearm\" to protect himself, civil rights attorney Ben Crump told reporters. Fortson's family planned to view body camera video later in the day.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his Fort Walton Beach apartment.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office planned to hold a news conference later Thursday afternoon. It has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nCrump said deputies responding to a disturbance call burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Fortson when they saw he had a gun. He said Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump, a noted civil rights attorney, called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing\" and said the sheriff's office needed to own up to it instead of maintaining that deputies were acting in self-defense.\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has not responded to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's account. In a statement last week, the office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nFortson had constitutional rights to have the firearm and against unreasonable searches by the police, Crump said. He led family members and other attorneys in a chant of, \"Clear Roger's name.\"\n\n\"Any law-abiding citizens who feel they have a right to the Fourth Amendment and the Second Amendment, they should be troubled by this,\" Crump said.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nThe spelling of the name of Fortson's mother has been corrected to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki.", "source": {"uri": "delcotimes.com", {"uri": "8119380552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:23:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:23:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:17:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/national-world/cnn-national/2024/05/09/airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputy-who-was-in-wrong-apartment-family-attorney-says/", "title": "Airman fatally shot by Florida deputy who was in wrong apartment, family attorney says", "body": "(CNN) -- An attorney for the family of a Black airman fatally shot by a Florida deputy in his home last week is calling for the release of law enforcement bodycam footage, saying a witness believes the deputy was at the wrong apartment.\n\nThe 23-year-old victim has been identified by his family as Roger Fortson - an active-duty senior airman, according to family attorney Ben Crump.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said, citing the account of an unidentified person who was on FaceTime with Fortson at the time of the shooting.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said in a statement deputies responded last Friday to an apartment after receiving a call for \"a disturbance in progress.\"\n\n\"Hearing sounds of a disturbance, (a deputy) reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun and after the deputy had identified himself as law enforcement,\" the sheriff said.\n\n\"The deputy shot the man, who later succumbed to his injuries,\" said the sheriff.\n\n\"I immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents,\" the sheriff's statement said.\n\nCNN has reached out to the sheriff's office and Florida Department of Law Enforcement for additional information.\n\nThe deputy involved in the shooting has not been identified by officials.\n\nCrump - who's expected to hold a news conference in Fort Walton Beach, Florida, on Thursday - called Fortson \"a stellar member of the Air Force and loved by his community.\"\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the IMMEDIATE release of bodycam video to the family,\" Crump said Wednesday in a post on X.\n\nFortson heard two separate knocks at the door and - the witness said - when no one could be seen through the peephole, Fortson retrieved his gun, which was legally owned, according to Crump.\n\nThe deputy then allegedly burst into the apartment and shot Fortson.\n\nThe witness said law enforcement responded to the wrong apartment, and there was no disturbance there at the time, Crump said in a news release. According to Crump, the witness said Fortson was alone at the time.\n\nHer relationship to Fortson was not disclosed.\n\nDeputies communicated with dispatch that Fortson had been shot six times with multiple gunshot wounds to the chest with one exit wound, according to police dispatch calls, obtained by CNN affiliate WEAR.\n\nOfficers can be heard saying that there was a \"disturbance ... physical in progress,\" in the dispatch calls, WEAR reported.\n\n\"Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron. He entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019,\" said a statement from the Air Force, which noted the shooting occurred at Fortson's off-base residence.\n\n\"The 1st Special Operations Wing's priorities are providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted,\" said the Hurlburt Field statement.\n\nWhile details about the shooting remain murky, the allegation the Okaloosa deputy responded to the wrong apartment echoes other shootings in recent years, in which a Black man or woman was killed by law enforcement in their home.\n\nIn 2019, a former Dallas police officer was sentenced to 10 years in prison after fatally shooting Botham Jean in his apartment the year prior. The officer - off duty but still in uniform - lived on the floor below Jean's and said she approached what she believed to be her own apartment when she saw Jean inside.\n\nAtatiana Jefferson was killed that same year when a Fort Worth officer, responding to what police believed to be a burglary, shot her through her bedroom window.\n\nThe officer testified at trial that Jefferson pointed a gun at him, but prosecutors argued there was no evidence he saw the gun before opening fire. The former Fort Worth officer was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison in 2022.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8119598397", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:06:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:06:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:06:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://hollywoodunlocked.com/roger-fortson-airman-shot-killed-deputies-wrong-apartment-ben-crump/", "title": "Ben Crump Speaks Out With Family Of U.S. Airman Roger Fortson Who Was Killed After Deputy Entered Wrong Apartment", "body": "Devastating news is currently surfacing on social media after a Black U.S. Air Force airman was killed by Florida deputies after authorities reportedly burst into the wrong apartment.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was fatally shot on May 3 at his off-base apartment off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach, Florida. An Air Force representative informed Task and Purpose that he served as a Special Missions Aviator with the AC-130J gunships of the 4th Special Operations Squadron. Civil rights attorney Ben Crump who is representing the family shared a photo of Fortson on social media standing with his little sister and captioned the post by saying, \"This is Roger Fortson and his little sister. Roger bought her the flight suit so they could match. These pictures perfectly show her love and admiration for her big brother. A love his WHOLE family shared -- still there, but now tainted by the brutal nature of his needless death.\"\n\nRELATED: Attorney Ben Crump Gives Update After Breonna Taylor's Family Meets With Kentucky AG: \"We Do Expect Charges To Be Filed\" Soon\n\nCrump stated that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman during the fatal incident. The woman, whose identity has not been disclosed, reported that Fortson was by himself in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. According to Crump, Fortson asked who was knocking at the door but received no answer. A few minutes later, he heard a louder knock and checked out the area, but did not see anyone. That's when Fortson grabbed his gun that legally owned and walked into the living room. Deputies then burst through the door and shot him 6 times.\n\nSubsequently, he passed away at a hospital, as stated by Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden in a press release on Tuesday, May 7. Furthermore, the deputy responsible for shooting Fortson was put on administrative leave while an investigation is conducted.\n\nCrump stated that according to the woman, Fortson was not causing any disturbance, leading her to believe that the deputies had mistakenly targeted the wrong apartment.\n\nRELATED: Shocking Footage Shows The Moment Samuel Sterling Was Hit by unmarked Michigan State Police Vehicle\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in his statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"", "source": {"uri": "hollywoodunlocked.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-05-349602608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:01:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:01:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:05:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.oneidadispatch.com/2024/05/08/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says/", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n____\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "oneidadispatch.com", {"uri": "2024-05-349586452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:25:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:25:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T19:05:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/8/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-roger-fortson-us/", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot U.S. airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "MIAMI -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, there was a very aggressive knock on the door, Crump said in a statement, but Fortson didn't see anyone when he looked out the peephole.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nOfficials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said Wednesday in a statement, \"All of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer involved shooting over the weekend.\"\n\nAden said that he immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents. The State Attorney's Office will also conduct an independent review.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" the sheriff said.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew {"uri": "8114519154", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "22:23:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T22:23:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T22:22:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://taskandpurpose.com/news/gunship-airman-killed-by-deputy/", "title": "AC-130 gunship crewman killed in shooting with Florida sheriff deputy", "body": "Senior Airman Roger Fortson was a Special Missions Aviator that flew as aircew on AC-130J Ghostrider gunships with the 4th Special Operations Squadron.\n\nAn airman who flew as a crewmember on AC-130 gunships died in a shooting with a sheriff's deputy at an apartment complex near Hurlburt Field Sunday, sources on the base and in Florida told Task & Purpose.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died in an \"off-base incident at his residence,\" according to a release from the 1st Special Operations Wing. Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron on Hurlburt. An Air Force spokesperson told Task & Purpose Fortson was a Special Missions Aviator assigned to the squadron's AC-130J gunships.\n\nAn Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office deputy shot and killed an armed man on Friday, May 3, according to a post on the OCSO's Facebook page posted over the weekend. Sources on Hurlburt told Task & Purpose that personnel on base had been told that Fortson was the man killed and a spokesperson for the OCSO confirmed that the incidents were \"connected.\"\n\nAccording to the OCSO's Facebook page, a deputy with the department encountered a man \"armed with a gun\" at an apartment complex on Racetrack Road late Friday afternoon, about five miles from the base that is home to Air Force Special Operations Command. The deputy was responding to a call for a \"disturbance in progress.\"\n\nAccording to the sheriff's department, the deputy encountered \"a 23-year old man armed with a gun.\" The deputy shot the man \"in self-defense\" after identifying himself as a law enforcement officer, the OCSO said.\n\nFortson entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nThe 4th Special Operations Squadron is one of nine flying squadrons in the 1st Special Operations Wing based at Hurlburt Field. The 4th is one of two squadrons that fly the AC-130 gunship. The 4th SOS currently flies AC-130J gunships which carries a crew of four officers and four enlisted crew members who train the plane's 30mm and 105mm guns on ground targters, along with GBU-39 bombs, AGM-114 hellfire and AGM-176 Griffin missiles, and the GBU-69 Small Glide Munition.\n\nA November 2023 incident of an Okaloosa Sheriff's deputy in an officer-involved shooting made national headlines. An Okaloosa deputy had arrested a man and put him in the rear of his own patrol car when the deputy heard a loud noise he believed was a gunshot. He yelled \"shots fired!,\" \"I'm hit!\" and shot at the car multiple times while laying on his side.\n\nAn investigation determined that the noise was an acorn falling from a tree and striking the {"uri": "2024-05-349584097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:21:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:21:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T19:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-05-08/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says", "title": "Florida Deputies Who Fatally Shot US Airman Burst Into Wrong Apartment, Attorney Says", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n____\n\nAssociated Press reporter Curt Anderson contributed to this story from St. Petersburg, Florida.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8118331341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:19:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:19:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/air-force-airman-killed-florida-deputies-wrong-apartment-attorney-says-rcna151387", "title": "Air Force airman killed by Florida deputies who were at wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "U.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was fatally shot Friday by an Okaloosa County sheriff's deputy. U.S. Air Force\n\nAn Air Force airman who was fatally shot at his Okaloosa County, Florida, apartment Friday was killed by a deputy after law enforcement burst into the wrong home, civil rights attorney Ben Crump said Wednesday.\n\nA woman said she was on a FaceTime video call with Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, when he was killed and that he was alone and there was no disturbance, which law enforcement said was the reason for the call, Crump said.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said that Friday afternoon, \"our deputy responded to a call of a disturbance in progress where he encountered an armed man,\" and the deputy shot him.\n\nAccording to the woman on the FaceTime call, whom Crump did not identify, Fortson heard a knock at his door, asked \"who is it?\" and got no response, and could not see anyone through the peephole, Crump said in a statement.\n\nThere was a second, aggressive knock, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\n\"Concerned, he did what any other law-abiding citizen would do and retrieved his legally-owned gun, but as he was walking back to the living room, police burst through the door. When they saw the gun, they shot Roger six times,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"The witness has said that she saw Roger on the ground stating, 'I can't breathe,' after he was shot,\" Crump said. \"She has also said the police were in the wrong apartment as there was no disturbance in the apartment and he was alone.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the sheriff's office Friday night did not immediately respond to a request for comment about the claim that police were at the wrong apartment.\n\nThe Florida Department of Law Enforcement said it is investigating the shooting at the request of the sheriff's department. It did not provide any additional information, citing the active investigation.\n\nThe state attorney's office is also conducting an independent review, the sheriff's office said.\n\nSheriff Eric Aden said in a statement that \"all of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer involved shooting over the weekend.\"\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" he said.\n\nHurlburt Field, the Air Force base where Fortson was assigned, said in a statement that Fortson entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019. He was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron.\n\n\"The 1st Special Operations Wing's priorities are providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted,\" the base said in a statement.\n\nOkaloosa County is in the Florida Panhandle, east of Pensacola.", "source": {"uri": Apartment and Kill US Airman: Attorney", "body": "Roger Fortson, a senior airman with the U.S. Air Force since 2019, died on May 3 in his apartment just five miles from his airbase after a deputy sheriff shot him while responding to a service call, CBS News reported.\n\nA 23-year-old U.S. airman stationed in the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed earlier this month after his family's attorney says police entered the wrong apartment and opened fire, according to reports.\n\nRoger Fortson, a senior airman with the U.S. Air Force since 2019, died on May 3 in his apartment just five miles from his airbase after a deputy sheriff shot him while responding to a service call, CBS News reported.\n\nPolice earlier said the deputy reacted in self-defense after he saw Fortson armed with a gun, BBC reported.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing the victim's family, said in a statement that Fortson was on a FaceTime call with a woman at the time of the encounter, CBS News said.\n\nWhile Crump did not identify the woman, he said she heard the encounter when someone knocked on Fortson's door and he asked who it was, when no one replied, the attorney says the knocking got more aggressive and the victim checked the peephole and when he did not see anything, he got his legally owned firearm, CBS News said.\n\nCrump says authorities busted through his door, saw Fortson armed and opened fire, CBS News reported.\n\nFortson reportedly was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said, according to CBS News.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation, according to reports.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their FaceTime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said, according to CBS News.\n\nInside Edition Digital has reached out to Ben Crump for comment and has not heard back.\n\nThe officer was with the Okaloosa County Sheriff Department. patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event.\"\n\nThe incident is now being investigated by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the State Attorney's Office, Sheriff Aden added.\n\nInside Edition Digital has reached out to the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the State Attorney's Office for comment and has not heard back.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities,\" Crump said in a statement obtained by BBC.\n\nPolice are yet to respond to his statement, he says, according to BBC.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said in his statement obtained by WESH. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nAt a press conference Thursday afternoon, Crump called Fortson \"a patriot,\" and \"the best America had to offer\" who \"always dreamed of serving in the U.S. Air Force and he was living his dream and by doing so he was going to make it better for his mother and his family so they could have their chance at the American Dream.\"\n\nCrump also took to Instagram and made multiple posts about Fortson, including candid shots of him with his family.", "source":
