"https://www.insideedition.com/sites/default/files/images/2024-05/airman.jpg?crop=1280:720&width=1280", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-03", "textStart": 75, "textEnd": 80, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": -0.3960784313725491, "wgt": 204, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8119179937", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:03:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:03:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:01:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/attorney-family-of-black-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-want-a-transparent-investigation/article_80a8e664-6c36-51b9-ac36-45a5fac4b7b5.html", "title": "Attorney, family of Black airman fatally shot by Florida deputies want a transparent investigation", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The family of a 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force airman who was fatally shot by sheriff's deputies at his off-base apartment in Florida last week will join civil rights attorney Ben Crump for a news conference Thursday calling for transparency in the investigation.\n\nCrump said in a statement released Wednesday that Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson when they saw he was armed with a gun. Fortson was home alone and on a Facetime call with a friend when deputies arrived at his door, Crump said.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom the attorney didn't identify, said Fortson heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nOn Wednesday, when he released a statement about Fortson's death, Crump was in Ohio for the funeral of Frank Tyson, a 53-year-old who died in police custody on April 18.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's statements. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook on Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this {"uri": "8119578518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:50:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:50:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:49:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/news/11324139/who-roger-fortson-airman-death/", "title": "Who was airman Roger Fortson?", "body": "The 23-year-old's family has already retained noted civil rights attorney, Benjamin Crump\n\nROGER Fortson was sitting in his apartment, alone, when authorities reportedly burst through the door and shot him several times.\n\nFortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida.\n\nHe was a member of the 4th Special Operations Squadron, and entered active duty on November 19, 2019.\n\n\"By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson's squadron was one of nine in the 1st Special Operations Wing, and one of two that fly the AC-130 gunship.\n\nForston was a Special Mission Aviator assigned to the AC-130J gunship.\n\nAlong with his fellow crew members, he would \"fire the plane's 30mm and 105mm guns at ground targets, along with GBU-39 bombs, AGM-114 hellfire and AGM-176 Griffin missiles, and the GBU-69 Small Glide Munition,\" as reported by Task and Purpose.\n\nNot only was Fortson an active-duty service member who had just returned from a mission overseas, he also supported himself and his family.\n\nHe had no previous criminal record, was military-trained, and was reportedly a model citizen to those who knew him.\n\nOn Friday, May 3, 2024, Roger Fortson was reportedly alone at his off-base apartment, about five miles from his base.\n\nHe lived at the Chez Elan Apartments on Racetrack Road, and was reportedly on FaceTime at around 4:30 pm when he heard a knock on the door.\n\nHe asked who was there, and after receiving no response, checked the peep hole in his door, but didn't see anyone.\n\nAccording to the woman Fortson was on FaceTime with, who wishes to remain anonymous, Fortson reportedly grew concerned, and retrieved his gun, which he legally owned.\n\nAuthorities then reportedly burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed, and shot him six times.\n\nFortson was taken to a local hospital, where he eventually succumbed to his injuries and died.\n\nAccording to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, a deputy had responded to a call about a disturbance in progress at the Chez Elan Apartments.\n\nOCSO Sheriff Eric Aden released a statement about the shooting, calling the event \"tragic.\"\n\n\"All of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer involved shooting over the weekend,\" the statement said.\n\n\"Late Friday afternoon, our deputy responded to a call of a disturbance in progress where he encountered an armed man.\"\n\n\"The deputy shot the man, who later succumbed to his injuries,\" the statement said, referring to Fortson.\n\n\"I immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents.\"\n\n\"The State Attorney's Office will also conduct an independent review.\"\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event.\"\n\nRoger Fortson's family has retained Ben Crump to represent them in their case.\n\nBenjamin Lloyd Crump, known as Ben Crump, is an American attorney who specializes in personal injury and civil rights cases, including wrongful death lawsuits.\n\nCrump has previously represented the families of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and Trayvon Martin.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought [Fortson] was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said, as reported by AP News.\n\n\"They took a patriot from us,\" he said, before adding that law enforcement entered the wrong unit in the apartment complex.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump wrote in his statement on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\n\"The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\"\n\nCrump previously stated that Fortson was on a FaceTime call when he heard a knock on the door.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family.\"\n\n\"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy,\" Crump added in the statement.\n\n\"We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media.\"\n\n\"It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home.\"\n\n\"What we know for sure is that Roger was a dedicated U.S. Airman serving the country and a cherished member of his community.\"\n\n\"Any attempts to tarnish his character only compound the pain felt by his loved ones.\"\n\n\"We demand justice for Roger Fortson. We demand accountability for those responsible for his death.\"\n\n\"And we stand in solidarity with Roger's family and friends as they navigate this unimaginable loss,\" Crump wrote.", "source": {"uri": "8118200149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:34:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:34:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:34:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/08/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst/", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "U.S. Air Force via AP\n\nThis photo provided by the U.S. Air Force, shows Senior Airman Roger Fortson in a Dec. 24, 2019, photo. The Air Force says the airman supporting its Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Fla., was shot and killed on May 3, 2024, during an incident involving the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office.\n\nBy David Fischer, Associated Press\n\nWednesday, May 8, 2024 | 4:27 p.m.\n\nMIAMI -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n____\n\nAssociated Press reporter Curt Anderson contributed to this story from St. Petersburg, Florida.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas {"uri": "8118243690", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:30:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:30:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:29:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-u-s-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says-1.6879408", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot U.S. airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawyer", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? Log in.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office was responding to a disturbance between a man and woman in the apartment building, and deputies shot Fortson, who was Black, multiple times in the chest, according to police radio communications.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said. \"The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the attorney's claims. The sheriff's office recently came under scrutiny after one of its deputies resigned following an internal investigation last year of an incident in which he fired his weapon multiple times at a detained suspect after mistaking the sound of an acorn hitting the roof of his patrol vehicle as a gunshot, GulfLive.com reported.\n\nFortson lived in an off-base residence, and his special operations squadron at Hurlburt Field in the Florida panhandle flies AC-130J Ghostrider gunships.\n\nCrump said there was no disturbance and that Fortson was home alone on a video call with another person, who reported the airman heard a knock on the door.\n\nFortson, according to the witness, asked, \"Who is it?\" But he didn't receive an answer. After a subsequent \"aggressive\" second knock and seeing no one through the peephole, Fortson grabbed his legally owned gun, Crump detailed.\n\nAs Fortson was walking back to his living room, police entered the apartment and shot him. He reportedly said, \"I can't breathe\" while on the ground after being shot, Crump said, repeating a witness account of the event.\n\nPublicly available police radio audio reviewed by Military.com reported a call for a disturbance at an apartment complex at 319 Racetrack Road around 4:30 p.m. local time.\n\n\"Don't have anything further than a male and female; it's all fourth party information from the front desk at the leasing office,\" a deputy said on the radio.\n\nA few minutes later, another deputy called in to report \"shots fired, suspect down,\" and called for emergency medical services.\n\n\"Multiple gunshot wounds to the chest, Black male,\" another deputy chimes in shortly after. Fortson was shot six times, Crump said in his statement.\n\nNo other details, including the circumstances of the disturbance that prompted the local deputies to visit the apartment building, were released. Fortson was taken to an area hospital, where he later died. No officers were harmed in the incident.\n\nFortson joined the Air Force on November 19, 2019, according to a copy of his service record provided to Military.com. He joined as an AC-130J gunner. Crump added that Roger graduated from high school with honors and had no criminal record.\n\nThe deputy involved was not identified in the news release and was \"placed on paid administrative leave\" pending the outcome of an investigation and administrative review, the sheriff's office said.\n\nOn Monday evening, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden released a statement saying the department was \"saddened\" by the incident and calling for further investigation into the shooting.\n\n\"I immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents,\" Aden said. \"The State Attorney's Office will also conduct an independent review. At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office declined to provide Military.com the original 911 call and the police report into the incident, citing \"the ongoing active investigation\" in an emailed response.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of bodycam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy. We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media. {"uri": "2024-05-350605037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:04:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:04:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:54:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://eu.pnj.com/story/news/local/2024/05/09/airman-shot-in-florida-roger-fortson-family-ben-crump-calls-for-truth-to-come-out/73627192007/", "title": "Family of Florida airman killed by Okaloosa deputies demands his name be cleared", "body": "Attorney Ben Crump led a room full of people in a chant of \"clear Roger's name\" as he and the family of 23-year-old Special Operations Senior Airman Roger Fortson called upon the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office to clean up the narrative the agency had provided following the May 3 officer involved shooting that took Fortson's life.\n\nCrump, a well-known a civil rights attorney, held a Thursday press conference to present what they say is the real story of how Fortson died; shot inside his own apartment by cops who had burst in while he conversed over Facetime with his girlfriend.\n\nIt is their belief that the deputy who shot Fortson had entered the wrong apartment in answering a domestic disturbance call, and that the agency has since tried to change the story and cover up what really happened.\n\nRoger Fortson death: 'Police entered wrong apartment': Ben Crump takes case of airmen killed by deputy. What we know\n\nAn attorney from Crump's office said they have located \"an unofficial redacted 911 call\" that has led them to believe a disturbance had been reported to the leasing office at the Elan Apartment \"from what we believe to be a fourth party.\"\n\n\"We're telling the Sheriff's Office to be transparent, we're not going away until that transparency happens,\" said Brian Barr, an attorney from Pensacola's Levin Levin Papantonio Rafferty firm who is co-counseling in this case alongside Crump.\n\nTo hammer home the Sheriff's Office effort to turn attention away from the Fortson shooting, Barr pointed to the news release issued following the shooting. That release said the shooting took place \"after a deputy made contact with an armed individual at an apartment of Racetrack Road late Friday afternoon.\"\n\n\"Hearing sounds of a disturbance, he reacted in self defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun after the deputy identified himself as law enforcement,\" the release said.\n\n\"You read that statement, it makes you think this was outside, there was a disturbance and this kid was creating a scene,\" Barr said. \"They made it sound so convincing\" he told the assembled media, \"none of you covered it. It didn't get any attention. I didn't hear about it until this Tuesday, and I live here. This statement made people try to forget about Roger.\"\n\nAttorney Ben Crump, family to meet with Sheriff\n\nThe Sheriff's Office has continued since the shooting to say little about the incident. According to Crump, his fellow lawyers and the Fortson family would review body cam footage of the shooting at noon today. The Sheriff's Office has scheduled a press conference of its own for 2 p.m.\n\nCrump said the girlfriend, who has hired an attorney and is staying out of the public eye for now, has told him \"she heard everything\" that happened inside Fortson's apartment on the afternoon of the shooting.\n\nShe said Fortson was startled by an aggressive pounding on the door of the apartment, but when he peered through the peep hole could see no one on the other side, so he went and retrieved his legally registered gun.\n\n\"She just heard shots and he was on the ground, they just said 'he's shot up'\" Meka Fortson interjected, sobbing, as Crump spoke. \"My baby was shot up.\"\n\n\"Obviously you can see how devastated the family is,\" Crump continued. \"And as he was laying on the ground saying 'I can't breathe' they seemed to go through the apartment saying 'county sheriff, reveal yourself' while he was struggling to breathe.\"\n\nMore: Falling acorn spooks Florida deputy who fired into his own car, then resigned. Watch the video\n\nFortson, who had been shot six times, died from his injuries after being taken to a local hospital.\n\nMeka Fortson said the girlfriend had called her following the shooting and she had traveled from Atlanta to see him. She said Sheriff's Office investigators never told her that her son had died, only that his shooting was \"under investigation.\"\n\nRoger Fortson 'living his dream'\n\nShe called Roger Fortson the backbone of her family who had enlisted in the military after graduating high school to work toward his dream of buying her a home.\n\n\"He was living his dream, he was going to make life better for his mother and family,\" she said.\n\nHe was also well respected by his military superiors and colleagues, she said.\n\n\"Everybody has told us what a respectable young man he was,\" Meka Fortson said, adding that he would have had too much respect for law enforcement officers to confront them.\n\nCrump said the specific purpose of gathering the media Thursday was to call for steps to be taken to clear Roger Fortson's name.\n\n\"The purpose of this news conference is to demand that Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office do the right thing and correct this narrative,\" he said. \"Don't put a stain {"uri": "8119732882", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:09:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:09:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:08:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/video-shows-florida-deputy-announced-himself-prior-to-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman/article_7e5f8c07-0817-5072-9683-001d2b0a10ed.html", "title": "Video shows Florida deputy announced himself prior to fatal shooting of Black airman", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, body camera video shown to reporters Thursday shows.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe video from the deputy's body camera showed that Fortson answered his apartment door with what appears to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The video shows the deputy banging on the door, stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office!\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe door opened, and the deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" The deputy then fired off shots, and shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun! Do not move!\" The deputy then called for paramedics on his radio.\n\nNoted civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, earlier had asked the sheriff's office for transparency and disputed the narrative authorities released following the May 3 shooting. An email was sent to Crump's office Thursday afternoon seeking comment about what the bodycam footage showed and the sheriff's describing as inaccurate Crump's statements that the deputy went to the wrong apartment and didn't announce himself.\n\nAlden is seen on the video arriving at an apartment building and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nCrump told reporters earlier that Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating the shooting.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his Fort Walton Beach apartment.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nIn a statement last week, the sheriff's office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\n___\n\nThe spelling of the name of Fortson's mother has been corrected to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki.", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118240347", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:24:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:24:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:24:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/national-international/hurlburt-field-airman-fatally-shot-by-florida-deputies-after-bursting-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says/3408105/", "title": "US airman fatally shot by Florida deputies after bursting into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3\n\nDeputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n____", "source": {"uri": "nbclosangeles.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Southern California"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawyer", {"uri": "2024-05-350536441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:37:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:37:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:34:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/4654138-attorneys-family-of-slain-airman-demand-transparency-from-police-officers/", "title": "Attorneys, family of slain airman demand transparency from police officers", "body": "Civil rights attorney Ben Crump on Thursday said Florida police officers violated the constitutional rights of Roger Fortson, a 23-year-old active-duty Senior Airman who was fatally shot by a Florida sheriff's deputy on May 3.\n\nSpeaking from Florida with Fortson's family at his side, Crump urged the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office to \"tell the truth\" about what happened the night Fortson was killed.\n\n\"They thought he was a bad guy,\" Crump said. \"But he was a good guy. They killed a good guy. They took from his mama a good guy. They took from his brother and sister a good guy. They took from his father a good guy. They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nAccording to Crump, Fortson was alone in his apartment on the night of the shooting when he heard a knock at the door.\n\nFortson asked who was at the door but didn't get a response. Minutes later, there was an \"aggressive\" knock on the door, but Fortson was unable to see anyone when he looked out the peephole.\n\nFortson then retrieved his legally-owned gun. As he was walking back to the living room, police burst through the door.\n\nUpon seeing the gun, police shot Fortson six times.\n\nAccording to a witness who Crump said was on Facetime with Fortson during the shooting, Fortson fell to the ground stating, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot. He was transported to a hospital, where he died.\n\nThe witness, according to Crump, said there was no disturbance in the apartment and Fortson was alone when police burst in.\n\nIn a statement released last week, the sheriff's office said that a deputy was responding to a call of a disturbance at Fortson's apartment complex and reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man.\n\nBut attorneys for Fortson's family lambasted the police department for a \"disingenuous\" narrative that smears Fortson's name by implying he had committed a crime.\n\n\"Tell the truth,\" Crump said. \"That's not so hard to do.\"\n\n\"The truth is this is about the Constitution, because in the state of Florida, I mean, we encourage gun ownership,\" said Crump. \"Roger had a right to the Second Amendment ... and he also had a right to the Fourth Amendment, to be free of unlawful searches and seizures. Especially in his home.\"\n\nAttorney Brian Barr, who is representing Fortson's family with Crump, added that the young airman could have been anyone.\n\n\"Every one of us sit in our houses every day, and every one of us, if somebody we don't know comes into our house, are going to defend ourselves?\" Barr said. \"He lost his life because they knocked on the wrong door.\"\n\nBarr added that the attorneys and family just want transparency from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office.\n\n\"We want to see the body cam video. We want to know what happened. We want the mistakes to be owned,\" said Barr. \"And we're not going away until that transparency happens, and we're not going to let them forget Roger. That's not going to happen, not on our watch.\"\n\nCrump said the family will meet with Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden on Thursday. He expects body camera footage of the shooting to be shared with the family at the meeting.\n\nThe Hill has reached out to the sheriff's office for comment.", "source": {"uri": "thehill.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hill"}, "authors": [{"uri": "cheyanne_m_daniels@thehill.com", "name": "Cheyanne M. "label": {"eng": "Florida"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriot_(American_Revolution)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, {"uri": "8118443513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:21:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:21:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:20:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/air-force-airman-killed-florida-041201477.html", "title": "Air Force airman killed by Florida deputies who were at wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "An Air Force airman who was fatally shot at his Okaloosa County, Florida, apartment Friday was killed by a deputy after law enforcement burst into the wrong home, civil rights attorney Ben Crump said Wednesday.\n\nA woman said that she was on a FaceTime video call with Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, when he was killed and that he was alone and there was no disturbance, which law enforcement said was the reason for the call, Crump said.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said that Friday afternoon, \"our deputy responded to a call of a disturbance in progress where he encountered an armed man,\" and the deputy shot him.\n\nAccording to the woman on the FaceTime call, whom Crump did not identify, Fortson heard a knock at his door, asked \"Who is it?\" got no response and could not see anyone through the peephole, Crump said in a statement.\n\nThere was a second, aggressive knock, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\n\"Concerned, he did what any other law-abiding citizen would do and retrieved his legally-owned gun, but as he was walking back to the living room, police burst through the door. When they saw the gun, they shot Roger six times,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"The witness has said that she saw Roger on the ground stating, 'I can't breathe,' after he was shot,\" Crump said. \"She has also said the police were in the wrong apartment as there was no disturbance in the apartment and he was alone.\"\n\nA sheriff's spokesperson Friday night did not immediately respond to a request for comment about the claim that police were at the wrong apartment.\n\nThe Florida Department of Law Enforcement said it is investigating the shooting at the request of the sheriff's department. It did not provide any additional information, citing the active investigation.\n\nThe state attorney's office is also conducting an independent review, the sheriff's office said.\n\nSheriff Eric Aden said in a statement that \"all of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer involved shooting over the weekend.\"\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" he said.\n\nHurlburt Field, the Air Force base where Fortson was assigned, said in a statement that Fortson entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019. He was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron.\n\n\"The 1st Special Operations Wing's priorities are providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted,\" the base said.\n\nOkaloosa County is in the Florida Panhandle, east of Pensacola.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "8119836921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:50:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:50:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:49:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.theadvocate.com/video-shows-florida-deputy-announced-himself-prior-to-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman/article_e5611cc7-4d05-5a6d-b1db-a282e27048c3.html", "title": "Video shows Florida deputy announced himself prior to fatal shooting of Black airman", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense. Aden rejected assertions made by civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, that the deputy had gone to the wrong apartment, covered the door's peephole and did not announce himself.\n\nThe video shows the deputy arriving at a Fort Walton Beach apartment building on May 3 and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nThe video shows the deputy banging on the door and stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office! Open the door!\"\n\nFortson opened the door and could be seen holding what appeared to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" and fired off shots. He then shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun!\"\n\n\"It's over there,\" Fortson said.\n\n\"Drop the gun!\" the deputy yelled back.\n\n\"I don't have it,\" Fortson said, lying on the ground.\n\nThe deputy then called paramedics on his radio.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputy or his race. The deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump released a statement later noting that the officer did not tell Roger to drop his gun before shooting \"multiple times within a split second of the door being opened.\"\n\n\"We remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment,\" the statement said.\n\nCrump also told reporters earlier that Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime and that he grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment. He said that the deputy burst into the apartment, citing the account of the girlfriend, who has not yet been identified.\n\n\"The girlfriend acknowledges that even though she initially thought the door was forced open by the police that she stands by her emotional recollection of what happened,\" Crump's later statement said.\n\nAden said he had met with the family before showing the video to reporters and extended his deepest condolences.\n\n\"This result is one we never hope to encounter,\" Aden said. \"These investigations take time, but I want to assure you that we are not hiding or attempting to cover anything up.\"\n\nOfficials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating. FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nThe sheriff said the probe was being handled as a criminal investigation and that no determination had yet been made on whether the deputy's actions were justified or not. However, the initial news release from the sheriff's office that described the shooting said that the deputy \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times.\n\nHe said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\nThe spelling of the name of Fortson's mother has been corrected to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki.", "source": {"uri": "theadvocate.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Advocate"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@theadvocate.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", {"uri": "8116187713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "20:02:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T20:02:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T20:02:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/roger-fortson-us-airman-killed-florida-officer-1898100", "title": "Who is Roger Fortson? US airman killed by Florida sheriff's officer", "body": "The US service member fatally shot by a Florida sheriff's deputy on Friday has been identified by the Air Force as Senior Airman Roger Fortson.\n\nFortson, 23, was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron at Hurlburt Field, Fla., according to the Air Force. He entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nDozens wrote heartfelt messages on the Hurburt Field's Facebook post about Fortson describing him as a \"phenomenal human\" who \"always had a smile on his face.\" One of his instructors, U.S. Air Force Tech Sgt. Curtis Lassiter called him a \"very bright young man,\" who was \"one of the best students to go through training.\"\n\n\"Roger was a very humble and mellow guy,\" said his cousin, Keon Johnson. \"He was always happy and smiling.\"\n\nJohnson called Forston \"very, very smart,\" recalling his 5th grade Criterion-Reference Competency Test scores were \"extremely high and exceeded the standard.\"\n\n\"I was so shocked because I never saw anything like it,\" Johnsons aid. \"I knew then my cousin was very special and could be or do whatever his heart desired.\"\n\nForston loved playing video games and enjoyed football.\n\n\"He definitely didn't deserve what happened to him,\" Johnson said.\n\nHe served as a gunner on the AC-130J Ghostrider, providing close air support and armed reconnaissance.\n\nA deputy responding to a disturbance call \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release on Friday.\n\nForston, who was from Atlanta, was at his off-base apartment on Racetrack Road when the shooting happened around 4:30 p.m., according to the Air Force.\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital, where he died.\n\nThe deputy was placed on paid administrative leave, \"pending the outcome of a formal investigation and administrative review,\" according to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office.\n\n\"To protect the integrity of the investigation, no other information will be released at this time,\" according to the Hurlburt Field Facebook page.\n\nThe 1st Special Operations Wing is providing casualty affairs services to Fortson's family and a base-wide message was sent on mental health resources.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-05-349581334", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:15:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:15:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:11:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.wjcl.com/article/airman-shot-killed-florida-police-identified-air-force/60717082", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.Civil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.According to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.The woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.As Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.Fortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.The woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"Crump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.Crump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.The Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.The sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.The sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.Fort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.____Associated Press reporter Curt Anderson contributed to this story from St. Petersburg, Florida.\n\nDeputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida {"uri": "8119402901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:34:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:34:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:34:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.military.com/daily-news/2024/05/09/they-took-my-gift-away-interview-mother-of-florida-airman-killed-police-describes-shock.html", "title": "'They Took My Gift Away': In Interview, Mother of Florida Airman Killed by Police Describes Shock", "body": "The mother of the 23-year-old airman who was shot and killed by police on May 3 said her son was a model citizen and called for the Florida sheriff's office to be forthcoming about his last moments.\n\nMeka Fortson told Military.com in an exclusive interview Thursday that her son, Senior Airman Roger Fortson, had always wanted to serve his country and had dreams of becoming a pilot. She said he had recently returned from a deployment overseas, only to die in his apartment.\n\n\"It's a disbelief. Every day, I try to go to sleep early to wake up like it's a dream,\" she told Military.com. \"He just came back from deployment from fighting for us. With everything we got going on in our country, he's fighting for us and he came back to be murdered, slain like that so violently.\"\n\nRead Next: Police Who Shot Florida Airman 6 Times in His Home May Have Entered Wrong Apartment, Family Says\n\nRoger Fortson lived in an off-base residence in Fort Walton Beach. His special operations squadron at Hurlburt Field in the Florida panhandle flies AC-130J Ghostrider gunships.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a May 4 statement that deputies were responding to a reported disturbance.\n\nBut Ben Crump, a high-profile civil rights attorney retained by the Fortson family, said there was no disturbance and that Fortson was home alone May 3, chatting on a video call with another person, who told the attorney that the airman heard a knock on his door.\n\nRoger Fortson, according to the witness, asked, \"Who is it?\" But he didn't receive an answer. After a subsequent \"aggressive\" second knock and seeing no one through the peephole, Fortson grabbed his legally owned gun, Crump said.\n\nThe Sunshine State has made it easier to buy and carry firearms in recent years, and has created special carve-outs for service members that simplify the process further, such as not requiring troops to take safety courses in order to qualify to carry concealed weapons under a 2023 law.\n\nFortson was a service member, in his own residence and had no criminal record, Crump said.\n\nIn a May 4 statement, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said, \"Hearing sounds of a disturbance, [the deputy] reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun and after the deputy had identified himself as law enforcement.\"\n\nCrump pushed back against that narrative and told Military.com no gunfire was exchanged and that Fortson was a model citizen who did not pose a threat.\n\n\"The reality is he was the best of us. He was the person who you would trust with a firearm. I mean, he was military trained,\" Crump said. \"So, for them to put out a statement claiming self-defense is just misleading because they're trying to suggest that what they did was justified.\"\n\nAs Fortson was walking back to his living room, police entered the apartment and shot him. He reportedly said \"I can't breathe\" while on the ground after being shot, Crump said, repeating a witness account of the event.\n\nPolice radio audio reviewed by Military.com reported a call for a disturbance at an apartment complex at 319 Racetrack Road around 4:30 p.m. local time.\n\n\"Don't have anything further than a male and female; it's all fourth-party information from the front desk at the leasing office,\" a deputy said on the radio.\n\nA few minutes later, another deputy reported \"shots fired, suspect down,\" and called for emergency medical services.\n\n\"Multiple gunshot wounds to the chest, Black male,\" another deputy chimes in shortly after. Fortson was shot six times, Crump said in his statement.\n\nNo other details, including the circumstances of the disturbance that prompted the local deputies to visit the apartment building, were released. Fortson was taken to an area hospital, where he later died. No officers were harmed in the incident.\n\nThe sheriff's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment Wednesday on the attorney's claims. The same sheriff's office received public scrutiny when an internal investigation detailed that a deputy fired his weapon multiple times at a detained suspect after believing the sound of an acorn hitting his vehicle was gunfire, GulfLive.com reported. That deputy resigned.\n\nCrump told Military.com that he wants the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office to admit that it did something wrong and criticized the deputies, saying they didn't identify themselves when they came to Roger's apartment.\n\n\"All he did was what many law-abiding, responsible American citizens would have done,\" Crump said. \"And that is when you hear somebody at your door, and you are not sure who it is because you don't hear them identify themselves, you get your legally registered firearm for protection.\"\n\nFortson joined the Air Force on Nov. 19, 2019, according to a copy of his service record provided to Military.com. He joined as an AC-130J gunner. He graduated from McNair High School in Atlanta, Georgia, with honors, Crump told Military.com.\n\nThe deputy involved was not identified in the news release.\n\nOn Monday evening, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden released a statement saying the department was \"saddened\" by the incident and called for further investigation into the shooting.\n\n\"I immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents,\" Aden said. \"The State Attorney's Office will also conduct an independent review. At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office declined to provide Military.com the original 911 call, body camera footage or the police report into the incident, citing \"the ongoing active investigation\" in an emailed response.\n\nFollowing his death, Roger's mother has received kind words from those who served alongside him. She described him as a rising star in the ranks and an inspiration to his 16-year-old brother and 10-year-old sister.\n\n\"He was my gift, and they took my gift away,\" Roger's mother said. \"And they didn't give it to me. God gave me that gift ... and they took my gift away.\"", "source": {"uri": "military.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Military"}, "authors": [{"uri": "thomas_novelly@military.com", "name": "Thomas
