{"uri": "8119724883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:01:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:01:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:01:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mn/video-shows-florida-deputy-announced-himself-prior-to-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman/article_4126ea3f-f900-59b9-9b1b-2972cabad7a5.html", "title": "Video shows Florida deputy announced himself prior to fatal shooting of Black airman", "body": "By STEPHEN SMITH and MIKE SCHNEIDER - Associated Press\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, body camera video shown to reporters Thursday shows.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense.\n\nThe video from the deputy's body camera showed that Fortson answered his apartment door with what appears to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The video shows the deputy banging on the door, stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office!\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school Coaches association warns Waunakee basketball lawsuit 'sets dangerous precedent' Joe Gow's teaching position at issue as UW-La Crosse Faculty Senate to hear unethical conduct allegations Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire Onalaska man faces 60 years for alleged sexual assault of girls River Point District developers hit stride as buildings rise along La Crosse riverfront Onalaska registered sex offender arrested for possession of child pornography Viroqua High School's Kami Delap wins silver at national powerlifting championship Extra Effort: Luther High student overcomes school difficulties on her way to education career American Airlines reintroduces higher capacity E175 jets at La Crosse Regional Airport Extra effort: Holmen teen with brain tumor achieves academic success Paul S. Schemenauer\n\nThe door opened, and the deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" The deputy then fired off shots, and shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun! Do not move!\" The deputy then called for paramedics on his radio.\n\nNoted civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, earlier had asked the sheriff's office for transparency and disputed the narrative authorities released following the May 3 shooting. An email was sent to Crump's office Thursday afternoon seeking comment about what the bodycam footage showed and the sheriff's describing as inaccurate Crump's statements that the deputy went to the wrong apartment and didn't announce himself.\n\nAlden is seen on the video arriving at an apartment building and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nCrump told reporters earlier that Fortson had grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating the shooting.\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death inside his Fort Walton Beach apartment.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"He was just in his apartment, minding his businesses,\" Crump said. \"They could have made sure they were at the right apartment. They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door.\"\n\nIn a statement last week, the sheriff's office said a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times and died at a hospital. The deputy who shot him was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\n\"He was living his dream. By doing so, he was going to make it better for his mother and siblings so they could have a better chance at the American dream,\" Crump said.\n\nFortson was talking to his girlfriend, who hasn't yet been identified, on FaceTime when deputies burst into his apartment on May 3, Crump added.\n\nWithout her, his family wouldn't have known what happened, he said. The girlfriend notified his mother, who drove to Fort Walton Beach to find out that her son was dead.\n\nAt the hospital, deputies approached Chantemekki Fortson, and she told them, \"'You guys have killed my baby. Just take me to my baby please. I just want to see my child,'\" she recounted at the news conference.\n\n\"They had taken my gift,\" she said. \"My heart is bleeding, and they wanted to talk to me. They told me the investigation was ongoing,\" she said.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nIn November 2023, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy mistook the sound of an acorn hitting his patrol vehicle for a gunshot and fired multiple times at the SUV where a handcuffed Black man was sitting in the backseat. Sheriff's officials said the man, who was being questioned about stealing his girlfriend's car, was not injured. He was taken into custody, but released without being charged. The officer who initiated the shooting resigned.\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\nThe spelling of the name of Fortson's mother has been corrected to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8119502694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:49:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:49:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:48:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.unionleader.com/news/national/deputy-fatally-shot-black-airman-after-entering-wrong-apartment-lawyer-says/article_83fcc15a-0e23-11ef-a478-676168a29f5b.html", "title": "Deputy fatally shot Black airman after entering wrong apartment, lawyer says", "body": "A Florida deputy fatally shot a Black Air Force airman last week after forcibly entering the wrong apartment, his family's attorney alleged Wednesday, citing information from a witness.\n\nThe witness - who was on FaceTime with Senior Airman Roger Fortson during the incident - said Fortson, 23, was alone in his apartment when the authorities entered, according to a statement released by attorney Ben Crump's office.\n\nFortson heard a knock at the door and asked who was there, but did not receive a reply, the witness said. After another \"very aggressive knock,\" Fortson looked out the peephole and could not see anyone. He was concerned, the statement said, and retrieved a gun, which he owned legally.\n\nAs Fortson returned to the living room with the gun, the authorities allegedly burst through the door and shot him six times. The witness recalled Fortson saying \"I can't breathe\" after he was shot. He died at a hospital.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement released Tuesday that a deputy was responding to a \"call of a disturbance in progress\" when he \"encountered an armed man,\" whom the deputy shot.\n\nCrump said in the statement that the authorities' telling of the incident \"falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat\" and is \"deeply troubling.\"\n\n\"It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home,\" he said, calling for transparency in the investigation and the immediate release of body-cam footage to Fortson's family.\n\nThe Florida Attorney General's Office and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement did not immediately respond to requests for comment Wednesday evening.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said in a statement that he placed the deputy on administrative leave and asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct a review.\n\nFortson enlisted in 2019 and served as a special mission aviator with the 4th Special Operations Squadron, the Air Force said, including as a gunner on the AC-130J, a workhorse aircraft in Special Operations. His decorations include an Air Medal with \"C\" Device, according to his service record, indicating that he served in a combat environment.\n\nThe Black community is saddened over the killing, and anger is starting to boil over as few questions are being answered by authorities, said Sabu Williams, an Air Force veteran and president of the Okaloosa County branch of the NAACP.\n\nWilliams said he has met with military and law enforcement officials to learn more about the incident, but that details on why the deputy arrived at Fortson's door, who opened it and what circumstances led to the shooting remain unclear or ambiguously described by the sheriff's office.\n\n\"There are issues with this incident,\" he said. \"Issues I think will probably not fare well for the deputy involved.\"\n\nNicole Hodskins, an Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office spokesperson, said police shootings are typically referred to state law enforcement investigators but did not respond to a request to provide recent examples.\n\nThe Washington Post on Tuesday requested body-camera footage from deputies involved and the incident report filed after the shooting. A representative of the records office said the report is \"still in the process of being completed.\" The sheriff's department will release the footage Thursday afternoon, a spokesperson said.\n\nAccording to internal investigation documents released in February, a law enforcement officer from the same sheriff's office shot at an unarmed and handcuffed man in November after he mistook the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot. While the investigation concluded that the deputy used excessive force, there were no criminal charges filed, and the deputy resigned before the public release of the findings.\n\nPolice violence against Black Americans has sparked mass protests over the past decade, including the Black Lives Matter movement, in response to the killings of such individuals as Eric Garner, Breonna Taylor and others. Public outcry reached a fever pitch in 2020 after George Floyd's fatal interaction with police.\n\nAccording to The Post's database of fatal police shootings from 2015 to April this year, police killed the highest number of people on record in 2023, and Black Americans are killed by police at more than twice the rate of White Americans.\n\nFortson joined the military after graduating from high school with honors and did not have a criminal record, Crump's office said in the statement. \"By all accounts, he was a stellar member of the Air Force and loved by his community,\" Crump wrote of Fortson.", "source": {"uri": "unionleader.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UnionLeader.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawyer", "type": "wiki", "score": {"uri": "8119309090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:27:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:27:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:26:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://lavocedinewyork.com/en/news/2024/05/09/us-airman-was-killed-by-cops-who-entered-wrong-apartment-attorneys-say/", "title": "US Airman Was Killed by Cops Who Entered Wrong Apartment, Attorneys Say", "body": "Officers allegedly shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson six times after noticing he was armed\n\nCivil rights lawyer Ben Crump is set to join a press conference on Thursday to demand justice for a 23-year-old Black Air Force airman who was shot and killed by sheriff's deputies at his off-base residence in Florida last week.\n\nIn a statement made public on Wednesday, Crump said that Okaloosa County Sheriff's officers responding to a disturbance complaint at the Fort Walton Beach apartment complex entered the incorrect unit and shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson to death when they noticed he was carrying a gun.\n\nWhen deputies showed up at Fortson's door, he was alone in his house, talking on Facetime with a woman who is now the key witness in the case. After noticing Fortson was armed, officers allegedly shot him six times.\n\n\"The witness has said that she saw Roger on the ground stating, 'I can't breathe,' after he was shot,\" Crump said. \"She has also said the police were in the wrong apartment as there was no disturbance in the apartment and he was alone.\"\n\nRoger was later declared dead in a hospital.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump stated, as reported by the Associated Press.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump added. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nAt the sheriff's department's request, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement announced that it is looking into the shooting. Awaiting the results of the inquiry, the deputy who was shot was put on administrative leave.\n\n\"All of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer involved shooting over the weekend,\" said sheriff Eric Aden in a statement. \"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" he added.\n\nAccording to the sheriff's office, an independent assessment is also being carried out by the state attorney's office.\n\nThe circumstances surrounding Fortson's murder bear remarkable resemblance to those of other Black individuals who were slain by police in their homes in recent years, when the cops had responded to the incorrect location or had used wanton use of fatal force in response to service calls.\n\nBreonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home in 2020 during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend, and Ahmaud Arbery are just a few of the high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people in which Crump, a well-known attorney based in Florida, has been involved.", "source": {"uri": "lavocedinewyork.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8117363823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:27:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:27:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:26:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://popularmilitary.com/special-operations-airman-dies-after-being-shot-by-police-at-his-residence/", "title": "Special Operations Airman dies after being shot by police at his residence", "body": "Senior Airman Roger Fortson (Air Force/Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office)\n\nA special operations airman died after being shot by police at an apartment complex in Florida on Friday afternoon.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was shot by an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy who responded to a \"disturbance in progress\" call at the Chez Elan Apartment complex in Fort Walton Beach.\n\nAccording to the Sheriff's office, the deputy encountered Fortson armed and shot him in \"self-defense.\"\n\n\"Hearing sounds of a disturbance, he reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun and after the deputy had identified himself as law enforcement,\" Sherriff Eric Aden said in a statement.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron at Hurlburt Field -roughly eight miles from where the shooting occurred.\n\nAccording to a press release from Hurlburt Field, Fortson lived at the apartment complex where he was shot.\n\nThe base did not release his service records but said he joined the Air Force in 2019.\n\nThe deputy was been placed on leave until the Florida Department of Law Enforcement conducts its investigation of the shooting.\n\nThe deputy has yet to be identified.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's came under scrutiny earlier this year after a deputy fired shots at a handcuffed suspect when he misinterpreted the sound of an acorn falling on his vehicle as gunshots.\n\n\u00a9 2024 Bright Mountain Media, Inc. {"uri": "8118975366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:47:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:47:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:46:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "http://www.sfltimes.com/business/air-force-service-member-shot-killed-by-florida-police-identified", "title": "Air Force service member shot, killed by Florida police identified", "body": "SENIOR AIRMAN ROGER FORTSON: Died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement Monday. PHOTO COURTESY OF MILITARY.COM\n\nFort Walton Beach, Fla. (AP) - The U.S. Air Force said an airman based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida, was shot and killed Friday during an incident involving a sheriff's deputy.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said in a statement released Monday.\n\nA deputy responding to the call of a disturbance in progress \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23year-old man armed with a gun,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a news release Friday.\n\nFortson was taken to a hospital where he died, officials said. The deputy involved was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nIn a statement late Tuesday, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the incident and the State Attorney's Office will conduct an independent review. He said the sheriff's office was \"saddened\" by the shooting.\n\nThe Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are \"providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the an apartment complex on 319 Racetrack Road in Okaloosa County, Florida.\n\nA Okaloosa County deputy was responding to report of a disturbance and 'reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun,' cops say.\n\nA witness, who was on FaceTime with Fortson during the time of the shooting, claimed Fortson heard a knock at the door and asked who was there.\n\nU.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was identified as the young man shot dead in a shooting last Friday afternoon\n\nThe black airman (pictured) was killed in his Florida apartment after police forced their way into the wrong apartment and shot him as his horrified friend watched on FaceTime\n\nWhen he did not receive a response but heard another 'very aggressive knock,' Fortson peered through the peephole - but did not see anyone and grew concerned.\n\nOut of concern, Fortson retrieved a gun - which he owned legally, according to the witness.\n\nWhen he returned to his living room with the gun, authorities allegedly pushed through his door and shot him six times.\n\nThe traumatized witness, who remained on the FaceTime call for the duration of the horrifying shooting, recalled that Fortson said 'I can't breathe,' after the shots were fired. Fortson later died at the hospital.\n\nThe deputy involved in the incident has since been placed on administrative leave while the shooting continues to be investigated.\n\nThe 23-year old was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida. {"uri": "8119632869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:35:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:35:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:35:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/family-of-us-airman-killed-by-florida-deputy-demands-release-of-body-cam-video/article_8674f315-fa28-5d2b-90d4-ee8f009486b8.html", "title": "Family of US airman killed by Florida deputy demands release of body-cam video", "body": "By Brendan O'Brien\n\n(Reuters) -A Florida sheriff's deputy who fatally shot a Black airman over the weekend may have entered the wrong apartment in response to a disturbance call, according to the family's attorney who is demanding the release of body-camera video showing the shooting.\n\nThe shooting occurred on the afternoon of May 3, when a deputy with the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office went to the apartment complex, entered the unit and opened fire, according to a statement from Sheriff Eric Aden.\n\nSix shots hit Roger Fortson, 23, a senior Air Force airman who was stationed nearby, according to attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family.\n\nThe sheriff said the deputy heard sounds of a disturbance and reacted in self defense after he encountered the 23-year-old. The sheriff did not name Fortson in his statement.\n\nDuring a news conference on Thursday, Crump said Fortson was on a Facetime call with his girlfriend after he just got home from playing video games with his friends. When he heard a knock on his door, he asked, \"Who is it?\" but didn't get a response.\n\nFortson then retrieved a gun he owned legally and was walking back into his living room when the deputies burst through the door and opened fire. Fortson did not fire his weapon, Crump said.\n\n\"He was in his apartment minding his business and then ... this cascade of tragic events started to take place,\" he said, calling on the sheriff to release body-camera footage.\n\nThe killing is reminiscent of an unannounced police raid in Louisville, Kentucky, in March 2020, when police burst into the apartment of Breonna Taylor, a Black 26-year-old emergency medical technician, killing her. Under questionable pretenses, police had obtained a \"no knock\" warrant to raid the apartment.\n\nTaylor's death, along with the killing of George Floyd by Minneapolis police weeks later, set off a worldwide wave of protests against racism in law enforcement in the summer of 2020.\n\nAfter Fortson was shot, he was taken to a hospital where he died from his wounds.\n\nThe deputy went to the wrong apartment as there was no disturbance at Fortson's residence and he was alone, Crump said.\n\n\"They had a duty to make sure they were at the right apartment before they busted in the door,\" he said, noting that the U.S. Constitution protected against unreasonable searches and seizures by police.\n\nCrump said Fortson always dreamt of becoming a pilot, describing him as a patriot and a good young man who followed rules and respected authority.\n\n\"My baby was my everything,\" his mother said during the news conference, demanding full transparency from the sheriff's office as she held a photograph of her son. \"Tell the truth about my son ... please clean his reputation.\"\n\nThe deputy, who has not been identified, was placed on paid administrative leave pending the investigation, the sheriff said. He did not specify who was conducting the investigation.\n\n(Reporting by Brendan O'Brien in Chicago; Editing by Alistair Bell and Bill Berkot)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8119702569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:39:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:39:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:39:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/news/11323714/roger-fortson-death-airman-okaloosa-county-florida-video/", "title": "Horrific bodycam footage shows cop shoot dead Airman as he opened apartment door", "body": "COPS investigating the death of a US airman have shown sickening bodycam footage of the moment he was killed.\n\nAir Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was shot dead in his own apartment by officers in a suspected case of mistaken identity.\n\nAddressing the media before showing the video, Sheriff Eric Aden from Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said that his officers had let Fortson know they were law enforcement twice before opening fire.\n\nIn the short clip, a volley of shots can be heard ringing out as an officer shouts \"Drop the weapon.\"\n\nFortson, 23, was killed after the police rushed into the wrong home and shot him.\n\nAt the time, he was alone in his home some five miles from his base at Hurlburt Field, Florida.\n\n\"Our deputy responded to a call of a disturbance in progress where he encountered an armed man,\" according to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office last Friday afternoon.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump previously revealed at the time that the Senior Airman was on a Facetime call with a woman when police showed up at the house.\n\nThe attorney revealed that Fortson initially heard a knock but no one had answered.\n\nInstead, he heard another knock that was much more aggressive.\n\n\"Concerned, he did what any other law-abiding citizen would do and retrieved his legally owned gun, but as he was walking back to the living room, police burst through the door. When they saw the gun, they shot Roger six times,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"The witness has said that she saw Roger on the ground stating, 'I can't breathe,' after he was shot,\" Crump said.\n\n\"She has also said the police were in the wrong apartment as there was no disturbance in the apartment and he was alone.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has not confirmed whether they were in the wrong home.\n\nHowever, a statement was released after the news of Fortson's death.\n\n\"All of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer-involved shooting over the weekend,\" Sheriff Eric Aden said in a statement.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" he said.\n\nHurlburt Field, the Air Force base where the airman was assigned, also released a statement after the news was released.\n\n\"The 1st Special Operations Wing's priorities are providing {"uri": "8119414629", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:43:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:43:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:42:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://bossip.com/2650806/roger-fortson-killed-by-police-entering-wrong-apartment/", "title": "Cops Kill People: Florida Officers", "body": "Florida is a trash-a** state for hundreds of years of reasons and today we can add another heartbreaking one to top of the list.\n\nAccording to APNews, an inept group of sheriff's deputies in Miami, Florida were responding to a call about a disturbance at an apartment complex on May 3, 2024. When they arrived on the scene, they were so jacked up on adrenaline and ready to use force than they kicked in the wrong door and shot 23-year-old Black U.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson to death with six rounds.\n\nThe report states that Fortson was alone in his home talking to a woman on FaceTime when he heard the disturbance that deputies were responding to. The woman says Fortson heard a knock at his door but got no response when he asked who it was. Upon hearing a second, much louder knock, Fortson checked the peephole but saw no one outside. The woman says he grew concerned and went to retrieve his legally owned firearm. When he walked back into the living room, cops kicked in the door and immediate began firing at the sight of Fortson holding a gun. The witness says he laid on the floor saying, \"I can't breathe\". He would die later at the hospital.\n\nWhat is it with cops not knowing how to read numbers? This case sounds very familiar to the Amber Guyger case and the death of Botham Jean.\n\nUbiquitous civil rights attorney Ben Crump is representing Fortson's family in the ongoing case.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Department refused to publicly name the deputies involved or disclose their races but Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office are investigating the incident while the officer is on administrative leave.\n\nWe will provide more information as it "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3803921568627451, "wgt": 185, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8118223032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:04:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:04:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:03:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mn/florida-deputies-who-fatally-shot-us-airman-burst-into-wrong-apartment-attorney-says/article_086c7d82-99b9-5d6c-8aee-c573572ebf8d.html", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong apartment, attorney says", "body": "By DAVID FISCHER - Associated Press\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man's family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn't identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn't see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman's account.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school Amtrak adds second train between Twin Cities, Chicago; Borealis service will stop in La Crosse, Tomah, Winona Mount Horeb shooting: Students 'saw something' as teen approached school, notified staff Joe Gow's teaching position at issue as UW-La Crosse Faculty Senate to hear unethical conduct allegations La Crosse orders City Brewery to stop the smells; daily fines begin Monday Coaches association warns Waunakee basketball lawsuit 'sets dangerous precedent' Onalaska teen faces charges for uploading child pornography Onalaska man faces 60 years for alleged sexual assault of girls River Point District developers hit stride as buildings rise along La Crosse riverfront Viroqua High School's Kami Delap wins silver at national powerlifting championship Extra Effort: Luther High student overcomes school difficulties on her way to education career\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump's statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump's claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I'm trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. (WEAR/TND) -- Last Friday's shooting in the Florida panhandle that killed a senior airman with the U.S. Air Force reportedly happened after deputies responding to a disturbance call at the apartment complex burst into the wrong unit.\n\nDispatch calls released to WEAR revealed Okaloosa County deputies reported shooting Fortson within six minutes of dispatch getting the disturbance call.\n\nThe sheriff's office said a deputy acted in self-defense after hearing sounds of a disturbance inside Fortson's off-base apartment, and that Fortson was believed to be armed with a gun after the deputy identified himself as law enforcement.\n\nDispatch calls revealed deputies thought Fortson was shot six times:\n\nGunshot wounds to the chest. One exit wound, counted six gunshot wounds.\n\nAccording to Crump, witnesses said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock on the door and asked, \"Who is it?\" but didn't get a response. A few minutes later, there was an aggressive knock on the door, but Fortson didn't see anyone on the other side.\n\nCrump wrote that Fortson grabbed his \"legally-owned\" gun and was shot as he was walking back to the living room, as deputies burst through the door.\n\nAccording to Crump, witnesses said deputies were in the wrong apartment. He's asking for bodycam video to be released right away.\n\nSo is the president of Okaloosa NAACP.\n\n\"I'm just concerned as to what happened and why it happened and how it happened,\" Sabu Williams said. \"We're going to remain engaged in the outcome in the investigation.\"\n\n\"This one tells me there may be more to it than meets the eye right now,\" he added.\n\nWilliams said the video should give the public insight on what happened.\n\n\"We certainly share our grievances not only with family, but co-workers and friends in the community,\" he said. \"We've spoken with base commanders and our community and the sheriff's office.\"\n\nFortson entered active duty in 2019. He was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron and stationed at Hurlburt Field.\n\nThe sheriff's office announced the deputy involved was immediately placed on administrative leave and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement has taken over the investigation. He was a patriot.\"\n\nAccording to Hurlburt Field, Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron and entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nCrump said there was no disturbance at Fortson's apartment; therefore, they believe deputies had come to the wrong apartment.\n\nFortson's girlfriend was on Facetime with him at the time of the shooting.\n\n\"She talked about how she heard a bang at the door, an aggressive bang, and she talked about how he said, 'Who is it?' and he heard no response,\" said Crump. \"She talked about how he went to the door to look through the peephole, but it was as if somebody was covering up the peephole so he couldn't see out of it.\"\n\nCrump continued by saying that the girlfriend heard Fortson continue to say, \"Who is it,\" and went to retrieve his gun to protect himself. "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13401725/Roger-Fortson-airman-shot-bodycam-footage.html", "title": "Harrowing moment cops shoot dead decorated airman, 23", "body": "A woman said she witnessed his killed by cops while they were on FaceTime\n\nBodycam footage of the moment a 23-year-old airman was killed at his home after police allegedly forced their way into the wrong apartment and shot him has now been released.\n\nUS Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was identified as the young man shot dead in a shooting last Friday afternoon.\n\nHarrowing footage shows the moments leading up to the deadly shooting as a resident of the apartment complex describes a disturbance to law enforcement officers as she leads them through the building.\n\nThe law enforcement officer confirmed with the woman that he was going to the fourth floor before riding the elevator up to Fortson's off-base residence at an apartment complex on 319 Racetrack Road in Okaloosa County, Florida.\n\nBodycam footage of the moment a 23-year-old airman was killed at his home after police allegedly forced their way into the wrong apartment and shot him has now been released\n\n'\n\nWhen Fortson opened his front door, the officer fired six rapid shots that sent the 23-year-old stumbling to the ground.\n\nA Okaloosa County deputy was responding to report of a disturbance and 'reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun,' cops say.\n\nA witness, who was on FaceTime with Fortson during the time of the shooting, claimed Fortson heard a knock at the door and asked who was there.\n\nU.S. Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was identified as the young man shot dead in a shooting last Friday afternoon\n\nThe black airman (pictured) was killed in his Florida apartment after police forced their way into the wrong apartment and shot him as his horrified friend watched on FaceTime\n\nWhen he did not receive a response but heard another 'very aggressive knock,' Fortson peered through the peephole - but did not see anyone and grew concerned.\n\nOut of concern, Fortson retrieved a gun - which he owned legally, according to the witness.\n\nWhen he returned to his living room with the gun, authorities allegedly pushed through his door and shot him six times.\n\nThe traumatized witness, who remained on the FaceTime call for the duration of the horrifying shooting, recalled that Fortson said 'I can't breathe,' after the shots were fired. Fortson later died at the hospital.\n\nThe deputy involved in the incident has since been placed on administrative leave while the shooting continues to be investigated.\n\nThe 23-year old was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida. He entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019\n\nHe was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe terrible incident took place at Fortson's off-base residence - an apartment complex on 319 Racetrack Road in Okaloosa County, Florida\n\nFortson (pictured on the left) was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator after entering active duty on Nov. 19, 2019\n\nThe Air Force's 1st Special Operations Wing said its priorities are 'providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted.'\n\nFortson's mother, Meka Fortson, said that it had always been a dream of her son to service his country and that he had wanted to become a pilot.\n\n'It's a disbelief. Every day, I try to go to sleep early to wake up like it's a dream,' she told Military.com.\n\n'He just came back from deployment from fighting for us. With everything we got going on in our country, he's fighting for us and he came back to be murdered, slain like that so violently.'\n\n'He was my gift, and they took my gift away,' Roger's mother said. 'And they didn't give it to me. God gave me that gift ... and they took my gift away.'\n\nA similar incident happened involving the same sheriff's office back in November - in which the officer shot an unarmed and handcuffed man after he mistook the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot, according to The Washington Post.\n\nThe Washington Post's database of fatal police shootings from 2015 to April this year found that police killed the highest number of people on record in 2023.\n\nBlack Americans are killed by police at more than twice the rate of White Americans.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/black-us-airman-killed-police-174606054.html", "title": "Black US airman killed in police 'excessive' use of force: lawyer", "body": "A Black airman in the US Air Force was shot and killed in an \"excessive\" use of force by a Florida sheriff's deputy who burst into the wrong apartment, a lawyer retained by his family said Thursday.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump, who has represented the families of other African American victims of police violence, demanded a full investigation into the May 3 death of Roger Fortson.\n\nSheriff Eric Aden of the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said the deputy was responding to reports of a \"disturbance in progress\" when the shooting occurred.\n\nBut Crump, at a press conference, said \"it wasn't Roger's apartment that had a disturbance.\"\n\n\"He was in his apartment, his sanctuary, his castle, where he had every right to be, and they forcefully entered into his apartment,\" Crump said, in an \"excessive\" use of force.\n\nCrump said the 23-year-old Fortson was on FaceTime with his girlfriend, a nurse, when the shooting took place.\n\nShe \"heard everything,\" starting with an \"aggressive banging\" at the door, he said.\n\n\"She talked about how he said 'Who is it' and he heard no response,\" Crump said, adding that Fortson looked through a peephole but didn't see anyone.\n\n\"He went and retrieved his legally registered gun,\" Crump said, adding that he was walking back when the door opened.\n\n\"And then she said that she just heard shots,\" he said. \"He was shot six times.\"\n\nCrump demanded a transparent investigation to \"do whatever justice will allow for a good man.\"\n\nIn his statement, Aden said a deputy had responded to \"a call of a disturbance in progress where he encountered an armed man.\"\n\n\"The deputy shot the man, who later succumbed to his injuries,\" Aden said, adding that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and state attorney's office would conduct an investigation.\n\nThe United States was rocked by protests in 2020 following the videotaped murder of George Floyd, a Black man, by a white {"uri": "8118210832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:01:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:01:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:48:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13397977/Florida-deputies-fatally-shot-US-airman-burst-wrong-apartment-attorney-says.html", "title": "Florida deputies who fatally shot US airman burst into wrong...", "body": "MIAMI (AP) - Deputies responding to a disturbance call at a Florida apartment complex burst into the wrong unit and fatally shot a Black U.S. Air Force airman who was home alone when they saw he was armed with a gun, an attorney for the man\u00b4s family said Wednesday.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, was in his off-base apartment in Fort Walton Beach when the shooting happened on May 3.\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump said in a statement that Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter.\n\nAccording to Crump, the woman, whom Crump didn\u00b4t identify, said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn\u00b4t get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn\u00b4t see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman\u00b4s account.\n\nThe woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which Crump said was legally owned.\n\nAs Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed and shot him six times, according to Crump\u00b4s statement. The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, \"I can\u00b4t breathe,\" after he was shot, Crump said.\n\nFILE - Civil rights attorney Ben Crump speaks in the Audubon Ballroom, now part of The Malcolm X & Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center, in New York, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2024. (AP Photo/Ted Shaffrey, File)\n\nFortson died at a hospital, officials said. The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn\u00b4t causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump\u00b4s statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger\u00b4s death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger\u00b4s death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff\u00b4s Office didn\u00b4t immediately respond to an email or voicemail from The Associated Press seeking comment about Crump\u00b4s claims. But Sheriff Eric Aden posted a statement on Facebook Wednesday afternoon expressing sadness about the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community\u00b4s patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" Aden said.\n\nThe sheriff\u00b4s office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney\u00b4s Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nFortson\u00b4s death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police offer fatally shot Botham Jean, an unarmed Black man, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was found guilty of murder the following year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson\u00b4s front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump has represented families in both cases as part of his ongoing effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n\"What I\u00b4m trying to do, as much as I can, even sometimes singlehandedly, is increase the value of Black life,\" Crump told The Associated Press in 2021 following the conviction a former Minneapolis officer in the murder of George Floyd.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.\n\n____\n\nAssociated Press reporters Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, and Aaron Morrison in New York contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", {"uri": "8119422078", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:48:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:48:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:48:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://lawandcrime.com/high-profile/i-cant-breathe-airman-alone-in-apartment-and-on-facetime-shot-6-times-by-deputy-who-burst-through-the-door-of-wrong-address-lawyer-alleges/", "title": "Airman alone at home and on FaceTime shot dead by deputy responding to wrong address: Lawyer", "body": "A prominent civil rights lawyer representing the family of a 23-year-old U.S. senior airman shot to death at home in Fort Walton Beach last Friday afternoon is now alleging that Roger Fortson was by himself and on FaceTime when an Okaloosa County, Florida, deputy \"burst through the door\" of the wrong address and shot him six times, killing him.\n\nAttorney Ben Crump announced several demands of law enforcement on Wednesday for transparency about the circumstances of the shooting, citing \"serious questions that demand immediate answers\" in light of an \"alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment\" during their response to a disturbance call.\n\nCrump's law firm said that the witness was a woman on a FaceTime call with Fortson \"during the entire encounter.\"\n\n\"Roger was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked, 'Who is it?' but didn't get a response,\" a press release said of the witness's account. \"A few minutes later, there was a very aggressive knock on the door, but Roger didn't see anyone when he looked out the peephole.\"\n\n\"Concerned, he did what any other law-abiding citizen would do and retrieved his legally-owned gun, but as he was walking back to the living room, police burst through the door. When they saw the gun, they shot roger six times.\"\n\nThe witness, Crump's firm said, recalled hearing a dying Fortson say \"I can't breathe.\"\n\n\"She has also said the police were in the wrong apartment as there was no disturbance in the apartment and he was alone,\" the firm said.\n\nNow, Ben Crump is demanding the release of body cam video to shed light on the lead-up to Fortson's death, as authorities have resisted releasing recordings as a larger investigation ramps up.\n\n\"The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement,\" Crump said.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden, in a statement on the shooting, described Fortson as \"an armed man.\" The deputy that opened fire, who has not been identified, is on leave, and the shooting is under investigation, Aden added.\n\n\"I immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents,\" the sheriff said. \"The State Attorney's Office will also conduct an independent review. At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event.\"\n\nThough the circumstances appear to be different, based on how Crump described the Fortson shooting, it was nonetheless reminiscent of another case, in which Crump represented the family of a Black man who was shot and killed by a police officer who entered the wrong apartment.\n\nAmber Guyger, then a Dallas police officer, was off-duty and returning home from work in September 2018, but Guyger walked up to an apartment door that was not hers. It was 26-year-old Botham Jean's.\n\nThe case established that Guyger, still wearing her uniform, parked her car on the wrong floor of her apartment complex, walked up to Jean's door, ignored telltale signs that the apartment was not hers (such as the floor mat in front of the door that her apartment did not have), pulled her gun, and opened fire wrongly believing Jean, an accountant unwinding at home and eating ice cream, was an intruder.\n\nAfter the shooting, Guyger was heard on 911 audio saying \"I'm f -- ed\" as Jean lay dying.\n\n\"I'm going to lose my job. I thought it was my apartment/ Hey bud. Hey bud. Hey bud. Come on. Oh f -- . I thought it was my apartment,\" she said.\n\nGuyger repeated that last line over and over again.\n\n\"I thought it was my apartment. I thought it was my apartment. I thought it was my apartment. I thought it was my apartment,\" she said. \"Oh my god. I, I, How the f -- did I put the, how did, how did I ... I'm so tired.\"\n\nAt trial, the defense attempted to explain that Guyger was running on \"auto-pilot\" and exhausted from working overtime, but a jury of her peers found her guilty of murder in 2019. That conviction was upheld on appeal.\n\nIt remains to be seen if Florida investigators will find whether the deputy who shot Fortson can credibly raise a self-defense argument, considering that Crump has said Fortson \"legally-owned\" the firearm he \"retrieved\" before his death.\n\nHurlburt Field, the U.S. Air Force base where Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron, said in a statement that it would not be releasing additional information \"at this time.\"\n\n\"The 1st Special Operations Wing's priorities are providing casualty affairs service to the family, supporting the squadron during this tragic time, and ensuring resources are available for all who are impacted,\" the statement said.\n\nThe apartment where Fortson was fatally shot was not located on the base but was miles away.", "source": {"uri": "lawandcrime.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Law & Crime"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement", "type": {"uri": "8119373406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:12:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:12:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:12:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/zacharyfolk/2024/05/09/black-air-force-member-roger-fortson-allegedly-killed-after-deputy-entered-wrong-apartment-heres-what-we-know/", "title": "Black Air Force Member Roger Fortson Allegedly Killed After Deputy Entered Wrong Apartment: Here's What We Know", "body": "Roger Fortson, a 23-year-old black Air Force servicemember, was shot and killed by a Florida sheriff's deputy who entered the wrong apartment, prominent civil rights attorney and Fortson family lawyer Ben Crump alleged in a statement on Wednesday -- however, authorities have released few details about the shooting.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has not commented on Crump's statement, and has not confirmed if the deputy responded to the wrong apartment. The Sheriff's Office did not return a request for comment from Forbes.\n\n\"The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement,\" Crump said in a statement posted on social media.\n\nAccording to Crump, Fortson \"enlisted in the military after graduating from high school with honors and had no criminal record. By all accounts, he was a stellar member of the Air Force and loved by his community.\" He was originally from the Atlanta area, and graduated from McNair High School in DeKalb County, Georgia, local station 11Alive reported. Fortson, a senior airman at the time of his death, entered active duty in November 2019 was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron based out of Hurlburt Field. The unit flies Block 30 AC-130J Ghostrider gunships and is currently supporting Operation Inherent Resolve -- the Pentagon's operation to support regional allies after the defeat of ISIS in Iraq and {"uri": "8118956786", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:35:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:35:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:34:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://blackamericaweb.com/2024/05/08/florida-cop-who-killed-black-air-force-officer-responded-to-wrong-apartment-witness-says-report/", "title": "Florida Cop Who Killed Black Air Force Officer Responded To Wrong Apar", "body": "Black America Web Featured Video CLOSE\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson. | Source: U.S. Air Force\n\nThe Florida police officer who shot and killed a young Black U.S. Air Force officer went to the wrong apartment when responding to a reported disturbance last week, the lawyer representing the Airman's family said on Wednesday.\n\nWhat happened to Roger Fortson?\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump claims a witness was conducting a Facetime video call with Senior Airman Roger Fortson when the unidentified deputy with the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office knocked on the 23-year-old's apartment door on Friday.\n\nMORE: Florida Cop Who Killed Young Black Air Force Officer Is From Same Police Department In 'Acorn' Shooting\n\nCrump said the witness claims that when no one answered Fortson's question of who was knocking, a few minutes later the knocking got \"very aggressive.\" Again, no one answered when asked \"who is it?\" and Fortson, an active member of the U.S. military, armed himself with his legally owned gun.\n\nThat's when the police kicked in Fortson's door, saw he had a gun and shot him six times, the witness claims.\n\nThe witness, only identified as a female, told Crump that she saw and heard Fortson on the ground claiming, \"I can't breathe.\"\n\nFortson was later pronounced dead at a local hospital.\n\nThe witness claims that the officers went to the wrong apartment because there was no disturbance happening while she and Fortson were on the Facetime call.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has been scarce with details of the shooting and would only offer a narrative that the deputy who fired the fatal shots \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nCiting the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, the Associated Press reported that the deputy responded to a vague report of \"a disturbance in progress,\" but it was not immediately clear what that referred to.\n\nThe deputy allegedly fired his gun only after he \"identified himself as law enforcement,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office was careful to say, claiming the reaction was to \"Hearing sounds of a disturbance.\"\n\nCrump, who has been retained by Fortson's family, said in a statement that the \"circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment. The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\"\n\nCrump called for an immediate investigation into the shooting and demanded any bodycam footage recorded during the incident be made available to Fortson's family.\n\n\"We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media,\" Crump added. \"It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home. What we know for sure is that Roger was a dedicated U.S. Airman serving the country and a cherished member of his community. Any attempts to tarnish his character only compound the pain felt by his loved ones.\"\n\nThe deputy who shot and killed Fortson was not identified and placed on administrative leave, according to reports.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office doesn't have a great track record\n\nLast week was far from the first time that the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has been involved in a questionable shooting in recent months.\n\nThere could also be additional scrutiny of this shooting because the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office is the same police department that employed a cop who in November infamously shot at an unarmed and handcuffed Black man after mistaking the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot.\n\nIn that instance, now-former deputy Jesse Hernandez is shown on video shooting at unarmed suspect Marquis Jackson - who was not injured - after an acorn fell onto the roof of the patrol car.\n\nThat prompted Hernandez to yell \"shots fired!\" before he let off some rounds from his own service weapon.\n\nHernandez was allowed to resign gracefully in December while he was under investigation.\n\nIn what could be a sign of things to come from the police shooting and killing Fortson, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office ultimately described Hernandez's actions on that fateful day as \"reasonable\"and cleared him of any wrongdoing.\n\nThe police murder of Botham Jean\n\nFortson's shooting was reminiscent of the 2018 police murder of Botham Jean when off-duty Dallas police officer Amber Guyger mistook his apartment for her own, profiled the Black man in his own home for a burglar of hers and shiot him to death within seconds. Jean, 27, had been eating Ice cream on his sofa when Guyger broke into his apartment and shot him to death.\n\nIn that instance, the Dallas Police Department was accused of trying to criminalize Jean in death by irrelevantly claiming \"a small amount of marijuana\" wa found in the apartment.\n\nSEE ALSO:\n\nRIP Johnny Hollman Sr.: Family Of Church Deacon Tased To Death By Atlanta Cop Welcomes $3.8M Settlement\n\nLight Sentence? The deputy involved was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the incident.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nIn a statement late Tuesday, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the incident and the State Attorney's Office will conduct an independent review. He said the sheriff's office was \"saddened\" by the shooting.\n\nThe police officer who shot Fortson was not immediately identified.\n\nThe lack of details in a shooting that the police are framing as \"self defense\" could generate some suspicion since law enforcement was seemingly not as transparent as they could have been.\n\nIt's also not the first time that the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has been involved in a questionable shooting in recent months.\n\nThere could also be additional scrutiny of this shooting because the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office is the same police department that employed a cop who in November infamously shot at an unarmed and handcuffed Black man after mistaking the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot.\n\nIn that instance, now-former deputy Jesse Hernandez is shown on video shooting at unarmed suspect Marquis Jackson - who was not injured - after an acorn fell onto the roof of the patrol car.\n\nThat prompted Hernandez to yell \"shots fired!\" before he let off some rounds from his own service weapon.\n\nHernandez was allowed to resign gracefully in December while he was under investigation.\n\nIn what could be a sign of things to come from the police shooting and killing Fortson, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office ultimately described Hernandez's actions on that fateful day as \"reasonable\" and cleared him of any wrongdoing.\n\nThis is America.\n\nRIP Johnny Hollman Sr.: Family Of Church Deacon Tased To Death By Atlanta Cop Welcomes $3.8M Settlement\n\nLight Sentence? The deputy involved in the shooting was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nThe woman said Fortson wasn't causing a disturbance during their Facetime call and believes that the deputies must have had the wrong apartment, Crump's statement said.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the statement.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally known attorney based in Tallahassee, Florida. He has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Tyre Nichols and George Floyd.\n\nCrump and Fortson's family plan to speak at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach on Thursday morning.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office said in a statement last week that a deputy responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex reacted in self-defense after encountering an armed man. The office did not offer details on what kind of disturbance deputies were responding to or who called them.\n\nThe sheriff's office also declined to immediately identify the responding deputies or their races. The office did not respond to an email or phone message on Wednesday. Officials said earlier this week that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the local State Attorney's Office will investigate the shooting.\n\nFDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is highly unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles as a member of the squadron's AC-130J Ghostrider aircrew was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons during missions.\n\nThe sheriff's office didn't immediately respond to an email or voicemail seeking comment Wednesday by The Associated Press.\n\nFort Walton Beach is between Panama City Beach and Pensacola in the Florida {"uri": "8118168449", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:57:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:57:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:57:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/civil-rights-attorney-ben-crump-215054413.html", "title": "Civil rights attorney Ben Crump now represents family of slain Hurlburt Field airman", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH -- The family of Roger Fortson, the airman who was killed in a deputy-involved shooting on May 3 in Fort Walton Beach, has retained national civil rights and personal injury attorney Ben Crump to represent them.\n\nAccording to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, authorities were called to Fortson's apartment about 4:30 p.m. May 3 in reference to an apparent disturbance. Once a deputy arrived on the scene, the OCSO said, Fortson allegedly had a gun in his possession and the deputy acted in self-defense.\n\nAccording to a news release from Crump's law office, the encounter played out differently than what the OCSO has been reporting.\n\nAccording to Crump, a witness who was on a Facetime call with Fortson at the time of the shooting said that Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at his door.\n\nFortson asked, \"Who is it?\" and failed to get a response, the release says. A few minutes later, Fortson heard an \"aggressive\" knock, but failed to see anyone once he looked out his peephole.\n\nFortson, concerned for his safety, retrieved his legally owned gun, the release says. As Fortson returned to the living room, the witness said, deputies \"burst through his door.\" When deputies saw the gun, they fired at Fortson six times.\n\nThe witness said he saw Fortson on the ground, stating, \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot. The witness also said police were at the wrong apartment, and there was no disturbance, according to the release.\n\nFortson was taken to a local hospital, where he later died.\n\n\"Roger enlisted in the military after graduating from high school with honors and had no criminal record,\" Crump said in the release. \"By all accounts, he was a stellar member of the Air Force and loved by his community.\"\n\nAccording to the sheriff's office, the deputy in question was placed on paid administrative leave, as is standard in such cases, pending the results of an investigation.\n\nOn Tuesday, Sheriff Eric Aden released a statement about the shooting. He said all members of his agency \"are saddened about the fatal officer-involved shooting over the weekend.\"\n\nAden then reiterated points made in the previous release from his agency, noting that the deputy in question was placed on administrative leave and that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will investigate the shooting.\n\nAden also noted that the State Attorney's Office also will conduct an independent investigation into the shooting.\n\n\"At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,\" said Aden.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said in the release. \"The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\n\nEarlier coverage: A Hurlburt Field airman died following a deputy-involved shooting at an FWB apartment\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" the statement continues. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy. We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media. It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home. What we know for sure is that Roger was a dedicated U.S. Airman serving the country and a cherished member of his community. Any attempts to tarnish his character only compound the pain felt by his loved ones.\n\n\"We demand justice for Roger Fortson. We demand accountability for those responsible for his death. And we stand in solidarity with Roger's family and friends as they navigate this unimaginable loss.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts":
