{"uri": "8119776176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:51:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:51:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:50:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://taskandpurpose.com/news/bodycam-video-roger-fortson/", "title": "Florida sheriff releases graphic video of deputy shooting Air Force special ops flyer", "body": "The encounter in which a Florida sheriff's deputy shot an Air Force AC-130 gunship crewman inside his apartment near Hurlburt Field was a split-second confrontation in which the officer drew and unloaded his pistol at the airman immediately after the special operations airman opened his front door holding a pistol.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson died soon after the May 5 shooting. The Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office released the bodycam footage from the incident Thursday afternoon, soon after allowing Fortson's family to view the footage.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff's Office Sheriff Eric Aden said he met with Fortson's family for the viewing and offered his condolences to them. He also disputed reports the deputy had gone to the wrong apartment or had entered Fortson's apartment without warning.\n\n\"We are aware of a press release and other comments that falsely state our deputy entered the wrong apartment and implied that they burst through the door into Mr. Fortson's residence,\" Aden told reporters during a Thursday news conference. \"Those statements are inaccurate.\"\n\nFrom the video, one key fact previously claimed by the Sheriff's office is clear: Fortson was holding a handgun when he answered the door.\n\nHowever, in the brief moment in which the gun is visible before he falls, Fortson is holding the gun at his side.\n\nThe video also confirms several other claims that had surfaced around the shooting and dispels others.\n\nThe entire violent encounter lasted five seconds, according to the timestamp on the video: Fortson begins to open the door at 4:32:00. The deputy tells him to \"step back\" two seconds later as the door swings open, then immediately draws and fires at least five shots (a lawyer for Fortson's family claimed earlier Thursday that he had been shot six times).\n\nAfter the shots, with Fortson on the ground, the deputy yells for Fortson to \"drop the gun\" and Fortson responds \"it's over there\" and \"I don't have it.\"\n\nThe video ends with the deputy reporting that shots have been fired and requesting emergency medical services come to the scene.\n\nFortson was a Special Missions Aviator assigned to AC-130J gunships under the 4th Special Operations Squadron, 1st Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field, Florida. He entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019.\n\nDefense Secretary Lloyd Austin is following the case \"closely,\" Air Force Maj. Gen. Pat Ryder, a Pentagon spokesman, told reporters on Thursday. The Defense Department offers its thoughts and prayers to Fortson's family.\n\n\"A tragic situation here,\" Ryder said at a Pentagon news conference. \"As I mentioned we're certainly saddened by the loss of our airman. We obviously need the investigation to run its course, don't want to get ahead of that. But we certainly never want to see our airmen or any military member or part of our DoD family be put into a situation like this. {"uri": "8117982917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "19:49:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T19:49:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T19:48:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.military.com/daily-news/2024/05/08/family-of-florida-airman-shot-death-deputies-claims-police-went-wrong-apartment.html", "title": "Family of Florida Airman Shot to Death by Deputies Claims Police Went to Wrong Apartment", "body": "An attorney for the family of a Florida special operations airman who was shot and killed in his home by local police said Wednesday that officers responding to a reported disturbance may have entered the wrong apartment.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, who was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron at Hurlburt Field, was alone in his apartment May 3 when police burst through the door and fatally shot him six times, according to Ben Crump, an attorney representing Fortson's family.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office was responding to a disturbance between a man and woman in the apartment building, and deputies shot Fortson, who was Black, multiple times in the chest, according to police radio communications.\n\nRead Next: With Mounting Opposition, Proposal to Move Guard Units to Space Force Appears Doomed in Congress\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said. \"The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the attorney's claims. The sheriff's office recently came under scrutiny after one of its deputies resigned following an internal investigation last year of an incident in which he fired his weapon multiple times at a detained suspect after mistaking the sound of an acorn hitting the roof of his patrol vehicle as a gunshot, GulfLive.com reported.\n\nFortson lived in an off-base residence, and his special operations squadron at Hurlburt Field in the Florida panhandle flies AC-130J Ghostrider gunships.\n\nCrump said there was no disturbance and that Fortson was home alone on a video call with another person, who reported the airman heard a knock on the door.\n\nFortson, according to the witness, asked, \"Who is it?\" But he didn't receive an answer. After a subsequent \"aggressive\" second knock and seeing no one through the peephole, Fortson grabbed his legally owned gun, Crump detailed.\n\nAs Fortson was walking back to his living room, police entered the apartment and shot him. He reportedly said \"I can't breathe\" while on the ground after being shot, Crump said, repeating a witness account of the event.\n\nPublicly available police radio audio reviewed by Military.com reported a call for a disturbance at an apartment complex at 319 Racetrack Road around 4:30 p.m. local time.\n\n\"Don't have anything further than a male and female; it's all fourth party information from the front desk at the leasing office,\" a deputy said on the radio.\n\nA few minutes later, another deputy called in to report \"shots fired, suspect down,\" and called for emergency medical services.\n\n\"Multiple gunshot wounds to the chest, Black male,\" another deputy chimes in shortly after. Fortson was shot six times, Crump said in his statement.\n\nNo other details, including the circumstances of the disturbance that prompted the local deputies to visit the apartment building, were released. Fortson was taken to an area hospital, where he later died. No officers were harmed in the incident.\n\nFortson joined the Air Force on Nov. 19, 2019, according to a copy of his service record provided to Military.com. He joined as an AC-130J gunner. Crump added that Roger graduated from high school with honors and had no criminal record.\n\nThe deputy involved was not identified in the news release and was \"placed on paid administrative leave\" pending the outcome of an investigation and administrative review, the sheriff's office said.\n\nOn Monday evening, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden released a statement saying the department was \"saddened\" by the incident and calling for further investigation into the shooting.\n\n\"I immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents,\" Aden said. \"The State Attorney's Office will also conduct an independent review. At this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event.\"\n\nThe sheriff's office declined to provide Military.com the original 911 call and the police report into the incident, citing \"the ongoing active investigation\" in an emailed response.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of bodycam video to the family,\" Crump said. \"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy. We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media. {"uri": "8118148916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:34:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:34:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:33:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://newsone.com/5215437/roger-fortson-police-shooting-update/", "title": "Florida Cop Who Killed Black Air Force Officer Responded To Wrong Apar", "body": "NewsOne Featured Video CLOSE\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson. | Source: U.S. Air Force\n\nThe Florida police officer who shot and killed a young Black U.S. Air Force officer went to the wrong apartment when responding to a reported disturbance last week, the lawyer representing the Airman's family said on Wednesday.\n\nWhat happened to Roger Fortson?\n\nCivil rights attorney Ben Crump claims a witness was conducting a Facetime video call with Senior Airman Roger Fortson when the unidentified deputy with the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office knocked on the 23-year-old's apartment door on Friday.\n\nCrump said the witness claims that when no one answered Fortson's question of who was knocking, a few minutes later the knocking got \"very aggressive.\" Again, no one answered when asked \"who is it?\" and Fortson, an active member of the U.S. military, armed himself with his legally owned gun.\n\nThat's when the police kicked in Fortson's door, saw he had a gun and shot him six times, the witness claims.\n\nThe witness, only identified as a female, told Crump that she saw and heard Fortson on the ground claiming, \"I can't breathe.\"\n\nFortson was later pronounced dead at a local hospital.\n\nThe witness claims that the officers went to the wrong apartment because there was no disturbance happening while she and Fortson were on the Facetime call.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has been scarce with details of the shooting and would only offer a narrative that the deputy who fired the fatal shots \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nCiting the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, the Associated Press reported that the deputy responded to a vague report of \"a disturbance in progress,\" but it was not immediately clear what that referred to.\n\nThe deputy allegedly fired his gun only after he \"identified himself as law enforcement,\" the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office was careful to say, claiming the reaction was to \"Hearing sounds of a disturbance.\"\n\nCrump, who has been retained by Fortson's family, said in a statement that the \"circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment. The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\"\n\nCrump called for an immediate investigation into the shooting and demanded any bodycam footage recorded during the incident be made available to Fortson's family.\n\n\"We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media,\" Crump added. \"It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home. What we know for sure is that Roger was a dedicated U.S. Airman serving the country and a cherished member of his community. Any attempts to tarnish his character only compound the pain felt by his loved ones.\"\n\nThe deputy who shot and killed Fortson was not identified and placed on administrative leave, according to reports.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office doesn't have a great track record\n\nLast week was far from the first time that the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has been involved in a questionable shooting in recent months.\n\nThere could also be additional scrutiny of this shooting because the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office is the same police department that employed a cop who in November infamously shot at an unarmed and handcuffed Black man after mistaking the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot.\n\nIn that instance, now-former deputy Jesse Hernandez is shown on video shooting at unarmed suspect Marquis Jackson - who was not injured - after an acorn fell onto the roof of the patrol car.\n\nThat prompted Hernandez to yell \"shots fired!\" before he let off some rounds from his own service weapon.\n\nHernandez was allowed to resign gracefully in December while he was under investigation.\n\nIn what could be a sign of things to come from the police shooting and killing Fortson, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office ultimately described Hernandez's actions on that fateful day as \"reasonable\"and cleared him of any wrongdoing.\n\nThe police murder of Botham Jean\n\nFortson's shooting was reminiscent of the 2018 police murder of Botham Jean when off-duty Dallas police officer Amber Guyger mistook his apartment for her own, profiled the Black man in his own home for a burglar of hers and shiot him to death within seconds. Jean, 27, had been eating Ice cream on his sofa when Guyger broke into his apartment and shot him to death.\n\nIn that instance, the Dallas Police Department was accused of trying to criminalize Jean in death by irrelevantly claiming \"a small amount of marijuana\" wa found in the apartment.\n\nRIP Johnny Hollman Sr.: Family Of Church Deacon Tased To Death By Atlanta Cop Welcomes $3.8M Settlement\n\nLight Sentence? {"uri": "8119825451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:37:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:37:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:36:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/05/09/florida-sheriff-bodycam-footage-u-s-airman-fatally-shot/", "title": "Bodycam Footage Appears To Show US Airman Fatally Shot By Police", "body": "Florida's Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office released bodycam footage Thursday of a police shooting that later resulted in the death of a U.S. airman during a press conference.\n\nThe footage showed a law enforcement deputy responding to an incident of a domestic fight Friday at an apartment complex. A woman told the officer that the apartment where the incident happened was \"1401\" and observed that \"the girl [in the apartment who called] sounded scared...and [that it sounded] like it's getting really out of hand.\" The deputy could be seen approaching an apartment with a plaque that read 1401 and repeatedly knocking on the door.\n\nHe also announced that he was with the sheriff's office and to open the door. When the suspect, who was blurred out, opened the door, he could be seen carrying what appeared to be an object in one hand. The deputy, after requesting the suspect \"step back\", appeared to have noticed the object and started to shoot the man.\n\nThe deputy shouted for the suspect to \"drop the gun\" to which the suspect responded \"It is over there. I don't have it.\" The deputy could be heard reporting the incident and requesting emergency medical services to come to his location.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said in a press release Tuesday that the suspect \"later succumbed to his injuries,\" the deputy involved in the incident was placed on administrative leave and that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement as well as the State Attorney's Office would be conducting a review. (RELATED: REPORT: Wisconsin Police Fatally Shoot Armed Teenager Outside Middle School)\n\nThe deceased was identified as Senior Airman Roger Fortson, CBS News reported. allegedly entered the wrong apartment, allegedly burst into Fortson's apartment when Fortson was armed and allegedly shot him \"six times.\" Fortson, according to Crump's press release, was heard by {"uri": "2024-05-349522850", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:35:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:35:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:22:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/ben-crump-roger-fortson-dead-florida-deputy-shooting-1898574", "title": "Ben Crump hired by family of US Airman killed by Florida sheriff deputy", "body": "The family of a 23-year-old US Airman who was fatally shot by a Florida sheriff's deputy retained prominent civil rights attorney Ben Crump.\n\nRoger Fortson was shot and killed inside his apartment on Friday when an Okaloosa County Sheriff's deputy responding to a disturbance call \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\n\"We demand accountability for those responsible for his death,\" Crump said in an email to Newsweek. \"And we stand in solidarity with Roger's family and friends as they navigate this unimaginable loss.\"\n\nCrump is a nationally recognized trial lawyer best known for leading the legal teams for the families of George Floyd, Trayvon Martin and Breonna Taylor. He also has been involved in environmental justice cases, such as representing the residents of Flint, Mich.\n\nHow the deadly police-involved shooting unfolded\n\nFortson, who was from Atlanta, was at his off-base apartment on Racetrack Road when the shooting happened around 4:30 p.m., according to the Air Force.\n\nA witness who was on Facetime with Fortson during the entire encounter said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door, according to Crump.\n\nThe witness suggested the police were at the wrong apartment since Fortson was alone and there was no disturbance, Crump said.\n\nFortson allegedly asked, \"Who is it?\" but did not receive a response.\n\n\"A few minutes later, there was a very aggressive knock on the door, but Roger didn't see anyone when he looked out the peephole,\" Crump said. \"Concerned, he did what any other law-abiding citizen would do and retrieved his legally owned gun, but as he was walking back to the living room, police burst through the door.\"\n\nFortson was shot six times, according to Crump. The witness said she saw him on the ground saying, \"I can't breathe.\"\n\nFortson was taken to the hospital, where he died.\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment,\" Crump said. \"The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\"\n\n'Calling for transparency'\n\nThe deputy was placed on administrative leave, \"pending the outcome of a formal investigation and administrative review,\" according to the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office.\n\n\"We are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family,\" Crump said.\n\nNewsweek requested body camera footage from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Department but was told \"due to this being an open/active investigation currently, BWC videos are unavailable for release.\" The department also denied a request to release the affidavit.\n\n\"His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy,\" Crump said. \"We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media. It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home.\"\n\nWho was Roger Fortson?\n\nFortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron at Hurlburt Field, Fla., according to the Air Force. He entered active duty on Nov. 19, 2019. He enrolled after graduating from high school in Atlanta with honors.\n\nHe had no criminal record, according to Crump.\n\nDozens of heartfelt messages on Facebook have called him a \"phenomenal human\" who \"always had a smile on his face.\"\n\n\"What we know for sure is that Roger was a dedicated U.S. Airman serving the country and a cherished member of his community,\" Crump said. \"Any Attorneys for Fortson's family had asked that the footage be released to the public.\n\nIt was released by Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden during a press conference.\n\nThe footage opens with a Sheriff's deputy arriving on the scene and being directed to Fortson's apartment by bystanders. The deputy repeatedly knocks on the door, twice saying, \"Sheriff's office. Open the door\" before it is opened by Fortson.\n\nAs the door opens, the deputy says \"step back\" before quickly firing off five shots. \"Drop the gun,\" he says. An object that may have been a firearm appears in the man's right hand, but the footage is blurry.\n\n\"It's over there. I don't have it,\" Fortson says as he lies on the ground after apparently being shot.\n\n\"It pains me to show the video, but I know you all need to see it,\" Aden, the county sheriff, said during a news conference.\n\nFortson died in a local hospital while being treated for the injuries he sustained.\n\nAden said in a previous statement that the deputy was responding \"to a call of a disturbance in progress where he encountered an armed man.\"\n\nThe Florida Department of Investigation is carrying out a criminal investigation of the shooting, and the state attorney's office will conduct a final review thereafter, authorities said.\n\n\"We know you have many questions, as do we. {"uri": "8118107817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:51:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:51:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:50:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.fox10tv.com/2024/05/08/family-us-airman-killed-by-okaloosa-deputy-working-with-attorney/", "title": "Family of U.S. Airman killed by Okaloosa deputy working with attorney", "body": "OKALOOSA COUNTY, Fla. (WJHG/WECP) - Civil rights and personal injury attorney Ben Crump has been retained by the family of Roger Fortson, a 23-year-old active-duty Senior Airman who was fatally shot by an Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office Deputy on Friday, May 4.\n\nAccording to the Associated Press Fortson was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. In a statement released by the U.S. Air Force, they say he died at his off-base residence.\n\nOn Friday, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office reported a deputy responded to a disturbance call in which they said the deputy encountered an armed man.\n\nTheir full statement regarding the incident is below:\n\n\"All of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer-involved shooting over the weekend.\n\nLate Friday afternoon, our deputy responded to a call of a disturbance in progress where he encountered an armed man. The deputy shot the man, who later succumbed to his injuries.\n\nI immediately placed the deputy on administrative leave and have asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation that is required in such incidents.\n\nThe State Attorney's Office will also conduct an independent review.\n\nAt this time, we humbly ask for our community's patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event.\"\n\nAccording to a witness who was on Facetime with Roger during the encounter, he was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door.\n\nHe reportedly asked, 'Who is it?' but did not get a response. According to Attorney Crump's office, Roger heard another aggressive knock but did not see anyone when he looked inside the peephole.\n\nThose representing the family said that Roger was concerned and had grabbed his legally owned gun but as he was walking back to the living room law enforcement busted through the door.\n\nWhen they saw the gun they reportedly shot Roger six times. The witness stated she saw Roger on the ground stating \"I can't breathe,\" after he was shot.\n\nThe witness also said the police were in the wrong apartment and there was no disturbance in the apartment Roger was in.\n\nAccording to Crump's office, Roger enlisted in the military after graduating from high school with honors and had no criminal record.\n\nThe following is a statement from Attorney Ben Crump:\n\n\"The circumstances surrounding Roger's death raise serious questions that demand immediate answers from authorities, especially considering the alarming witness statement that the police entered the wrong apartment. The narrative released by law enforcement, which falsely suggests that Roger posed a threat, is deeply troubling and inconsistent with the details provided by that witness: Roger was home alone, causing no disturbance, when his life was tragically cut short by law enforcement.\n\nWe are calling for transparency in the investigation into Roger's death and the immediate release of body cam video to the family. His family and the public deserve to know what occurred in the moments leading up to this tragedy. We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media. It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home. What we know for sure is that Roger was a dedicated U.S. Airman serving the country and a cherished member of his community. Any attempts to tarnish his character only compound the pain felt by his loved ones.", "source": {"uri": "fox10tv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX10 News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119836921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:50:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:50:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:49:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.theadvocate.com/video-shows-florida-deputy-announced-himself-prior-to-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman/article_e5611cc7-4d05-5a6d-b1db-a282e27048c3.html", "title": "Video shows Florida deputy announced himself prior to fatal shooting of Black airman", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense. Aden rejected assertions made by civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, that the deputy had gone to the wrong apartment, covered the door's peephole and did not announce himself.\n\nThe video shows the deputy arriving at a Fort Walton Beach apartment building on May 3 and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nThe video shows the deputy banging on the door and stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office! Open the door!\"\n\nFortson opened the door and could be seen holding what appeared to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" and fired off shots. He then shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun!\"\n\n\"It's over there,\" Fortson said.\n\n\"Drop the gun!\" the deputy yelled back.\n\n\"I don't have it,\" Fortson said, lying on the ground.\n\nThe deputy then called paramedics on his radio.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputy or his race. The deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump released a statement later noting that the officer did not tell Roger to drop his gun before shooting \"multiple times within a split second of the door being opened.\"\n\n\"We remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment,\" the statement said.\n\nCrump also told reporters earlier that Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime and that he grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment. He said that the deputy burst into the apartment, citing the account of the girlfriend, who has not yet been identified.\n\n\"The girlfriend acknowledges that even though she initially thought the door was forced open by the police that she stands by her emotional recollection of what happened,\" Crump's later statement said.\n\nAden said he had met with the family before showing the video to reporters and extended his deepest condolences.\n\n\"This result is one we never hope to encounter,\" Aden said. \"These investigations take time, but I want to assure you that we are not hiding or attempting to cover anything up.\"\n\nOfficials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating. FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nThe sheriff said the probe was being handled as a criminal investigation and that no determination had yet been made on whether the deputy's actions were justified or not. However, the initial news release from the sheriff's office that described the shooting said that the deputy \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times.\n\nHe said Fortson had always wanted to join the U.S. Air Force and enlisted after graduating high school. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile law enforcement shooting cases involving Black people, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes, in circumstances that involved officers responding to the wrong address or responding to service calls with wanton uses of deadly force.\n\nIn 2018, a white former Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white former Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\nThe spelling of the name of Fortson's mother has been corrected to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki.", "source": {"uri": "theadvocate.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Advocate"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@theadvocate.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheriff", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sheriff"}}, {"uri": {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119839134", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:53:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:53:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:52:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/killing-of-an-airman-by-florida-deputy-is-among-cases-of-black-people-being-shot-in-their-homes", "title": "Killing of an airman by Florida deputy is among cases of Black people being shot in their homes", "body": "If you are a Home delivery print subscriber, unlimited online access is included in your subscription. Crump said Fortson grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\nOn the body camera video, the deputy can be heard yelling that he was from the sheriff's department and knocking, while also stepping seemingly out of view of the door. The video then shows Fortson opening the door with what appears to be a gun in his hand pointed toward the ground.\n\nThe deputy quickly fires several shots, yelling for Fortson to drop the gun after he is already on the ground wounded.\n\nBotham Jean, an 26-year-old Black man, was fatally shot in 2018 by a white police officer who mistook his Dallas apartment for her own.\n\nAmber Guyger was still in uniform after a long shift when she walked up to Jean's apartment -- which was on the fourth floor, directly above hers on the third -- and found the door unlocked.\n\nJean, an accountant from the Caribbean island nation of St. Lucia, had been eating a bowl of ice cream when Guyger entered his home and shot him. {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119840059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:54:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:54:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:53:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/nation-world/story/2024-05-09/killing-of-an-airman-by-florida-deputy-is-among-cases-of-black-people-being-shot-in-their-homes", "title": "Killing of an airman by Florida deputy is among cases of Black people being shot in their homes", "body": "The fatal shooting of a U.S. Air Force airman at his off-base apartment in the Florida Panhandle by a sheriff's deputy brings to mind other instances of Black people being killed by law enforcement in their own homes as they're going about their day.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was killed on May 3 in his apartment in Fort Walton Beach. Body camera video shown to reporters Thursday shows the deputy going to Fortson's door after speaking to a woman who described hearing an argument.\n\nAttorney Ben Crump, who has been hired by Fortson's family, has said Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime when the deputy arrived. Crump said Fortson grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\nOn the body camera video, the deputy can be heard yelling that he was from the sheriff's department and knocking, while also stepping seemingly out of view of the door. The video then shows Fortson opening the door with what appears to be a gun in his hand pointed toward the ground.\n\nThe deputy quickly fires several shots, yelling for Fortson to drop the gun after he is already on the ground wounded.\n\nAmber Guyger was still in uniform after a long shift when she walked up to Jean's apartment -- which was on the fourth floor, directly above hers on the third -- and found the door unlocked.\n\nJean, an accountant from the Caribbean island nation of St. Lucia, had been eating a bowl of ice cream when Guyger entered his home and shot him. He was unarmed.\n\nGuyger, the now-former officer, was found guilty in 2019 and sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nAtatiana Jefferson, a 28-year-old Black woman, was fatally shot through a window in her home in 2019 by Aaron Dean, a white officer, as he responded to a nonemergency call about the door to her Fort Worth, Texas, home being open.\n\nBody camera footage showed that Dean and a second officer didn't identify themselves as police at the house. Both testified at Dean's trial that they thought the house might have been burglarized and quietly moved into the fenced-off backyard looking for signs of forced entry.\n\nJefferson and her then-8-year-old nephew, Zion Carr, were up late playing video games. They'd left doors open to vent smoke after earlier burning hamburgers.\n\nZion testified that Jefferson took out her gun because she believed there was an intruder in the backyard. Dean fired a single shot through the window a split-second after shouting at Jefferson, who was inside, to show her hands.\n\nDean was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and the former officer was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nAiyana Stanley-Jones, 7, was fatally shot inside her family's Detroit home in 2010 by police who burst into the wrong unit of a duplex while looking for a man suspected in a killing that had been committed days earlier. The suspect was eventually arrested in the second-floor unit of the duplex.\n\nAiyana, who was Black, was shot in the head while sleeping on a couch.\n\nJoseph Weekley, a member of an elite police unit, was the first officer through the door of her home. Weekley, who is white, said he accidentally fired his gun during a struggle with Aiyana's grandmother.\n\nWeekley was charged with involuntary manslaughter but his first trial ended without a verdict in 2013 and his second ended in 2015 with a hung jury. During the second trial, a judge dismissed that charge.\n\nBreonna Taylor, a 26-year-old black woman, was killed by police officers who knocked down the door to her apartment in Louisville, Kentucky, in 2020 while executing a drug search warrant that was later found to be flawed.\n\nTaylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, fired a single shot that hit one of the officers as they came through the door of the apartment, and officers returned fire, striking Taylor in the apartment hallway multiple times.\n\nWalker told police investigators that he heard knocking but did not hear police announce themselves. He said he was \"scared to death,\" so he grabbed his gun and when the door was knocked down, he fired a shot.\n\nOfficers found no drugs in Taylor's apartment.\n\nFormer Louisville officer Brett Hankison, who fired 10 shots into Taylor's window and glass door, was found not guilty in 2022 on state charges that he endangered her neighbors when he opened fire. Some of his shots flew into a neighboring apartment, but none of them struck anyone.\n\nLast year a jury deadlocked over federal civil rights charges that Hankison used excessive force that night. Federal prosecutors have said they intend to retry him.\n\nThree other former officers involved in drawing up the warrant were charged in a separate federal case. One of them, Kelly Goodlett, has pleaded guilty to helping falsify the warrant. She's expected to testify against the other two in the upcoming trial.", "source": {"uri": "sandiegouniontribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "San Diego Union-Tribune"}, "authors": [], {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119837293", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:58:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:58:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:50:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/killing-airman-florida-deputy-among-214632823.html", "title": "Killing of an airman by Florida deputy is among cases of Black people being shot in their homes", "body": "The fatal shooting of a U.S. Air Force airman at his off-base apartment in the Florida Panhandle by a sheriff's deputy brings to mind other instances of Black people being killed by law enforcement in their own homes as they're going about their day.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was killed on May 3 in his apartment in Fort Walton Beach. Body camera video shown to reporters Thursday shows the deputy going to Fortson's door after speaking to a woman who described hearing an argument.\n\nAttorney Ben Crump, who has been hired by Fortson's family, has said Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime when the deputy arrived. Crump said Fortson grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment, got no response when he asked who was there and discovered the peephole on his door was blocked.\n\nOn the body camera video, the deputy can be heard yelling that he was from the sheriff's department and knocking, while also stepping seemingly out of view of the door. The video then shows Fortson opening the door with what appears to be a gun in his hand pointed toward the ground.\n\nThe deputy quickly fires several shots, yelling for Fortson to drop the gun after he is already on the ground wounded.\n\nAmber Guyger was still in uniform after a long shift when she walked up to Jean's apartment -- which was on the fourth floor, directly above hers on the third -- and found the door unlocked.\n\nJean, an accountant from the Caribbean island nation of St. Lucia, had been eating a bowl of ice cream when Guyger entered his home and shot him. He was unarmed.\n\nAtatiana Jefferson, a 28-year-old Black woman, was fatally shot through a window in her home in 2019 by Aaron Dean, a white officer, as he responded to a nonemergency call about the door to her Fort Worth, Texas, home being open.\n\nBody camera footage showed that Dean and a second officer didn't identify themselves as police at the house. Both testified at Dean's trial that they thought the house might have been burglarized and quietly moved into the fenced-off backyard looking for signs of forced entry.\n\nJefferson and her then-8-year-old nephew, Zion Carr, were up late playing video games. They'd left doors open to vent smoke after earlier burning hamburgers.\n\nZion testified that Jefferson took out her gun because she believed there was an intruder in the backyard. Dean fired a single shot through the window a split-second after shouting at Jefferson, who was inside, to show her hands.\n\nAiyana Stanley-Jones, 7, was fatally shot inside her family's Detroit home in 2010 by police who burst into the wrong unit of a duplex while looking for a man suspected in a killing that had been committed days earlier. The suspect was eventually arrested in the second-floor unit of the duplex.\n\nAiyana, who was Black, was shot in the head while sleeping on a couch.\n\nJoseph Weekley, a member of an elite police unit, was the first officer through the door of her home. Weekley, who is white, said he accidentally fired his gun during a struggle with Aiyana's grandmother.\n\nWeekley was charged with involuntary manslaughter but his first trial ended without a verdict in 2013 and his second ended in 2015 with a hung jury. During the second trial, a judge dismissed that charge.\n\nBREONNA TAYLOR\n\nBreonna Taylor, a 26-year-old black woman, was killed by police officers who knocked down the door to her apartment in Louisville, Kentucky, in 2020 while executing a drug search warrant that was later found to be flawed.\n\nTaylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, fired a single shot that hit one of the officers as they came through the door of the apartment, and officers returned fire, striking Taylor in the apartment hallway multiple times.\n\nWalker told police investigators that he heard knocking but did not hear police announce themselves. He said he was \"scared to death,\" so he grabbed his gun and when the door was knocked down, he fired a shot.\n\nOfficers found no drugs in Taylor's apartment.\n\nFormer Louisville officer Brett Hankison, who fired 10 shots into Taylor's window and glass door, was found not guilty in 2022 on state charges that he endangered her neighbors when he opened fire. Some of his shots flew into a neighboring apartment, but none of them struck anyone.\n\nLast year a jury deadlocked over federal civil rights charges that Hankison used excessive force that night. Federal prosecutors have said they intend to retry him.\n\nThree other former officers involved in drawing up the warrant were charged in a separate federal case. One of them, Kelly Goodlett, has pleaded guilty to helping falsify the warrant. She's expected to testify against the other two in the upcoming trial.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Authorities responded to a complaint of noise at Fortson's Okaloosa County, Florida, apartment complex.", "source": {"uri": "timesnownews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TimesNow"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Okaloosa_County,_Florida", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Okaloosa County, Florida"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Okaloosa County, Florida"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legislator", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Legislator"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads_and_Highways/Construction_and_Planning", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads and Highways/Construction and Planning", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Softball/Modified_Pitch", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Softball/Modified Pitch", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://static.tnn.in/thumb/msid-109990330,thumbsize-16872,width-1280,height-720,resizemode-75/109990330.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9546267", "eventUri": "eng-9546267", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-10", "textStart": 316, "textEnd": 324}], "sentiment": -0.1764705882352942, "wgt": 452988273, "relevance": 2}], "totalResults": 164, "page": 1, "count": 1, "pages": 164}}}
{"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119850890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:05:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:05:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:05:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://newsone.com/5217801/roger-fortson-bodycam-video/", "title": "Roger Fortson Bodycam Video Contradicts Claim Of 'Self Defense' In", "body": "NewsOne Featured Video CLOSE\n\nU.S. Air Force Senior Airman Rogert Fortson. | Source: U.S. Air Force\n\nThe family of a U.S. Air Force officer who was shot and killed last week by a police officer in Florida claims the bodycam footage from the deadly incident contradicts the initial police narrative and leaves more questions than answers.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office on Thursday released the video footage to the family of U.S. Air Force Senior Airman Rogert Fortson, who was killed in his own home last Friday. The police claim the deputy responded to a reported \"disturbance,\" but a witness claims the police showed up at the wrong address before shooting Fortson six times.\n\nWhat happened to Roger Fortson?\n\nInitial reports provided by the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office claimed the deputy acted out of \"self defense\" because Fortson was armed with a gun. The Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office also said the deputy opened fire only after he \"identified himself as law enforcement.\"\n\nBut Fortson's family suggested in a statement after watching the bodycam video of the shooting that those claims were not entirely true.\n\n\"In the four-and-a-half minute, heavily redacted video, it is very troubling that the deputy gave no verbal commands and shot multiple times within a split second of the door being opened, killing Roger,\" the family said in a statement shared with NewsOne. \"Despite the redactions, the video has provided some answers, but it's also raised even more troubling questions: As the officer didn't tell Roger to drop the weapon before shooting, was the officer trained to give verbal warnings? Did the officer try to initiate life-saving measures? Was the officer trained to deal with law-abiding citizens who are registered gun owners?\"\n\nThe fateful Facetime call\n\nFortson was on a Facetime call with his girlfriend at the time of the shooting, according to civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing the Airman's family. The unidentified deputy knocked on Fortson's apartment door, but didn't answer when asked who was knocking, Crump said. Fortson's girlfriend said a few minutes later the knocking got \"very aggressive,\" according to Crump. Again, no one answered when asked \"who is it?\" and Fortson, an active member of the U.S. military and possibly suspecting a burglar, armed himself with his legally owned gun.\n\nThat's when the police kicked in Fortson's door, saw he had a gun and shot him six times, Crump said.\n\nFortson's girlfriend said she saw and heard Fortson on the ground claiming, \"I can't breathe,\" according to Crump.\n\nCrump said Fortson's girlfriend claimed that the officers went to the wrong apartment because there was no disturbance happening while she and Fortson were on the Facetime call.\n\nFortson was later pronounced dead at a local hospital.\n\n\"The girlfriend acknowledges that even though she initially thought the door was forced open by the police that she stands by her emotional recollection of what happened,\" Fortson's family continued while sharing nearly four-minute long video footage from the Facetime call. The video, which is graphic and should be viewed with discretion, can be watched by clicking here.\n\nFortson's family added that they \"remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment.\"\n\nCrump has called for an immediate investigation into the shooting and suggested the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office was trying to assassinate Fortson's character in death.\n\n\"We urge authorities to immediately stop demonizing Roger in their statements to the media,\" Crump previously said. \"It's imperative to correct the record and acknowledge the wrongful entry into Roger's home. What we know for sure is that Roger was a dedicated U.S. Airman serving the country and a cherished member of his community. Any attempts to tarnish his character only compound the pain felt by his loved ones.\"\n\nThe deputy who shot and killed Fortson was not identified and placed on administrative leave, according to reports.\n\nRoger Fortson bodycam video\n\nNBC News has obtained the bodycam video:\n\nThe video shows the deputy arriving on scene and being directed to apartment 1401 by a woman whose face is blurred. The woman tells him that someone had overheard arguing there.\n\nThe video shows the deputy knocking and twice saying, \"Sheriff's office. Open the door.\"\n\nWhen Fortson opens the door, he appears to be holding a gun that is facing downward. The deputy says, \"Step back\" and fires his weapon multiple times. Fortson falls to the floor. The deputy twice yells, \"Drop the gun,\" to which Fortson replies, \"It's over there.\"\n\nThe deputy then calls for medical assistance.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office doesn't have a great track record\n\nLast week was far from the first time that the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has been involved in a questionable shooting in recent months.\n\nThere could also be additional scrutiny of this shooting because the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office is the same police department that employed a cop who in November infamously shot at an unarmed and handcuffed Black man after mistaking the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot.\n\nIn that instance, now-former deputy Jesse Hernandez is shown on video shooting at unarmed suspect Marquis Jackson - who was not injured - after an acorn fell onto the roof of the patrol car.\n\nThat prompted Hernandez to yell \"shots fired!\" before he let off some rounds from his own service weapon.\n\nHernandez was allowed to resign gracefully in December while he was under investigation.\n\nIn what could be a sign of things to come from the police shooting and killing Fortson, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office ultimately described Hernandez's actions on that fateful day as \"reasonable\"and cleared him of any wrongdoing.\n\nSimilarities to the police murder of Botham Jean\n\nFortson's shooting was reminiscent of the 2018 police murder of Botham Jean when off-duty Dallas police officer Amber Guyger mistook his apartment for her own, profiled the Black man in his own home for a burglar of hers and shot him to death within seconds. Jean, 27, had been eating Ice cream on his sofa when Guyger broke into his apartment and shot him to death.\n\nIn that instance, the Dallas Police Department was accused of trying to criminalize Jean in death by irrelevantly claiming \"a small amount of marijuana\" was found in the apartment.\n\nRIP Johnny Hollman Sr.: Family Of Church Deacon Tased To Death By Atlanta Cop Welcomes $3.8M Settlement\n\nLight Sentence? KKK Flag-Flying White Supremacist Who Terrorized Black, Brown People Gets 41 Months\n\n147 Black Men And Boys Killed By Police 146 photos\n\nRELATED TAGS\n\nbodycam footage Facetime fatal police shooting Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office Roger Fortson", "source": {"uri": "newsone.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News One"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Open the door.\"\n\nWhen Fortson opens the door, he appears to be holding a gun that is facing downward. The deputy says, \"Step back\" and fires his weapon multiple times. Fortson falls to the floor. The deputy twice yells, \"Drop the gun,\" to which Fortson replies, \"It's over there.\"\n\nThe deputy then calls for medical assistance.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office doesn't have a great track record\n\nLast week was far from the first time that the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has been involved in a questionable shooting in recent months.\n\nThere could also be additional scrutiny of this shooting because the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office is the same police department that employed a cop who in November infamously shot at an unarmed and handcuffed Black man after mistaking the sound of a falling acorn for a gunshot.\n\nIn that instance, now-former deputy Jesse Hernandez is shown on video shooting at unarmed suspect Marquis Jackson - who was not injured - after an acorn fell onto the roof of the patrol car.\n\nThat prompted Hernandez to yell \"shots fired!\" before he let off some rounds from his own service weapon.\n\nHernandez was allowed to resign gracefully in December while he was under investigation.\n\nIn what could be a sign of things to come from the police shooting and killing Fortson, the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office ultimately described Hernandez's actions on that fateful day as \"reasonable\"and cleared him of any wrongdoing.\n\nSimilarities to the police murder of Botham Jean\n\nFortson's shooting was reminiscent of the 2018 police murder of Botham Jean when off-duty Dallas police officer Amber Guyger mistook his apartment for her own, profiled the Black man in his own home for a burglar of hers and shot him to death within seconds. Jean, 27, had been eating Ice cream on his sofa when Guyger broke into his apartment and shot him to death.\n\nIn that instance, the Dallas Police Department was accused of trying to criminalize Jean in death by irrelevantly claiming \"a small amount of marijuana\" was found in the apartment.\n\nRIP Johnny Hollman Sr.: Family Of Church Deacon Tased To Death By Atlanta Cop Welcomes $3.8M Settlement\n\nLight Sentence? KKK Flag-Flying White Supremacist Who Terrorized Black, Brown People Gets 41 Months\n\n147 Black Men And Boys Killed By Police 146 photos\n\nRELATED TAGS\n\nbodycam footage Facetime fatal police shooting Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office Roger Fortson", "source": {"uri": "newsone.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News One"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_camera", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Body camera"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119883860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:43:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:43:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:42:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/05/09/body-camera-video-shows-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman-by-florida-deputy-in-apartment-doorway/", "title": "Body camera video shows fatal shooting of Black airman by Florida deputy in apartment doorway", "body": "By STEPHEN SMITH and MIKE SCHNEIDER (Associated Press)\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense. Aden rejected assertions made by civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, that the deputy had gone to the wrong apartment, covered the door's peephole and did not announce himself.\n\nThe video shows the deputy arriving at a Fort Walton Beach apartment building on May 3 and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nThe video shows the deputy banging on the door and stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office! Open the door!\"\n\nFortson opened the door and could be seen holding what appeared to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" and fired off shots. He then shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun!\"\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputy or his race. The deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump released a statement later noting that the officer did not tell Fortson to drop his gun before shooting \"multiple times within a split second of the door being opened.\"\n\n\"We remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment,\" the statement said.\n\nCrump also told reporters earlier that Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime and that he grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment. He said that the deputy burst into the apartment, citing the account of the girlfriend, who has not yet been identified.\n\n\"The girlfriend acknowledges that even though she initially thought the door was forced open by the police that she stands by her emotional recollection of what happened,\" Crump's later statement said.\n\nIn a clip from the FaceTime video captured by Fortson's cellphone, the airman can be heard groaning and saying, \"I can't breathe.\" A deputy can be heard yelling back at him, \"Stop moving!\" The phone is pointed at the ceiling and does not show what is going on in the apartment.\n\nAden said he had met with the family Thursday and extended his deepest condolences.\n\n\"This result is one we never hope to encounter,\" Aden said. \"These investigations take time, but I want to assure you that we are not hiding or attempting to cover anything up.\"\n\nOfficials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating. FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nThe sheriff said the probe was being handled as a criminal investigation and that no determination had yet been made on whether the deputy's actions were justified or not. However, the initial news release from the sheriff's office that described the shooting said that the deputy \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times.\n\nFortson enlisted in the Air Force after graduating high school, Crump said. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile cases of Black people in fatal encounters with law enforcement and vigilantes, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes.\n\nIn 2018, a white Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nThis story has been updated to correct the spelling of the name of Fortson's mother to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki and to reflect that some of the cases Crump has been involved with were encounters with vigilantes, not just law enforcement.", "source": {"uri": "delcotimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Delaware County Daily {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119886258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:46:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:46:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:46:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/09/body-camera-video-shows-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman-by-florida-deputy-in-apartment-doorway/", "title": "Body camera video shows fatal shooting of Black airman by Florida deputy in apartment doorway", "body": "Chantimekki Fortson, mother of Roger Fortson, holds a photo of her son during a news conference Thursday in Fort Walton Beach, Fla. Fortson was shot and killed by police in his apartment on May 3. Gerald Herbert/Associated Press\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense. Aden rejected assertions made by civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, that the deputy had gone to the wrong apartment, covered the door's peephole and did not announce himself.\n\nThe video shows the deputy arriving at a Fort Walton Beach apartment building on May 3 and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nThe video shows the deputy banging on the door and stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice, he shouted: \"Sheriff's office! Open the door!\"\n\nFortson opened the door and could be seen holding what appeared to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" and opened fire. He then shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun!\"\n\n\"It's over there,\" Fortson said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Drop the gun!\" the deputy yelled back.\n\n\"I don't have it,\" Fortson said, lying on the ground.\n\nThe deputy then called paramedics on his radio.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputy or his race. The deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump released a statement later noting that the officer did not tell Fortson to drop his gun before shooting \"multiple times within a split second of the door being opened.\"\n\n\"We remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment,\" the statement said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCrump also told reporters earlier that Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime and that he grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment. He said that the deputy burst into the apartment, citing the account of the girlfriend, who has not yet been identified.\n\n\"The girlfriend acknowledges that even though she initially thought the door was forced open by the police that she stands by her emotional recollection of what happened,\" Crump's later statement said.\n\nIn a clip from the FaceTime video captured by Fortson's cellphone, the airman can be heard groaning and saying, \"I can't breathe.\" A deputy can be heard yelling back at him, \"Stop moving!\" The phone is pointed at the ceiling and does not show what is going on in the apartment.\n\nAden said he had met with the family Thursday and extended his deepest condolences.\n\n\"This result is one we never hope to encounter,\" Aden said. \"These investigations take time, but I want to assure you that we are not hiding or attempting to cover anything up.\"\n\nOfficials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating. FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe sheriff said the probe was being handled as a criminal investigation and that no determination had yet been made on whether the deputy's actions were justified or not. However, the initial news release from the sheriff's office that described the shooting said that the deputy \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFortson enlisted in the Air Force after graduating high school, Crump said. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile cases of Black people in fatal encounters with law enforcement and vigilantes, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes.\n\nIn 2018, a white Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" Previous\n\nStates with abortion bans saw greater drops in medical school graduates applying for residencies Related Stories Latest Articles", "source": {"uri": "pressherald.com", (WALA) -This body camera video from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office shows what led up to the deputy involved shooting death of 23-year-old Senior Airman Roger Fortson. His mother Meka Fortson says her son was living out his dream of serving in the air force and providing a better life for his family.\n\n\"Roger wanted to show his mama who raised five kids that didn't know what credit was how to have something,\" said Roger's mother Meka Fortson. \"Roger wanted to put his mama in a house.\"\n\nHis family, who is represented by civil rights attorney Ben Crump says Fortson was alone at his apartment last Friday when he heard a loud knock on his door while on facetime with his girlfriend.\n\n\"She talked about how he went to the door to look through the peep hole but it was as if someone was covering up the peep whole so someone couldn't see out of it and he kept saying who is it,\" said civil rights attorney Ben Crump. \"And how he went and retrieved his legally registered gun as a gun owner to protect his house.\"\n\nFortson's mother still emotional while remembering that day.\n\n\"My baby was shot up they took my gift,\" said Fortson.\n\nAfter showing the family the body camera video, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden says he offered condolences to the family but wanted to set the record straight on the facts so far.\n\n\"We are aware of a press release and other comments that falsely state our deputy entered the wrong apartment and implied that they burst through the door into Mr. Fortson's residence,\" said Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden.\n\nOCSO says they were at the complex responding to a disturbance call. In the video the deputy knocks on the door and steps away for several seconds before knocking again and announcing himself twice before the door is opened. In the video Fortson does not appear to raise his gun before the shots were fired.\n\nOCSO says the deputy acted in self-defense after seeing the gun. Meanwhile Fortson's family is asking for the sheriff's office to clear his name which Sheriff Aden promised would happen pending an investigation.\n\n\"I need you to get his reputation right,\" said Fortson. \"I know my son did not do anything to you guys.\"\n\n\"They have my word. If this shooting is found to be unjustified their son's name will be fully vindicated and justice will be served,\" said Sheriff Aden.\n\nSheriff Aden has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to investigate this shooting. FDLE sent us the following statement:\n\n\"At the request of the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) is investigating the deputy-involved shooting that occurred on May 3.\n\nFDLE use-of-force cases are independent, fact-finding investigations. {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119888757", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:50:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:50:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:49:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.fox10tv.com/2024/05/09/ocso-releases-body-cam-video-deadly-deputy-involved-shooting-an-active-duty-senior-airman/", "title": "OCSO releases body cam video of deadly deputy involved shooting of an active duty senior airman", "body": "SHALIMAR, Fla. (WALA) -This body camera video from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office shows what led up to the deputy involved shooting death of 23-year-old Senior Airman Roger Fortson. His mother Meka Fortson says her son was living out his dream of serving in the air force and providing a better life for his family.\n\n\"Roger wanted to show his mama who raised five kids that didn't know what credit was how to have something,\" said Roger's mother Meka Fortson. \"Roger wanted to put his mama in a house.\"\n\nHis family, who is represented by civil rights attorney Ben Crump says Fortson was alone at his apartment last Friday when he heard a loud knock on his door while on facetime with his girlfriend.\n\n\"She talked about how he went to the door to look through the peep hole but it was as if someone was covering up the peep whole so someone couldn't see out of it and he kept saying who is it,\" said civil rights attorney Ben Crump. \"And how he went and retrieved his legally registered gun as a gun owner to protect his house.\"\n\nFortson's mother still emotional while remembering that day.\n\n\"My baby was shot up they took my gift,\" said Fortson.\n\nAfter showing the family the body camera video, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden says he offered condolences to the family but wanted to set the record straight on the facts so far.\n\n\"We are aware of a press release and other comments that falsely state our deputy entered the wrong apartment and implied that they burst through the door into Mr. Fortson's residence,\" said Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden.\n\nOCSO says they were at the complex responding to a disturbance call. In the video the deputy knocks on the door and steps away for several seconds before knocking again and announcing himself twice before the door is opened. In the video Fortson does not appear to raise his gun before the shots were fired.\n\nOCSO says the deputy acted in self-defense after seeing the gun. Meanwhile Fortson's family is asking for the sheriff's office to clear his name which Sheriff Aden promised would happen pending an investigation.\n\n\"I need you to get his reputation right,\" said Fortson. \"I know my son did not do anything to you guys.\"\n\n\"They have my word. If this shooting is found to be unjustified their son's name will be fully vindicated and justice will be served,\" said Sheriff Aden.\n\nSheriff Aden has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to investigate this shooting. FDLE sent us the following statement:\n\n\"At the request of the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) is investigating the deputy-involved shooting that occurred on May 3.\n\nFDLE use-of-force cases are independent, fact-finding investigations. The results are referred to the State Attorney's office to determine further action.\n\nAs this investigation is active, we do not have additional information to provide at this time.\"", "source":
