{"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119888757", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:50:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:50:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:49:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.fox10tv.com/2024/05/09/ocso-releases-body-cam-video-deadly-deputy-involved-shooting-an-active-duty-senior-airman/", "title": "OCSO releases body cam video of deadly deputy involved shooting of an active duty senior airman", "body": "SHALIMAR, Fla. (WALA) -This body camera video from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office shows what led up to the deputy involved shooting death of 23-year-old Senior Airman Roger Fortson. His mother Meka Fortson says her son was living out his dream of serving in the air force and providing a better life for his family.\n\n\"Roger wanted to show his mama who raised five kids that didn't know what credit was how to have something,\" said Roger's mother Meka Fortson. \"Roger wanted to put his mama in a house.\"\n\nHis family, who is represented by civil rights attorney Ben Crump says Fortson was alone at his apartment last Friday when he heard a loud knock on his door while on facetime with his girlfriend.\n\n\"She talked about how he went to the door to look through the peep hole but it was as if someone was covering up the peep whole so someone couldn't see out of it and he kept saying who is it,\" said civil rights attorney Ben Crump. \"And how he went and retrieved his legally registered gun as a gun owner to protect his house.\"\n\nFortson's mother still emotional while remembering that day.\n\n\"My baby was shot up they took my gift,\" said Fortson.\n\nAfter showing the family the body camera video, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden says he offered condolences to the family but wanted to set the record straight on the facts so far.\n\n\"We are aware of a press release and other comments that falsely state our deputy entered the wrong apartment and implied that they burst through the door into Mr. Fortson's residence,\" said Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden.\n\nOCSO says they were at the complex responding to a disturbance call. In the video the deputy knocks on the door and steps away for several seconds before knocking again and announcing himself twice before the door is opened. In the video Fortson does not appear to raise his gun before the shots were fired.\n\nOCSO says the deputy acted in self-defense after seeing the gun. Meanwhile Fortson's family is asking for the sheriff's office to clear his name which Sheriff Aden promised would happen pending an investigation.\n\n\"I need you to get his reputation right,\" said Fortson. \"I know my son did not do anything to you guys.\"\n\n\"They have my word. If this shooting is found to be unjustified their son's name will be fully vindicated and justice will be served,\" said Sheriff Aden.\n\nSheriff Aden has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to investigate this shooting. FDLE sent us the following statement:\n\n\"At the request of the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) is investigating the deputy-involved shooting that occurred on May 3.\n\nFDLE use-of-force cases are independent, fact-finding investigations. The results are referred to the State Attorney's office to determine further action.\n\nAs this investigation is active, we do not have additional information to provide at this time.\"", "source": {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119893836", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:56:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:56:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:56:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mn/body-camera-video-shows-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman-by-florida-deputy-in-apartment-doorway/article_4126ea3f-f900-59b9-9b1b-2972cabad7a5.html", "title": "Body camera video shows fatal shooting of Black airman by Florida deputy in apartment doorway", "body": "Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden holds a news conference where he shared deputy body cam footage of the May 3, 2024 shooting of Roger Fortson, a U.S. Navy airman, Thursday, May 9, 2024, in Fort Walton Beach, Fla. Fortson was shot in his apartment after a response to a complaint.\n\nBy STEPHEN SMITH and MIKE SCHNEIDER - Associated Press\n\nFORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense. Aden rejected assertions made by civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, that the deputy had gone to the wrong apartment, covered the door's peephole and did not announce himself.\n\nThe video shows the deputy arriving at a Fort Walton Beach apartment building on May 3 and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school Coaches association warns Waunakee basketball lawsuit 'sets dangerous precedent' Onalaska registered sex offender arrested for possession of child pornography Joe Gow's teaching position at issue as UW-La Crosse Faculty Senate to hear unethical conduct allegations Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire Onalaska man faces 60 years for alleged sexual assault of girls River Point District developers hit stride as buildings rise along La Crosse riverfront Viroqua High School's Kami Delap wins silver at national powerlifting championship Paul S. Schemenauer Extra Effort: Luther High student overcomes school difficulties on her way to education career American Airlines reintroduces higher capacity E175 jets at La Crosse Regional Airport Extra effort: Holmen teen with brain tumor achieves academic success\n\nThe video shows the deputy banging on the door and stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office! Open the door!\"\n\nFortson opened the door and could be seen holding what appeared to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" and fired off shots. He then shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun!\"\n\n\"It's over there,\" Fortson said.\n\n\"Drop the gun!\" the deputy yelled back.\n\n\"I don't have it,\" Fortson said, lying on the ground.\n\nThe deputy then called paramedics on his radio.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputy or his race. The deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump released a statement later noting that the officer did not tell Fortson to drop his gun before shooting \"multiple times within a split second of the door being opened.\"\n\n\"We remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment,\" the statement said.\n\nCrump also told reporters earlier that Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime and that he grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment. He said that the deputy burst into the apartment, citing the account of the girlfriend, who has not yet been identified.\n\n\"The girlfriend acknowledges that even though she initially thought the door was forced open by the police that she stands by her emotional recollection of what happened,\" Crump's later statement said.\n\nIn a clip from the FaceTime video captured by Fortson's cellphone, the airman can be heard groaning and saying, \"I can't breathe.\" A deputy can be heard yelling back at him, \"Stop moving!\" The phone is pointed at the ceiling and does not show what is going on in the apartment.\n\nAden said he had met with the family Thursday and extended his deepest condolences.\n\n\"This result is one we never hope to encounter,\" Aden said. \"These investigations take time, but I want to assure you that we are not hiding or attempting to cover anything up.\"\n\nOfficials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating. FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nThe sheriff said the probe was being handled as a criminal investigation and that no determination had yet been made on whether the deputy's actions were justified or not. However, the initial news release from the sheriff's office that described the shooting said that the deputy \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times.\n\nFortson enlisted in the Air Force after graduating high school, Crump said. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile cases of Black people in fatal encounters with law enforcement and vigilantes, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes.\n\nIn 2018, a white Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nIn 2019, a white Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\nThis story has been updated to correct the spelling of the name of Fortson's mother to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki and to reflect that some of the cases Crump has been involved with were encounters with vigilantes, not just law enforcement.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119896547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:00:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:00:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:59:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/body-camera-video-shows-fatal-shooting-of-black-airman-by-florida-deputy-in-apartment-doorway/article_7e5f8c07-0817-5072-9683-001d2b0a10ed.html", "title": "Body camera video shows fatal shooting of Black airman by Florida deputy in apartment doorway", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- A Florida sheriff's deputy announced himself as law enforcement just before fatally shooting a Black U.S. Air Force airman inside his apartment in the state's Panhandle, according to body camera video shown to reporters Thursday.\n\nOkaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden presented the video hours after the family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson and their attorneys held a news conference in which they disputed that the deputy acted in self-defense. Aden rejected assertions made by civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, that the deputy had gone to the wrong apartment, covered the door's peephole and did not announce himself.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe video shows the deputy arriving at a Fort Walton Beach apartment building on May 3 and speaking to a woman outside who described hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe video shows the deputy banging on the door and stepping aside, seemingly out of view of the door. Twice he shouted: \"Sheriff's office! Open the door!\"\n\nFortson opened the door and could be seen holding what appeared to be handgun pointed down toward the floor. The deputy shouted, \"Step back!\" and fired off shots. He then shouted, \"Drop the gun! Drop the gun!\"\n\n\"It's over there,\" Fortson said.\n\n\"Drop the gun!\" the deputy yelled back.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I don't have it,\" Fortson said, lying on the ground.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe deputy then called paramedics on his radio.\n\nThe sheriff's office has declined to identify the responding deputy or his race. The deputy was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation.\n\nCrump released a statement later noting that the officer did not tell Fortson to drop his gun before shooting \"multiple times within a split second of the door being opened.\"\n\n\"We remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment,\" the statement said.\n\nCrump also told reporters earlier that Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime and that he grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment. He said that the deputy burst into the apartment, citing the account of the girlfriend, who has not yet been identified.\n\n\"The girlfriend acknowledges that even though she initially thought the door was forced open by the police that she stands by her emotional recollection of what happened,\" Crump's later statement said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn a clip from the FaceTime video captured by Fortson's cellphone, the airman can be heard groaning and saying, \"I can't breathe.\" A deputy can be heard yelling back at him, \"Stop moving!\" The phone is pointed at the ceiling and does not show what is going on in the apartment.\n\nAden said he had met with the family Thursday and extended his deepest condolences.\n\n\"This result is one we never hope to encounter,\" Aden said. \"These investigations take time, but I want to assure you that we are not hiding or attempting to cover anything up.\"\n\nOfficials have said the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating. FDLE spokeswoman Gretl Plessinger told The Associated Press on Wednesday that it is unlikely the agency will have any further comment until the investigation is complete.\n\nThe sheriff said the probe was being handled as a criminal investigation and that no determination had yet been made on whether the deputy's actions were justified or not. However, the initial news release from the sheriff's office that described the shooting said that the deputy \"reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.\"\n\nFortson's mother, Chantemekki Fortson, walked into the morning news conference with Crump holding a framed portrait of her son in his dress uniform. She burst into tears as Crump spoke about her son's death.\n\n\"My baby was shot up,\" she said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCrump called the shooting \"an unjustifiable killing.\"\n\n\"For whatever reason, they thought he was a bad guy, but he was a good guy. He was a great guy. He was an exceptional guy,\" Crump said. \"They took a patriot from us.\"\n\nCrump said Fortson, originally from Atlanta, was shot six times.\n\nFortson enlisted in the Air Force after graduating high school, Crump said. He was based at the Special Operations Wing at Hurlburt Field. As a special missions aviator, one of his roles was to load the gunship's cannons during missions.\n\nCrump, based in Tallahassee, Florida, has been involved in multiple high-profile cases of Black people in fatal encounters with law enforcement and vigilantes, including those of Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin, Tyre Nichols, George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, who was also killed in her home during a no-knock police raid that targeted her ex-boyfriend in 2020.\n\nFortson's death draws striking similarities to other Black people killed in recent years by police in their homes.\n\nIn 2018, a white Dallas police officer fatally shot Botham Jean, who was unarmed, after mistaking his apartment for her own. Amber Guyger, the former officer, was convicted of murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn 2019, a white Fort Worth, Texas, officer fatally shot Atatiana Jefferson through a rear window of her home after responding to a nonemergency call reporting that Jefferson's front door was open. Aaron Dean, the former officer, was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nCrump represented families in both cases as part of his effort to force accountability for the killings of Black people at the hands of police.\n\n___\n\nSchneider reported from Orlando, Fla.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been updated to correct the spelling of the name of Fortson's mother to Chantemekki instead of Chantimekki and to reflect that some of the cases Crump has been involved with were encounters with vigilantes, not just law enforcement.", "source": {"uri": {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119900564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:07:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:07:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:04:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/airman-shot-deputy-doted-little-230130022.html", "title": "Airman shot by deputy doted on little sister and aimed to buy mom a house, family says", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- Just two days before a sheriff's deputy in Florida shot him dead, U.S. Air Force airman Roger Fortson called home to find out what his 10-year-old sister wanted for her birthday.\n\nIt was a typical gesture for the 23-year-old from Atlanta, who doted on the girl and was devoted to helping her, a younger brother and his mom prosper, his family says.\n\n\"He was trying to give me everything that I never could get for myself,\" his mother, Chantemekki Fortson, said Thursday at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach, where her son was living when he was killed.\n\nHe was her \"gift,\" she said, the man who taught her to love and forgive and served as her co-worker and counselor.\n\nAn Okaloosa County sheriff's deputy shot Fortson on May 3. Sheriff's officials say he acted in self-defense while responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex. But civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing the Fortson family, has accused the deputy of going to the wrong apartment and said the shooting was unjustified.\n\nThe Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating.\n\nAt Thursday's news conference, Chantemekki Fortson held a large framed portrait of her son in dress uniform. He joined the Air Force in 2019, the same year he graduated from Ronald McNair -- a majority Black high school in metro Atlanta's DeKalb County where roughly half of students don't graduate in four years.\n\nAir Force service was a lifelong dream, and Fortson rose to the rank of senior airman. He was stationed at Hurlburt Field near Fort Walton Beach.\n\n\"Where we come from, we don't end up where Roger ended up,\" his mother said.\n\nFortson, a gunner aboard the AC-130J, earned an Air Medal with combat device, which is typically awarded after 20 flights in a combat zone or for conspicuous valor or achievement on a single mission. An Air Force official said Fortson's award reflected both -- completing flights in a combat zone and taking specific actions during one of the missions to address an in-flight emergency and allow the mission to continue. The official spoke on the condition of anonymity to provide additional details that had not been made public.\n\nBut his service, like almost everything else he did, had a larger purpose.\n\n\"He was trying to help his family have a better life,\" Crump said Thursday.\n\nThat meant serving as a role model for his 16-year-old brother, his mom said, saving up to try to buy her a house, and getting her a new car. His nickname was \"Mr. Make It Happen.\"\n\nChantemekki Fortson recalled that her son, then in high school, accompanied her in an ambulance to the hospital when she was giving birth to her daughter and tried to tell the doctor how to deliver the baby.\n\nThe girl and his brother were always in his thoughts. Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons.\n\nChantemekki Fortson said her son was injured while loading a plane and was in such severe pain he thought he would die. But he told his mom he had to push through for his brother and sister.\n\nHe was also by her side when she got into an accident a short time later and needed to go the emergency room.\n\n\"That's the kind of gift he was,\" she said. \"They took something that can never be replaced.\"\n\n___\n\nThanawala reported from Atlanta. Associated Press writer Tara Copp in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119902264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:06:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:06:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:06:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://ktar.com/story/5573099/killing-of-an-airman-by-florida-deputy-is-among-cases-of-black-people-being-shot-in-their-homes/", "title": "Killing of an airman by Florida deputy is among cases of Black people being shot in their homes", "body": "The fatal shooting of a U.S. Air Force airman at his off-base apartment in the Florida Panhandle by a sheriff's deputy brings to mind other instances of Black people being killed by law enforcement in their own homes as they're going about their day.\n\nSenior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was killed on May 3 in his apartment in Fort Walton Beach. Body camera video viewed by reporters Thursday shows the Okaloosa County deputy arriving at the apartment building and speaking to a woman who described someone hearing an argument. The deputy then went up an elevator and walked down an outdoor hallway.\n\nOn the body camera video, the deputy can be heard yelling that he was from the sheriff's department and knocking, while also stepping seemingly out of view of the door. The video then shows Fortson opening the door with what appears to be a gun in his hand pointed toward the ground.\n\nThe deputy quickly fires several shots, yelling for Fortson to drop the gun after he is already on the ground wounded.\n\nAttorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, has said Fortson was talking to his girlfriend on FaceTime and grabbed his gun because he heard someone outside his apartment.\n\nCrump said in a Thursday statement that \"we remain adamant\" that law enforcement went to the wrong apartment. The sheriff rejects that assertion.\n\nBotham Jean, an 26-year-old Black man, was fatally shot in 2018 by a white police officer who mistook his Dallas apartment for her own.\n\nAmber Guyger was still in uniform after a long shift when she walked up to Jean's apartment -- which was on the fourth floor, directly above hers on the third -- and found the door unlocked.\n\nJean, an accountant from the Caribbean island nation of St. Lucia, had been eating a bowl of ice cream when Guyger entered his home and shot him. He was unarmed.\n\nGuyger, the former officer, was found guilty in 2019 and sentenced to 10 years in prison.\n\nAtatiana Jefferson, a 28-year-old Black woman, was fatally shot through a window at her home in 2019 by Aaron Dean, a white officer, as he responded to a nonemergency call about the door to her Fort Worth, Texas, home being open.\n\nBody camera footage showed that Dean and a second officer didn't identify themselves as police at the house. Both testified at Dean's trial that they thought the house might have been burglarized and quietly moved into the fenced-off backyard looking for signs of forced entry.\n\nJefferson and her then-8-year-old nephew, Zion Carr, were up late playing video games. They'd left doors open to vent smoke after earlier burning hamburgers.\n\nCarr testified that Jefferson took out her gun because she believed there was an intruder in the backyard. Dean fired a single shot through the window a split-second after shouting at Jefferson, who was inside, to show her hands.\n\nDean was found guilty of manslaughter in 2022 and the former officer was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison.\n\nAiyana Stanley-Jones, a 7-year-old Black girl, was fatally shot inside her family's Detroit home in 2010 by police who burst into the wrong unit of a duplex while looking for a man suspected in a killing that had been committed days earlier. The suspect was eventually arrested in the second-floor unit of the duplex.\n\nAiyana was shot in the head while sleeping on a couch.\n\nJoseph Weekley, a member of an elite police unit, was the first officer through the door of her home. Weekley, who is white, said he accidentally fired his gun during a struggle with Aiyana's grandmother.\n\nWeekley was charged with involuntary manslaughter but his first trial ended without a verdict in 2013 and his second ended in 2015 with a hung jury. During the second trial, a judge dismissed that charge.\n\nBreonna Taylor, a 26-year-old Black woman, was killed by police officers who knocked down the door to her apartment in Louisville, Kentucky, in 2020 while executing a drug search warrant that was later found to be flawed.\n\nTaylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, fired a single shot that hit one of the officers as they came through the door of the apartment, and officers returned fire, striking Taylor in the apartment hallway multiple times.\n\nWalker told police investigators that he heard knocking but did not hear police announce themselves. He said he was \"scared to death,\" so he grabbed his gun and when the door was knocked down, he fired a shot.\n\nOfficers found no drugs in Taylor's apartment.\n\nFormer Louisville officer Brett Hankison, who is white, fired 10 shots into Taylor's window and glass door, was found not guilty in 2022 on state charges that he endangered her neighbors when he opened fire. Some of his shots flew into a neighboring apartment, but none of them struck anyone.\n\nLast year a jury deadlocked over federal civil rights charges that Hankison used excessive force that night. Federal prosecutors have said they intend to retry him.\n\nThree other former officers involved in drawing up the warrant were charged in a separate federal case. One of them, Kelly Goodlett, has pleaded guilty to helping falsify the warrant. She's expected to testify against the other two in the upcoming trial.", "source": {"uri": "ktar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTAR News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@ktar.com", {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119900564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:07:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:07:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:04:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/airman-shot-deputy-doted-little-230130022.html", "title": "Airman shot by deputy doted on little sister and aimed to buy mom a house, family says", "body": "FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- Just two days before a sheriff's deputy in Florida shot him dead, U.S. Air Force airman Roger Fortson called home to find out what his 10-year-old sister wanted for her birthday.\n\nIt was a typical gesture for the 23-year-old from Atlanta, who doted on the girl and was devoted to helping her, a younger brother and his mom prosper, his family says.\n\n\"He was trying to give me everything that I never could get for myself,\" his mother, Chantemekki Fortson, said Thursday at a news conference in Fort Walton Beach, where her son was living when he was killed.\n\nHe was her \"gift,\" she said, the man who taught her to love and forgive and served as her co-worker and counselor.\n\nAn Okaloosa County sheriff's deputy shot Fortson on May 3. Sheriff's officials say he acted in self-defense while responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex. But civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing the Fortson family, has accused the deputy of going to the wrong apartment and said the shooting was unjustified.\n\nThe Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating.\n\nAt Thursday's news conference, Chantemekki Fortson held a large framed portrait of her son in dress uniform. He joined the Air Force in 2019, the same year he graduated from Ronald McNair -- a majority Black high school in metro Atlanta's DeKalb County where roughly half of students don't graduate in four years.\n\nAir Force service was a lifelong dream, and Fortson rose to the rank of senior airman. He was stationed at Hurlburt Field near Fort Walton Beach.\n\n\"Where we come from, we don't end up where Roger ended up,\" his mother said.\n\nFortson, a gunner aboard the AC-130J, earned an Air Medal with combat device, which is typically awarded after 20 flights in a combat zone or for conspicuous valor or achievement on a single mission. An Air Force official said Fortson's award reflected both -- completing flights in a combat zone and taking specific actions during one of the missions to address an in-flight emergency and allow the mission to continue. The official spoke on the condition of anonymity to provide additional details that had not been made public.\n\nBut his service, like almost everything else he did, had a larger purpose.\n\n\"He was trying to help his family have a better life,\" Crump said Thursday.\n\nThat meant serving as a role model for his 16-year-old brother, his mom said, saving up to try to buy her a house, and getting her a new car. His nickname was \"Mr. Make It Happen.\"\n\nChantemekki Fortson recalled that her son, then in high school, accompanied her in an ambulance to the hospital when she was giving birth to her daughter and tried to tell the doctor how to deliver the baby.\n\nThe girl and his brother were always in his thoughts. Fortson was assigned to the 4th Special Operations Squadron as a special missions aviator, where one of his roles was to load the gunship's 30mm and 105mm cannons.\n\nChantemekki Fortson said her son was injured while loading a plane and was in such severe pain he thought he would die. But he told his mom he had to push through for his brother and sister.\n\nHe was also by her side when she got into an accident a short time later and needed to go the emergency room.\n\n\"That's the kind of gift he was,\" she said. \"They took something that can never be replaced.\"\n\n___\n\nThanawala reported from Atlanta. {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119904205", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:09:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:09:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:08:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/crime/roger-fortson-airman-airforce-b2542599.html", "title": "Police release bodycam footage in Air Force airman shooting", "body": "Police have released bodycam footage of the fatal shooting of an Air Force airman at his Florida home after his family alleged that an officer responded to the wrong address.\n\nUS Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was shot on 3 May 2024 by a deputy from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office in Fort Walton Beach, Florida.\n\nDuring a news conference on Thursday, Fortson's family claimed that the deputy went to the wrong apartment and did not announce himself to the service member when he banged on the man's door at the Elan Apartments by ARIUM.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, the sheriff's office released four minutes of bodycam footage worn by the officer.\n\nIn the clip, the officer, who has not been identified by the department, is seen banging on the man's home three times and shouting \"Sheriff's office open the door\" twice.\n\nMr Fortson comes to the door and opens it. The officer then asks the man to step back and after seeing a firearm, immediately shoots him six times. It's unclear in the bodycam footage if Fortson indeed had a gun in his hand. After he was shot, the officer yelled at him to \"drop the gun\". Fortson then replied with \"It's over there\" and said, \"I don't have it\".\n\nThe deputy then radios to alert nearby police officers that shots have been fired at the residence and to request that emergency medical services respond to the scene. The Air Force member was taken to a nearby hospital where he died from his injuries.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference, Sheriff Eric Aden maintained that the deputy did knock on the correct door and that any statements made by the family and Ben Crump, the famed civil rights attorney retained to represent them, are inaccurate.\n\nThe deputy has been placed on paid administrative leave until a formal investigation into the matter and an administrative review are complete, per standard protocol.\n\nMr Crump told reporters at a separate news conference on Thursday that Fortson heard a knock at the door and replied \"Who is it?\" but did not get a response. He then said the service member heard a second knock and tried to look through the peephole to see who it was but it appeared as though someone had tried to cover it up.\n\nThe man then went to retrieve a firearm, which he legally had in his possession, the attorney said. When he returned, the deputy had busted through the door and was in the apartment, Crump said.\n\nThat narrative differs from what's shown in the bodycam footage.\n\nFortson's girlfriend was on the phone with him at the time of the shooting, the attorney continued. Once he was shot, she said she could see him on the ground saying \"I can't breathe\".\n\nThe man's family has called for a formal investigation into the matter. Sheriff Aden said that he has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation, a step that is typical in such shootings. The state attorney's office will conduct an independent review.\n\nProving wrongdoing in the case could be difficult as most police policies allow officers to use force if they're presented with a firearm.\n\nChantimekki Fortson, the airman's mother, appeared at the Thursday news conference clutching onto a framed Air Force portrait of her son and sobbing onto a friend's shoulder.\n\nShe described the service member as intelligent and compassionate.\n\n\"Where we come from, you don't end up where Roger ended up,\" she said, speaking of her son's military accomplishments.\n\nAn Air Force spokesperson said Fortson had entered the service in November 2019. He was stationed in a special operations squadron based on Hurlburt Field, an air base in Okaloosa County.\n\nHis decorations included an Air Medal with C Device, meaning he'd served in combat, and an Air Force Achievement Medal.\n\nMs Fortson demanded that the sheriff's department \"tell the truth about her son\" and clear his reputation, which she said has been tarnished by the sheriff's department's revelations.\n\n\"I know my son did not do anything to you guys,\" she said.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has come under fire in the past.\n\nLast year, a sheriff's deputy shot at an unarmed and handcuffed man after mistaking the sound of an acorn hitting his cruiser for a gunshot. The office determined that the deputy had used excessive force but he was cleared of criminal wrongdoing.\n\nThe deputy resigned while he was under investigation.", "source": {"uri": {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119904205", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:09:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:09:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:08:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/crime/roger-fortson-airman-airforce-b2542599.html", "title": "Police release bodycam footage in Air Force airman shooting", "body": "Police have released bodycam footage of the fatal shooting of an Air Force airman at his Florida home after his family alleged that an officer responded to the wrong address.\n\nUS Air Force Senior Airman Roger Fortson, 23, was shot on 3 May 2024 by a deputy from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office in Fort Walton Beach, Florida.\n\nDuring a news conference on Thursday, Fortson's family claimed that the deputy went to the wrong apartment and did not announce himself to the service member when he banged on the man's door at the Elan Apartments by ARIUM.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, the sheriff's office released four minutes of bodycam footage worn by the officer.\n\nIn the clip, the officer, who has not been identified by the department, is seen banging on the man's home three times and shouting \"Sheriff's office open the door\" twice.\n\nMr Fortson comes to the door and opens it. The officer then asks the man to step back and after seeing a firearm, immediately shoots him six times. It's unclear in the bodycam footage if Fortson indeed had a gun in his hand. After he was shot, the officer yelled at him to \"drop the gun\". Fortson then replied with \"It's over there\" and said, \"I don't have it\".\n\nThe deputy then radios to alert nearby police officers that shots have been fired at the residence and to request that emergency medical services respond to the scene. The Air Force member was taken to a nearby hospital where he died from his injuries.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference, Sheriff Eric Aden maintained that the deputy did knock on the correct door and that any statements made by the family and Ben Crump, the famed civil rights attorney retained to represent them, are inaccurate.\n\nThe deputy has been placed on paid administrative leave until a formal investigation into the matter and an administrative review are complete, per standard protocol.\n\nMr Crump told reporters at a separate news conference on Thursday that Fortson heard a knock at the door and replied \"Who is it?\" but did not get a response. He then said the service member heard a second knock and tried to look through the peephole to see who it was but it appeared as though someone had tried to cover it up.\n\nThe man then went to retrieve a firearm, which he legally had in his possession, the attorney said. When he returned, the deputy had busted through the door and was in the apartment, Crump said.\n\nThat narrative differs from what's shown in the bodycam footage.\n\nFortson's girlfriend was on the phone with him at the time of the shooting, the attorney continued. Once he was shot, she said she could see him on the ground saying \"I can't breathe\".\n\nThe man's family has called for a formal investigation into the matter. Sheriff Aden said that he has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation, a step that is typical in such shootings. The state attorney's office will conduct an independent review.\n\nProving wrongdoing in the case could be difficult as most police policies allow officers to use force if they're presented with a firearm.\n\nChantimekki Fortson, the airman's mother, appeared at the Thursday news conference clutching onto a framed Air Force portrait of her son and sobbing onto a friend's shoulder.\n\nShe described the service member as intelligent and compassionate.\n\n\"Where we come from, you don't end up where Roger ended up,\" she said, speaking of her son's military accomplishments.\n\nAn Air Force spokesperson said Fortson had entered the service in November 2019. He was stationed in a special operations squadron based on Hurlburt Field, an air base in Okaloosa County.\n\nHis decorations included an Air Medal with C Device, meaning he'd served in combat, and an Air Force Achievement Medal.\n\nMs Fortson demanded that the sheriff's department \"tell the truth about her son\" and clear his reputation, which she said has been tarnished by the sheriff's department's revelations.\n\n\"I know my son did not do anything to you guys,\" she said.\n\nThe Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office has come under fire in the past.\n\nLast year, a sheriff's deputy shot at an unarmed and handcuffed man after mistaking the sound of an acorn hitting his cruiser for a gunshot. The office determined that the deputy had used excessive force but he was cleared of criminal wrongdoing.\n\nThe deputy resigned while he was under investigation.", "source": {"uri": {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119907026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:12:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:12:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:12:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/airman-shot-by-deputy-doted-on-little-sister-and-aimed-to-buy-mom-a-house-family-says", "title": "Airman shot by deputy doted on little sister and aimed to buy mom a house, family says", "body": "If you are a Home delivery print subscriber, unlimited online access is included in your subscription. Activate your Online Access Now\n\nHe was her \"gift,\" she said, the man who taught her to love and forgive and served as her co-worker and counselor.\n\nAn Okaloosa County sheriff's deputy shot Fortson on May 3. Sheriff's officials say he acted in self-defense while responding to a call of a disturbance in progress at the apartment complex. But civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing the Fortson family, has accused the deputy of going to the wrong apartment and said the shooting was unjustified.\n\nThe Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating.\n\nAt Thursday's news conference, Chantemekki Fortson held a large framed portrait of her son in dress uniform. He joined the Air Force in 2019, the same year he graduated from Ronald McNair -- a majority Black high school in metro Atlanta's DeKalb County where roughly half of students don't graduate in four years.\n\nAir Force service was a lifelong dream, and Fortson rose to the rank of senior airman. He was stationed at Hurlburt Field near Fort Walton Beach.\n\n\"Where we come from, we don't end up where Roger ended up,\" his mother said.\n\nFortson, a gunner aboard the AC-130J, earned an Air Medal with combat device, which is typically awarded after 20 flights in a combat zone or for conspicuous valor or achievement on a single mission. An Air Force official said Fortson's award reflected both _ completing flights in a combat zone and taking specific actions during one of the missions to address an in-flight emergency and allow the mission to continue. The official spoke on the condition of anonymity to provide additional details that had not been made public.", "source": {"uri": "nationalpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "National Post"}, {"eng-9546267": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119921154", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:30:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:30:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:29:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/texas/news/roger-fortson-us-airman-girlfriend-shooting-facetime/", "title": "Florida sheriff's deputy seen fatally shooting U.S. airman in newly released body camera video", "body": "A Florida sheriff's office released body camera video Thursday showing a sheriff's deputy shoot and kill a U.S. airman at his apartment last week while the deputy was responding to a disturbance call.\n\nThe video shows a deputy from the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office in the Florida panhandle knock on the door of Senior Airman Roger Fortson's apartment late Friday afternoon and announce he was with the sheriff's office. When the door opens, the deputy yells for Fortson, 23, to step back.\n\nAttorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson's family, has said that Fortson got his legally owned gun after hearing knocking on his door and not hearing who was there. In a bodycam video released Thursday, the deputy initially knocks without announcing himself. About 30 seconds later, he knocks again, saying he's with the sheriff's office and to open the door. He knocks and announces himself approximately 10 seconds later. Within seconds of Fortson opening the door, the deputy shoots Fortson who is seen holding what appears to be a handgun at his side.\n\nFortson, who is blurred in the video, immediately falls to the ground. He's seen moving on the floor as the deputy tells him to drop his gun.\n\n\"It's over there,\" Fortson is heard on the video telling the deputy. \"I don't have it.\"\n\nThe deputy tells Fortson to not move and then calls on his radio for emergency medical services before the video ends.\n\nDuring a news conference, Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden told reporters, \"It pains me to show the video, but I know that you all need to see it.\"\n\nFortson's family said in a statement that it was troubling that the deputy fired multiple times so quickly.\n\n\"The video has provided some answers, but it's also raised even more troubling questions,\" the family said. \"As the officer didn't tell Roger to drop the weapon before shooting, was the officer trained to give verbal warnings? Did the officer try to initiate life-saving measures? Was the officer trained to deal with law-abiding citizens who are registered gun owners?\"\n\nDuring the incident, Fortson was on a FaceTime call with his girlfriend. Crump's firm released a video of the call that appears to start after the shooting, showing the ceiling of Fortson's apartment.\n\n\"I can't breathe,\" Fortson says in the video while groaning.\n\nNo law enforcement officers are seen in the video, but some voices in the background of the video can be heard.\n\n\"Do not move,\" a voice shouts to Fortson. \"Stop moving. Stop moving.\"\n\nFortson was shot six times, Crump's law firm said. As someone in the background counted how many gunshot wounds Fortson had, a voice says, \"Yeah, he's shot up.\"\n\nAden didn't take any questions during the afternoon news conference. The deputy, who hasn't been identified, has been placed on administrative leave, and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the state attorney's office are investigating the shooting.\n\n\"These investigations take time, but I want to assure you that we are not hiding, covering up or taking action that would result in a rush to judgment of Mr. Fortson or our deputy,\" Aden said.\n\nEarlier Thursday, Crump said during a news conference Fortson was on FaceTime with his girlfriend when he heard knocking on his door, saw no one through the peephole and got his gun.\n\nCrump initially said the deputy entered Fortson's apartment, saw him with his gun and shot him. According to the family's statement after the bodycam video was released, the girlfriend thought the door was forced open by the deputy. The footage released during Aden's news conference showed the deputy firing several shots in an exterior hallway outside the door to Fortson's apartment.\n\n\"We remain adamant that the police had the wrong apartment as Roger was on the phone with his girlfriend for a substantial amount of time leading up to the shooting, and no one else was in the apartment,\" the family said.\n\nFortson's mother Chantemekki Fortson told reporters her son's girlfriend was devastated from the shooting.\n\n\"She literally watched them walk over him as he was dying, taking his last breath,\" Fortson said.\n\nCrump didn't identify the girlfriend but said she has an attorney.\n\n\"She was afraid that she just heard them and watch them kill her boyfriend,\" Crump told reporters.\n\nThe sheriff's office said in a statement Saturday the deputy was responding to a disturbance call, \"made contact with an armed individual at an apartment\" and acted in self-defense. In an updated statement Tuesday, Sheriff Eric Aden said the deputy \"encountered an armed man\" and shot him.\n\n\"All of us at the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Office are saddened about the fatal officer-involved shooting over the weekend,\" Aden said.\n\nDuring his news conference, Aden said he met with Fortson's family and extended them his condolences.\n\n\"This result is one we never hope to encounter,\" the sheriff said.\n\nCrump said the family was going to view the bodycam footage Thursday afternoon. The family called for the footage to be released to the public and for the sheriff's office to correct what they've said about the shooting.\n\n\"Do the right thing and correct this narrative,\" Crump said. \"Correct this narrative and don't put a stain on the name of this young man ... Do not try to put stain on his name, on his life, on his legacy.\"", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
